Lincoln Borglum took over leadership of the construction at that time, fulfilling his father’s vision for the monument.

“Underdog” is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. Its cast features Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

"The 100" follows a group of teens—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first from a space habitat called “The Ark” to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke’s mother), Marcus Kane (an Ark council member), and Thelonious Jaha (the Ark’s Chancellor and Wells’ father).

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering humanitarian aid project that, despite later financial issues, succeeded in raising significant awareness and funds, ultimately paving the way for future events such as Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized as an influential Indian filmmaker who revolutionized the Tamil film industry and shaped the profile of Indian cinema.

Stephen A. Douglas introduced the Freeport Doctrine during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate in Freeport, Illinois, on August 27, 1858. The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also called The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Douglas, the Democratic incumbent, and Abraham Lincoln, the Republican contender for the Illinois Senate seat. These debates, especially those held in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted substantial crowds, reflecting the nation’s intense interest in the issue of slavery.

“Easy A” is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. The film features an ensemble cast including Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O’Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She debuted professionally with “Interview with the Vampire” in 1976 and later wrote sequels in the 1980s. Although her initial reception was mixed, her popularity grew in that decade. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

Camden, located in Camden County, New Jersey, had 77,344 residents as of the 2010 Census. It ranks as the 12th most populous municipality in the state. In the early 1900s, its population was primarily European immigrants. A city, such as Camden, is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.

Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller‐drama film “The Canyons,” directed by Paul Schrader. Despite being an original work by Ellis, the film was critically derided.

The passage describes the Lincoln–Douglas Debates of 1858, also called The Great Debates of 1858. They consisted of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and Stephen Douglas, the incumbent Democratic Senator. These debates took place in seven towns across Illinois.

Homer is presented as the ancient Greek author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two foundational epic poems of Greek literature. Additionally, “The Thicket” is introduced as a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band combining Soundgarden’s Chris Cornell with Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk, primarily known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave, began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 alongside Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, Wilk has played in the band Prophets of Rage, which includes Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, features vocalist Zack de la Rocha, bassist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello, and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid—a critically acclaimed concept album and sequel to her debut EP—on Bad Boy Records.
Winter’s Tale is identified as a novel published in 1983, written by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town in northeastern Louisiana and is the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. Meanwhile, at the University of Mississippi, around 55% of undergraduates and 60% of the overall student body are from Mississippi, with 23% identifying as minorities, and international students representing 90 different nations.
The passage states that “Flaked” was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, with a scheduled premiere date of June 2, 2017.
Aaron Burr served twice in the New York State Assembly, became New York State Attorney General, was then elected as a U.S. senator from New York, and ultimately rose to serve as vice president.

Soyuz is a series of Soviet spacecraft, originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs, that remains in service today. It was developed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s, following the Voskhod spacecraft. The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch these spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, starting with eight unmanned test flights before conducting 19 manned launches. The name “Soyuz” (Russian for “Union”) references the Soviet Union.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine experienced internal conflicts, prompting Zack de la Rocha to leave and the band to break up. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before splitting in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and played at the Coachella Festival. “Renegades,” the group’s fourth studio album, came out on December 5, 2000, via Epic Records.

The passage describes the S&P BSE SENSEX—also known as the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX—as a free-float, market-weighted index of 30 financially strong companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. It also notes that Tata Motors is one of those companies, being listed on the BSE (including as part of the SENSEX), the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia and has an estimated population of 92.7 million, making it the 14th most populous country globally and the ninth in Asia. It shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, and maritime boundaries with Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam's economy has grown at one of the highest rates worldwide, and it ranked first among 11 major economies in the Global Growth Generators Index in 2011. Vietnam remains one of four one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film, serving as John Gatins’s directorial debut, which he both wrote and directed.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who committed two notable acts of violence against British rule and was executed at the age of 23, making him a prominent folk hero of the Indian independence movement. His popularity as a folk hero continued to grow after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in Aamir Khan’s film "Dangal," a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I was King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and became King of England and Ireland on 24 March 1603, uniting the crowns under his rule. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own institutions, James strongly supported the idea of a single parliament for both countries. During his reign in England, he faced significant challenges with Parliament, and he ruled until his death on 27 March 1625.

Danielle Cormack, born on 26 December 1970 in New Zealand, is a stage and screen actress known for her early role in the soap opera Shortland Street. She also portrayed Amazon Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her work includes the film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and the role of Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Notably, Cormack played Bea Smith in the prison drama Wentworth for four years, leaving the series in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred or co-starred in several films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, released in 2015, was directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress who was born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but achieved significant commercial success. It debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming Gaga’s second consecutive number-one record in the United States. The album went on to sell 757,000 copies there and placed ninth in global sales for 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.

John Frusciante’s fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, titled “Stadium Arcadium,” was released in 2006. This album was also the band’s last to feature Frusciante, who departed in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, introduced policies known as Thatcherism. While she remains controversial, she is praised as one of Britain’s greatest and most influential politicians, even as debates over her policies continue.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his musical career, he has written weekly columns covering varied subjects for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, in addition to acting, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community called the Valencian Community (also referred to as the Valencian Country). It is Spain’s third-largest city, after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center. Its metropolitan area is also the country’s third-largest, with a population estimated between 1.7 and 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
"Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season, following an announcement on April 26, 2012, stating that it would be the final season. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics, drawing on linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to convert spoken language into text. Its applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, appliance control, data entry, and aircraft direct voice input. Recent advances are driven by deep learning, with companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, and others adopting this technology in their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International. Founded with Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 (later known as the San Diego Comic Book Convention), Alf also served as its chairman starting in 1970.
"Fist of Legend" is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," originally starring Bruce Lee in the lead role.

France’s Victor Dubuisson and South Africa’s Van Zyl share the lead on 16 under par, with Rory McIlroy and Kiradech Aphibarnrat one shot behind at 15 under. McIlroy, seeking his first title since May, posted a third straight 67, highlighted by an eagle on the 12th. Despite dropping his first shots of the week, McIlroy rebounded with a birdie and another eagle on the 13th. After an ankle injury in July and a return in time for the US PGA and FedEx Cup events, he is now targeting a third Race to Dubai title and currently leads Danny Willett in the standings. Meanwhile, Chris Wood sits at 13 under and Richard Bland at 12 under.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of the opposition group al-Wefaq, calls for a meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain backed by “concrete solutions” from the government. He insists that such talks require a royal representative, noting Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa is viewed as a reformist in a monarchy split between hardliners—led by the long-serving prime minister—and those open to granting concessions to the opposition. Sheikh Salman emphasizes that many younger protesters have lost trust in traditional opposition leaders, yet he still believes working with reform-minded figures in the ruling family is the best path forward. He recounts a 2011 agreement with the crown prince to move Bahrain toward a constitutional monarchy, which was derailed soon after by the arrival of Gulf Co-operation Council troops. Sheikh Salman expresses hope that U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry will exert more pressure for democratic reform and human rights, and calls on the British government to speak out publicly rather than privately. He also demands the release of 13 detained opposition figures, warning that without them, any dialogue risks failure.

Christopher Hogwood, a leading figure in the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home following a months-long illness. Known for founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it for nearly three decades, he led the ensemble in pioneering performances and more than 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His celebrated 1980 recording of Handel’s “Messiah” was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied at Cambridge and initially worked as a keyboard player and musicologist. He also served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival, Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic posts at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues remembered him for his generosity, intellectual depth, and dedication to letting the music “speak for itself.” A private funeral and a later memorial service were announced.

Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims in the year ending March 2016—the lowest number since 1976 and half the figure of nine years ago, with one case unresolved. Sharp instruments were used in 51% of these cases (mostly knives), and 31% of accused individuals were identified as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the decline but stressed continued efforts against violence and alcohol misuse. Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker similarly acknowledged the downward trend but urged caution, noting that previous figures had been revised upwards and highlighting rises in sexual crime and other serious violence. The total for 2014–15 was revised from 59 to 62 after reclassification.

Bournemouth suffered a 2-1 defeat at Sunderland—Sunderland’s first Premier League win this season—despite taking an early lead through Dan Gosling’s first goal in three games. Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe (from a penalty) scored for Sunderland, who played the latter stages with 10 men after Steven Pienaar’s sending-off. Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe, citing their six goals against Hull just weeks earlier, denied a crisis of confidence and stressed they created enough chances to win the match. He added that the key challenge is how the team responds to such setbacks.

Australia’s policy of detaining migrant boats has been branded “brutal” and “inhumane” by the New York Times, yet Prime Minister Tony Abbott asserts it is vital to stop deaths at sea. After the widely publicized death of a Syrian child, Abbott reiterated that preventing “illegal boats” was the only way to save lives. Separately, Australian Jewish groups criticized Abbott for claiming the so-called Islamic State was worse than the Nazis, pointing out that IS’s atrocities cannot be compared to the systematic genocide perpetrated by Nazi Germany. Though Abbott stood by his remarks, he maintained he was not “ranking evil.”

Washington has suspended bilateral peace talks with Russia, accusing it and the Syrian government of escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo and violating commitments made under a recent truce. Heavy bombardments have struck the rebel-held eastern side of the city, including hospitals, leaving hundreds dead and trapping roughly 250,000 people. The US faulted Russia for failing to rein in Syrian government forces and blamed them for a deadly strike on an aid convoy, which Moscow denies. Russia, in turn, criticized the US for not improving humanitarian conditions around Aleppo and not separating jihadist militants from moderate rebels. While the US is withdrawing personnel meant for joint coordination, both sides plan to continue discussions focused on counter-terrorism to avoid direct conflict.

Policy Exchange proposes selling off vacant, high-value social housing—as much as 21.8% of the total stock—to raise an estimated £4.5bn annually. They argue this could fund a major social house building program, potentially creating 80,000 to 170,000 new homes and cutting social housing waiting lists by up to 500,000 people. The prime minister’s office supports efforts by councils to use existing social housing stock more efficiently, while Labour contends that the plan would break up mixed communities and force out low-income earners. Critics also raise concerns about segregating poorer residents away from costly neighborhoods. The government highlights its own measures to boost housebuilding, including private and public investment of £19.5bn to deliver up to 170,000 homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his Swansea home amid a measles outbreak that has seen 942 cases and 83 hospitalisations since November. He had recently been discharged from Morriston Hospital, where he was treated for asthma, but soon developed a widespread rash and visited an out-of-hours GP on 17 April. He was found dead the next day. While laboratory tests confirmed measles, further tests are needed to determine the exact cause of death. An inquest has been opened and adjourned. His family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, were infected.

Vincent Hudson, 54, from Loweswater Avenue in Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16, reportedly committed in 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court.

Guiseley, unbeaten in five, opened the scoring through Jake Lawlor on 15 minutes against Gateshead, who were protecting a nine-match unbeaten run. After Guiseley’s lead held until half-time, Wes York equalized in the 62nd minute, capitalizing on a defensive slip to curl the ball into the top-right corner. The match ended 1-1, with both sides making substitutions and seeing yellow cards in a competitive National League contest.

Bristol Sport Ltd intends to replace two stands at the football club as an alternative to constructing a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which was delayed by a town green application. The council approved the redevelopment in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown expects to sign a section 106 agreement imminently. If no judicial review is initiated within six weeks, work on the stands will begin in May.

Cuadrilla suspended its shale gas fracking operations following a 1.5 magnitude tremor—its second in two months—near Poulton-le-Fylde. The British Geological Survey (BGS) will analyze data to assess any link between the tremors and fracking. BGS noted that both the recent quake and one in April (magnitude 2.3) likely shared a similar location and mechanism, and explained that injecting pressurized water into deep rock formations can trigger seismic activity. Despite environmental concerns about fracking—particularly in the US—the UK’s Commons energy select committee recently supported the process, suggesting strong regulation and good practices could mitigate risks. Cuadrilla’s chief executive, Mark Miller, stated that operations would remain suspended pending further consultation and data analysis.

Angus Carpenter, an experienced busker in Liverpool, was tried for three counts of fraud related to displaying a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes while performing. He was found guilty of one count—playing in April 2015 with the banner—after Sgt Chris Gaynor said it gave the impression he was collecting money on behalf of the charity. Carpenter maintained he was simply busking and had previously been authorized to display the banner as a tribute, rather than to solicit funds. He was cleared of the other two charges and will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town convincingly won 3–0 against Queens Park Rangers, with Grant Ward’s initial goal followed by Luke Varney scoring into an empty net after an Alex Smithies clearance error, and Tom Lawrence finishing off the victory. Ipswich had multiple further chances, including a header wide by Christophe Berra and a saved volley from Cole Skuse. QPR’s best moment was Sandro’s header against the post late on. After the match, Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised Smithies for preventing a heavier defeat despite his costly mistake, and highlighted Varney’s contribution. QPR boss Ian Holloway saw the second goal as a turning point, criticizing his side’s lack of mental toughness. The result lifted Ipswich to 14th in the table, pushing QPR down to 15th.

Wells, 23, delivered a strong performance in the T20 Blast last season by amassing 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club’s positive direction, highlighting the coaches’ elite-performance environment, which he believes is motivating the players to be part of the team.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive victory by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher praised key front-row players—Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams—for making over 70 tackles. With seven of their next eight opponents ranked below them, plus a match against top-placed Old Elthamians, Churcher sees room for improvement and emphasizes building on their recent strong performance.

Police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul (known as Nazu), a Bangladeshi citizen, raped the 74-year-old nun at a convent in Ranaghat on 14 March. He was arrested at a Kolkata railway station, reportedly after fleeing to Bangladesh and being identified on CCTV. This is the sixth arrest among eight total suspects, with two still untraced. The attack caused nationwide outrage, sparking street protests in multiple cities, and involved theft and ransacking at the convent school before the nun was assaulted.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains in an interactive video how consumer choices in the UK have shifted due to factors like the arrival of the domestic freezer, the introduction of washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also highlights changes in the ownership and ranking of major brands in the UK. A non-interactive version is available, along with links to further resources such as information on Chinese ownership, food-freezing tips, an annual survey of the top 20 consumer brands in the UK, and details about the Museum of Brands.

Two phone scam incidents are described, one on 15 September involving a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills and another a week later in Stranraer. In both cases, someone posing as a BT technical support worker claimed there were internet problems, gained remote access to the victims’ computers, and stole money. Police warn people never to provide banking details or allow remote computer access when responding to cold calls, as legitimate organizations do not request such information over the phone.

John Duffy, aged 37 and Scotland’s assistant coach, has joined Featherstone Rovers on a one-year deal following his departure from Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league match against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy’s impressive work under challenging conditions at Swinton. Having enjoyed a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, Duffy is replaced at Swinton by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. They found an injured rider with head injuries who had been lying unconscious on wet sand, causing her to become very cold. After receiving treatment, she was transported to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva allocated part of the radio spectrum for real-time global flight tracking in response to weaknesses highlighted by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in 2014. Representatives from over 160 countries agreed to let satellites receive existing ADS-B signals, now used only by other aircraft and ground stations. This move, led by the UN’s International Telecommunication Union, will enable worldwide real-time tracking of planes, addressing gaps that leave 70% of the globe uncovered by current radar systems. The UN’s aviation arm, ICAO, set a November 2016 deadline for airlines to send position data every 15 minutes, or more often in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez vanished at age five in 2002 and was discovered living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. The father was arrested after a tip surfaced when Julian had trouble applying for college, prompting an investigation by the FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Authorities confirmed Julian’s identity and notified his mother, while Bobby Hernandez remains in custody on charges that include tampering with records to get a driver’s license.

A fire at the Duncan Street site on 2 March disrupted train services and required several days of firefighting. The Environment Agency (EA) subsequently suspended and then decided to revoke Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s permit, effective 7 August. The site, run by Asset and Land Group, was deemed “broadly compliant” with fire safety legislation despite repeated visits by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service. Regulatory concerns focused on potential impacts to residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the blaze remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two new bills in response to the situation in Ukraine’s Crimea region. One bill would allow territories to more easily join Russia if their leaders or a referendum requested it—removing the need for a formal treaty if the neighboring state is seen as collapsing. The second bill would speed up issuing Russian passports by removing fees, residency requirements, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship. The lawmakers argue this supports Russian-speakers in Ukraine, citing what they call the “brown threat” of fascist elements. Several Russian MPs, including prominent figures, have traveled to Crimea to promote these proposals.

McLaren, once a dominant Formula 1 force with 182 wins, numerous drivers’ and constructors’ titles, and legendary partnerships (notably with Honda in the late 1980s), has fallen into a prolonged slump. Though they regained some aerodynamic strength after losing their way in 2013, the current Honda power unit remains a critical weakness. The team’s history has swung between peaks—such as Senna and Prost’s near-total dominance in 1988 and later successes with Hakkinen—and valleys, including controversies (spygate in 2007 and “lie-gate” in 2009) and recent winless seasons. Now led again by Ron Dennis, McLaren believes the cycle will soon swing back in their favor, with Fernando Alonso’s return symbolizing faith that they will once again challenge for championships.

Thomas “Tommy” Baker, 44, was found shot in the head and chest after leaving Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January and later died in hospital. Three men, aged 29, 29, and 32, have been arrested and remain in custody. Police believe the perpetrators waited outside the gym for about an hour before the shooting and are searching for a silver VW Polo seen speeding away along Balmoral, Molyneux, and Queens Roads. Investigators also urge witnesses captured on CCTV who were near the meat market but have not yet come forward to share any information they may have.

This passage describes modern, technology-focused ways people can celebrate Christmas. Everyday Church Online offers virtual Sunday services and festive sermons drawing parallels with popular culture like Star Wars. A fantasy game called Guardians of Ancora presents Bible stories as quests for children. Viral nativity videos retell the Christmas story online, including one told as social media updates. The Churches Advertising Network produced a similarly modern video about Mary and Joseph, though it faced challenges screening in cinemas. Next Manga’s “Manga Messiah” adapts the Christmas story into Japanese-style comics, including versions distributed to refugees. Finally, Christian groups increasingly use social platforms like Facebook and Twitter to share messages of hope and spirituality.

A public inquiry in Ebbw Vale is examining a proposal to use 250 hectares of common land, with supporters—including Blaenau Gwent council—offering 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts disagree on the impact on habitats and biodiversity: Natural Resources Wales is unsure if the replacement land is of equal value, but does not oppose the plan, while developers predict a net biodiversity gain, a claim the Gwent wildlife trust disputes. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the hearing, and Welsh government ministers will have the final decision.

Chechen Muslim clerics denounced a newspaper report alleging the detention and killing of gay men in Chechnya, vowing “retribution” against those responsible for publicizing the claims. The paper, Novaya Gazeta, interpreted this vow as a direct threat against journalists. The April 1 report described over a hundred men arrested on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed; the Russian LGBT Network confirmed the reports and said detainees were tortured. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denies there are any gay people in Chechnya, and his spokesman dismissed the allegations as lies. Novaya Gazeta pledged to continue its investigations despite the clerics’ warnings, recalling past murders of its reporters linked to Chechnya. Meanwhile, the LGBT Network is helping victims flee and threatening to involve the International Criminal Court if Russian authorities do not prosecute the perpetrators.

Investing Solutions, founded by Samir Patel, profits by renting properties to single homeless men—often referred from Fresh Start Housing, a charity he also established. By placing multiple tenants in a single property and claiming housing benefit for each one, Investing Solutions gathers a higher total payout than the rent it passes to landlords. Records show that in some instances, the difference between the total benefit and what the landlord receives can be substantial. Although both organizations insist they act within the law, conditions in certain properties have been described as poor, and critics argue that this arrangement prioritizes profit over properly accommodating vulnerable tenants. Local councils, notably Wandsworth, have paid millions in housing benefits to Investing Solutions, yet concerns persist about oversight and the quality of accommodation. Samir Patel states that Fresh Start’s board is independent and that most of the rental income goes to private landlords; Fresh Start, for its part, says it has housed hundreds of homeless people. A government spokeswoman emphasizes that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayer funds through proper inspections and investigations.

Great Britain led for most of their final warm-up game against the Netherlands before being overtaken in the last quarter, ultimately falling short despite Andrew Lawrence’s 14 points and Ben Gordon’s 13. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the need for full effort as GB heads into their EuroBasket qualifying campaign, noting that the team at times “lost a little of our fire.” Gordon had a standout stretch in the third quarter, hitting three consecutive three-pointers, and Prunty was pleased with his contribution, particularly given Gordon’s absence from the 2012 Olympic roster. However, the Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong’s 18 points, seized control in the fourth quarter and held on to secure the win.

Mayweather and McGregor’s upcoming fight at 154 lbs faces a debate on allowing 8oz instead of the usual 10oz gloves at that weight. Both fighters have submitted the required paperwork to Nevada’s commission, which will consider their health and safety before deciding. McGregor, making his boxing debut after UFC success with 4oz gloves, has been approved by the commission for several reasons, including his track record against Nate Diaz and favorable attributes like age, height, and reach. Training footage has reassured officials, and a specialized boxing referee, Joe Cortez, was brought in. The commission will finalize the glove decision on 16 August.

Fleet Street was once the thriving hub of British journalism, home to countless national and provincial newspapers, buzzing newsrooms, and legendary pubs. Over time, major papers relocated—most notably after Rupert Murdoch’s move to Wapping in 1986—leaving behind the “Street of Shame.” The Sunday Post’s closure of its London office marks the end of Fleet Street’s historic role. Former reporters Darryl Smith and Gavin Sherriff reflect on the clacking typewriters, smoke-filled rooms, and constant socializing that once defined press life there. Both are now moving on—Smith as a freelancer and Sherriff writing his memoirs—signaling Fleet Street’s final deadline.

J.K. Rowling described receiving both abusive and supportive comments on Twitter after her donations to the Labour Party and to the campaign opposing Scottish independence. She blocked hostile users—some of whom she believed were SNP supporters—while also conversing with others who shared certain political views despite supporting the SNP. Rowling stressed she would not “hush up” bullying to preserve any party’s image. She joked about potential public book burnings and noted that, in spite of the hostility, many decent people had reached out. At the time, the SNP won 56 of Scotland’s 59 seats in the UK election.

The studies by the University of Edinburgh reveal that children and young people from poorer backgrounds face disproportionately high levels of police action and are at heightened risk of violence—findings that persist even when other factors (like truancy or substance abuse) are considered. A history of police trouble strongly predicts disengagement from education or employment by age 18, and both the likelihood of offending and of being a victim of crime rise significantly with poverty. Gender also plays a major role, with boys more prone to violence overall—but poor girls are twice as likely as their better-off peers to commit violent acts. Further research shows that while crime in Scotland has generally fallen, the drop has not benefited the poorest communities. Despite government claims of historical lows in crime rates and additional investments to tackle poverty, inequality remains a key factor shaping offending and victimization patterns.

Mr Haugh, aged 25, was stabbed in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday and later died in hospital. Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August. Two other men were arrested but released without charge, pending files for the Director of Public Prosecutions. According to Detective Sergeant Frawley, Mr Walsh and two others entered the estate after 01:00 looking for Mr Haugh; a fight involving weapons ensued, resulting in Mr Haugh’s fatal stab wound. Police recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, and a judge noted heightened tension in Kilkee following the killing.

In May 2014, Phil Flanagan of Sinn Féin tweeted false claims that Tom Elliott, then an MLA and former UDR member, had harassed and shot people. Elliott, who has a clear Ministry of Defence record and now serves as MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted it within an hour and has since apologized in court, admitting his comments were “untrue and wholly without foundation.” The High Court is still to decide on compensation, and Flanagan is separately challenging his insurance firm’s refusal to cover him. Elliott expressed disappointment at the lengthy process but was pleased by the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, which dates back to 1874 and employs over 230 staff, has boosted weekly sweater production from about 7,500 to 9,500. This increase is driven by stronger-than-expected sales of its new self-branded range (launched in January) and ongoing private-label orders. Managing Director Benny Hartop, who bought the firm in November, attributes the success to dedicated staff and strong demand both in the UK and abroad, including numerous European countries, North America, Mexico, and Japan. He remains optimistic about the company’s future.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for allegedly causing serious injury to 72-year-old lollipop lady, Sylvia Blackburn, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. He admits hitting Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and could not recall if the light was red or green. Mrs Blackburn, a long-serving and much-loved school crossing attendant, suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Mr Wright expressed deep remorse in court, explaining he has thought of nothing else since the incident. The prosecutor stated that traffic in the opposite direction had stopped for the red light, but Mr Wright did not. The trial continues.

NATO is conducting an anti-submarine exercise, referred to as “Dynamic Mongoose,” in response to the heightened threat from increasingly active Russian submarines. In this exercise, a German submarine (U33) attempts to evade detection and simulate attacks on the USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker, highlighting how challenging it is to locate a stealthy adversary beneath vast oceans. New technologies such as underwater unmanned vehicles and anti-submarine warfare helicopters are being employed, alongside traditional warships and maritime patrol aircraft.

The passage also underscores Europe's concerns about Russia's expanding, technologically advanced submarine fleet. While nations like Russia continue to invest in their naval capabilities, Britain in particular faces a critical vulnerability, namely the absence of its own maritime patrol aircraft since the retirement of its Nimrod fleet. As a result, Britain must rely on NATO allies to monitor potential submarine threats near its waters. The exercise thus serves as a reminder that some countries, including the UK, cannot fully carry out anti-submarine warfare alone and points to a significant gap that needs addressing in upcoming defense reviews.

Violence in South Sudan has escalated since July, forcing at least 340,000 people—more than from any other country this year—to flee to Uganda. Reports describe killings, rape, and widespread ethnically motivated attacks primarily by Dinka troops against Nuer and Equatorians, creating fears of genocide or ethnic cleansing. Many refugees escaped on foot and witnessed brutality along the way. Uganda, working with aid agencies, has offered rapid support—allocating plots of land and essential supplies—but the growing number of arrivals, especially children, is straining resources. UN officials warn that the international community must act to pressure South Sudan’s leaders to stop the violent targeting of civilians.

Leon McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title. The former Norwich and Peterborough footballer turned professional boxer in 2013, two years after quitting football, and has a record of eight wins and one draw. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to be replaced with a modern facility funded by £33m, partly from the government’s £330m investment in new NHS buildings. The new hospital will include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray services, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is cramped and outdated, with staff noting its poor condition and impact on patient recovery. Three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have already been replaced in the past five years, and construction on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton has also started. Subject to planning permission for land at Bowers Lane, the hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014.

A man was shot and fatally wounded around 13:35 GMT outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, in Upperthorpe, Sheffield. He was near a black Mercedes at the time, sustained a gunshot to the chest, and died after being taken to Northern General hospital. Neighbors said he was part of a family gathering nearby and that relatives tried to help when they heard the shot. The incident follows other recent shootings in Sheffield, though those occurred in different areas (Shiregreen, Southey Green, and High Green).

This passage describes three hacker groups involved in the Ukraine conflict. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, focus on hacking Russian and separatist targets, using DDoS attacks and compromised CCTV or printers, and reportedly share findings with Ukraine’s security service. Cyber Berkut, staunchly anti-West, disrupts Ukrainian government sites and spreads pro-Russian propaganda by leaking or posting compromising material, such as alleged US military aid documents. Anonymous International (also called b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay) primarily leaks documents from inside Russia—their origins uncertain—and has also published messages related to Ukraine.

Several MSPs, including Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, and Labour’s Duncan McNeil, delivered farewell speeches before stepping down ahead of the 5 May election. Marwick was visibly moved by McNeil’s emotional address, in which he warned that Holyrood should learn lessons from Westminster on accountability and scrutiny. Salmond reiterated his belief that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” expressed disappointment with the Scotland Bill’s limited powers, and offered parting jokes about competing with the UK budget announcement and wishing future candidates luck. Annabel Goldie also gave a lighthearted valedictory, teasing John Swinney about his “faux indignation.” All were praised for their service and contributions to Scottish public life.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of residential care to understand older people's experiences and use the findings to form recommendations for care providers and public bodies. While she aims to highlight both good and poor care, concerns have been raised about “unacceptable variations” in care quality across Wales. Rochira’s team will speak to older people, family members, care providers, staff, and public bodies, focusing on factors like physical and mental health, social relationships, and the care environment. Although Care Forum Wales supports her aims, its chair, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that no provider expert currently sits on the commissioner’s advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, increased its pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, despite turnover dropping by £1 million to just over £100 million. The company’s international sales grew in Europe and beyond. Harbro manufactures animal feed for various livestock sectors and operates 19 “Country Store” shops across Scotland selling products for rural communities. Although the agricultural outlook and the impact of Brexit remain uncertain, the company’s board expresses confidence in its ability to adapt to future challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a property in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted. Another man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker. He is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight greying hair, and was reportedly wearing sunglasses, jeans or three-quarter trousers, and a blue-and-white checked short-sleeved shirt. Residents are advised not to approach him and to contact police or Crimestoppers with any information. Officers have increased patrols to reassure the community.

David Lipton, the IMF’s second-in-command, warned that the global economy is weakening and at a “delicate juncture.” He cited China’s recent trade data, which showed exports plunging by a quarter year-on-year, as a key factor. The IMF now expects to lower its current global growth forecast of 3.4% when it releases new projections in April, signaling ongoing repercussions for businesses and industries reliant on China’s growth.

The council held a scrutiny meeting about issues with a new Cowes chain ferry, which has experienced breakdowns, groundings, suspension over training concerns, and caused vehicle damage. In response, Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July and ordered an audit review. Businesses affected by lost trade requested compensation, and Transport Councillor Ian Ward confirmed it was under discussion. He described the ferry as a prototype facing "teething problems," including electrical issues and ramp design, which are being addressed with ramp extensions and training improvements.

A crash involving multiple vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. Police arrested a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road remained closed between Thursley and Liphook until the early evening for investigations.

Matching Models, an agency describing itself as an “international temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” placed ads requiring specific physical attributes—such as a personal assistant with “brown long hair and a b-c cup.” These postings prompted strong criticism from the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women’s equality campaigners, who called the ads illegal, demeaning, and reminiscent of 1970s sexism. Employment lawyers confirmed the ads could breach the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on factors like age or gender. 

Despite the backlash, agency founder Nathalie Jansen defended the ads, stating that many clients consider looks important. She cited examples of clients insisting on particular appearances, including an older gentleman designing a Dior outfit requiring a smaller cup size and an Indian businessman who requested a blonde, blue-eyed Greek woman. The EHRC underlined first impressions as important, but maintained employers must respect anti-discrimination laws.

A shooting occurred at a hostel of Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, allegedly carried out by Mahesh, an office assistant there. He reportedly shot 18-year-old Gautami, killing her, and wounded another student, Sirisha, who is now recovering. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. Although the motive remains unclear, incidents of gun crime in Indian schools are rare, and India maintains strict firearm laws.

Glaad’s study of TV series between June 2016 and May 2017 identified 278 LGBT characters, including a rise in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, Glaad highlighted the deaths of more than 25 lesbian and bisexual women (for instance, Poussey Washington in Orange Is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth) and noted that while there is a record high percentage of Black characters—largely due to shows such as Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder—these statistics are “only part of the story.”

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would not stand for re-election, just before a local party meeting where his candidacy was likely to be opposed. He has been under scrutiny over a £10.25m public loan, made while he was council leader, to rebuild Northampton Town FC’s stadium—most of which is missing and under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. Although Mackintosh denies any wrongdoing, the majority of his party’s local executive council reportedly intended to deselect him. He had previously planned to stand for re-election but stated he now feels the constituency should have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a former police officer, fired into a car leaving a house party in Balch Springs, Texas, in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Initially, police claimed the car reversed toward officers but later-released footage showed it driving away. Oliver was fired for policy violations and has been indicted for murder, as well as four counts of aggravated assault for shooting at the other teenagers in the car. If convicted of murder, he faces five to 99 years in prison and would be the first police officer in Dallas County convicted of murder since 1973. He is currently free on bail, and no trial date has been set.

Melania Trump plans to stay in New York with ten-year-old Barron until he finishes the school year, sparking social-media criticism over a First Lady not immediately moving into the White House. Historically, only two First Ladies—Martha Washington and Anna Harrison—have not lived in the White House, but some experts note that delaying a child’s relocation for school is not unusual. Melania’s choice supports her stated focus on Barron, which mirrors past presidential families who balanced child-rearing with their official roles. The First Lady role is traditionally ceremonial—hosting functions and promoting causes—but has evolved in modern times, exemplified by figures like Michelle Obama. Speculation arises that Ivanka Trump might take on some duties, as others have in previous administrations, but ultimately, each First Family shapes the position and their private lives in personal ways.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, is examining how Police Scotland initially responded to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaiting its results. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service instructed the Pirc to conduct the investigation, and a report of the findings will be submitted in due course.

A yellow wind warning has been issued, with gusts of up to 75mph likely, especially to the west of the mountains. The winds’ unusual easterly direction could increase their impact, causing likely travel disruption by road and sea. Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys are affected. Overnight gusts felled a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain shut for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants opened the scoring through Derrick Walser’s short-handed goal, but Jeff Dimmen quickly drew Nottingham level. In the second period, Mike Forney restored Belfast’s lead, only for Andy Bohmback to equalize again. Further goals from Mike Radja and James Desmarais made it 4–2 before David Ling pulled one back for the Panthers. Both teams meet again on Saturday. Nottingham currently tops the league on 28 points, followed by Sheffield on 27 and Belfast on 25.

Nico Rosberg secured a dominant win in a race shaped by first-lap collisions, safety-car interventions, and multiple pit stops. Lewis Hamilton began at the back, suffered front-wing damage on lap one, and pitted five times, severely hindering his efforts to close Rosberg’s 36-point championship lead. Ferrari’s Sebastian Vettel and Kimi Raikkonen also collided on the first lap, damaging both cars, though Vettel recovered to second and Raikkonen fought back to fifth. Red Bull’s Daniil Kvyat completed the podium despite a contentious opening-corner move, which Vettel criticized post-race. Daniel Ricciardo initially led from pole but suffered a puncture, and Rosberg’s decision not to pit under the safety car enabled him to cruise to victory.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German international footballer, publicly came out as gay in an interview to encourage open discussion about homosexuality in German football, where it remains largely taboo. Fellow players, including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, expressed strong support, as did leading figures in the German Football Association and Bundesliga officials, who hailed Hitzlsperger’s announcement as a major step against homophobia. High-profile voices such as Gary Lineker and Joey Barton also applauded his courage, noting how difficult it can be for players to come out. The German Chancellor’s spokesman praised Hitzlsperger, emphasizing that footballers should be judged by their conduct on and off the pitch rather than their sexuality. Some, like Philipp Lahm in 2011, had previously advised gay players to remain silent out of fear. Hitzlsperger’s decision is regarded as a watershed moment for challenging homophobia in German football and encouraging greater acceptance.

Steve Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, helping Brighton secure promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring soon, he hopes to sign a new deal and remain part of the team in the Premier League. Sidwell, who previously played in the top division for multiple clubs, believes he has exceeded expectations this season and deserves another opportunity at the highest level.

Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt after 12 minutes, but Colchester quickly drew level via Kurtis Guthrie following a corner. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe produced several impressive saves to keep the score at 1-1, including a key stop just before half-time. Tom Aldred missed a crucial header for Blackpool late on, and Colchester finished the match with ten men following Sean Murray’s injury-time red card. The match ended 1-1.

Reid, 29, made 37 appearances last season for the Sky Blues, who were relegated from League One. Having previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, he could now make his debut for Colchester (the U’s) in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington.

A permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, is being created to honor over 1,400 police officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. Spurred by the death of PC Keith Palmer, the UK Police Memorial Trust launched an appeal for £1.5m towards the £4m project, to which the government has contributed £1m. A brass screen will feature leaf shapes personalized for families of the fallen. The memorial, supported by Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the trust, and Home Secretary Amber Rudd, is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. They have won 25 of their first 30 matches and secured 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games, putting them on track to potentially surpass Chelsea’s 95-point record from 2005. With the derby against Manchester City looming, Sir Alex Ferguson emphasizes focusing on the next match. Several players, including Rafael and Anderson, picked up injuries at Sunderland, and Ferguson expects to make changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea. Despite these setbacks, Ferguson credits determined defending and courage for the victory.

Google’s chairman Eric Schmidt has defended the company’s approach to paying UK taxes—amounting to £10 million between 2006 and 2011—arguing Google follows existing legal requirements and that any desire for higher taxes should prompt government-led reforms. UK politician Margaret Hodge has proposed a new committee to examine large firms’ tax affairs, potentially taking evidence in secret to address confidentiality concerns. The EU has pledged to combat tax avoidance through an automatic exchange of information among tax authorities. Schmidt has also called for an international tax reform, emphasizing that taxes should be applied where economic activity occurs and urging policymakers to simplify and clarify regulations.

NHS Improvement wants to cut the NHS agency staff bill by £1bn (from last year’s £3.6bn) by the end of the financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far, limiting pay to 55% above normal shift rates for most roles (senior managers are exempt). Despite some progress, the NHS is still behind its savings target, and it remains unclear whether overtime spending or bank staff costs have increased. Later this year, NHS Improvement plans to publish “league tables” on agency spending, along with data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust. Examples show agencies quoting double the capped rates for doctors. NHS Improvement’s chief executive insists more needs to be done to reduce reliance on costly agency staff.

Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland’s Celtic Tiger, now reflects the crash’s aftermath. Local business owner Matt O’Brien has seen a modest turnaround by diversifying into childrenswear and dress hire. Opposition party Fianna Fáil criticizes the government for investing in water meters instead of improving broadband, and notes the IDA’s failure to attract foreign investment to Longford. In response, the government points to a proposed Center Parcs resort that could eventually create 1,000 jobs, though it still requires planning permission. While optimism is growing, issues like parking fees highlight the need for further measures to help local businesses.

Eight teams compete twice each, with the top four qualifying for play-offs leading to a final on 29 May. Key batting statistics show Warner, Kohli, and De Villiers leading in runs, with De Kock holding the highest individual score of 108. McClenaghan, Kumar, and Rahman lead the wicket-taking chart. Four England players feature: Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). A detailed schedule runs from 25 April until the final, with fixtures mostly starting at 15:30 BST.

The passage explains that the number of plastic carrier bags used has risen by 200 million since 2013, causing environmental problems as many bags are thrown away and end up in landfills or waterways. From October, England will introduce a 5p charge per bag to encourage reuse, a measure already effective in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. Campaigners hope this will reduce the number of discarded bags, benefiting the environment.

High winds across Wales on Friday led to part of a school roof being ripped off near Caernarfon, power cuts for hundreds of homes, and travel disruptions, including cancelled ferry sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, train speed restrictions, and bridge closures. Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle were also shut due to the weather. Although conditions eased by Friday evening, the windy forecast prompted the postponement of Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip by a day.

Michael B. Jordan is “super excited” about joining the Black Panther film and plans to “put a different spin on it,” although he has not revealed his exact role. The movie reunites him with Creed director Ryan Coogler, and Jordan looks forward to working with Lupita Nyong’o—an Oscar winner for 12 Years a Slave—and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently portraying Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously starred as the Human Torch in the 2015 Fantastic Four reboot, while Nyong’o appeared as Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther is set for release in February 2018.

The passage describes a plan to restore Alexandra Palace’s east wing, including the 1875 theatre and BBC studios. The project aims to reopen the theatre in 2018 for performances, cinema, comedy, and live music, while also refurbishing the BBC studios and converting the east court into a public space for exhibitions. The Heritage Lottery Fund will contribute £18.8 million, Haringey Council £6.8 million, and the Trust will raise £1 million by summer 2017 toward the £26.6 million total cost. The theatre retains much of its original décor and machinery, reflecting its origins showcasing opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings.

James Milner, aged 30 and formerly of Manchester City, earned 61 caps for England after debuting in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, although he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner, who holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps (46), scored his lone senior international goal in a 5-0 World Cup qualifying victory over Moldova. He described his decision to step away from England duty as “common sense” and wished incoming manager Sam Allardyce and the team well.

Marcy Smith’s young son, David, noticed flames while on a FaceTime call and alerted the sleeping family to a fast-spreading house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador. All three escaped wearing only their pyjamas, but the house was destroyed, and their dog and cats died. The fire began when some rubbish burned in the wood stove, something Marcy had done before without issue. The smoke alarm failed to sound. The local community rallied by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Marcy credits David with saving her and his sister’s lives, emphasizing his bravery despite his young age.

It was reported that an energy drinks company was considering a £200 million bid for West Ham United, which is majority-owned by Sullivan and Gold. They purchased the club in 2010 for a valuation of £105 million and now hold over 85% ownership. Since the club’s relocation to London Stadium in August, there have also been rumors of offers from Qatari and Chinese investors. Sullivan mentioned that a minority share could be sold to reduce debt, but he and Gold plan for ownership to remain within their families.

The passage describes an awards ceremony where The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking best movie. Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with co-star Ansel Elgort. Bradley Cooper received best male performance for American Sniper, dedicating his award to the late Chris Kyle. Channing Tatum won best comedic performance, Meryl Streep was named best villain, and several other stars, including Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, Rose Byrne, and Kevin Hart, also received awards. Robert Downey Jr accepted the Generation Award alongside his Avengers co-stars, and previews for upcoming summer films—Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Marvel’s Ultron—were shown.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 international, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. Having made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, he recorded four goals in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie club. St Mirren manager Jack Ross describes Smith as a “brilliant acquisition” who will add maturity and attacking strength. Last-place Championship side St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council aims to use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months, now that the weather is warm enough. Additional workers will also repair drainage systems damaged by rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016 on EnQuest’s Thistle platform, six Wood Group contractors—including Steve Innes—were unexpectedly exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. Although EnQuest stated this was below reportable thresholds, they informed the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) and introduced extra precautions. Innes, who alleges inadequate personal protective equipment and a failure in EnQuest’s duty of care, reports ongoing medical tests and cancer concerns. Both EnQuest and Wood Group emphasize employee safety and note that a joint investigation was conducted, while the HSE confirms it has not carried out a formal inquiry. The Unite union criticizes the handling of the incident and stresses the importance of transparency to improve offshore safety.

The Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past for US$650,000. Later, the gallery’s manager admitted to selling looted Indian antiquities and possessing stolen objects. The sculpture is believed to have been taken from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, although there is no conclusive proof. At India’s request, the ACM agreed to return the piece and is pursuing legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud. Of the 30 objects ACM acquired from Art of the Past, the other pieces are not thought to be listed as stolen.

An earthquake measuring 4.8 on the Richter scale struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, with tremors felt as far as Milan and Florence. Although there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, power outages occurred, phone lines went down, and schools in the vicinity were evacuated for safety checks. Italy, which frequently experiences earthquakes, witnessed a 2009 quake in L’Aquila that killed nearly 300 people and led to the conviction of six scientists and an ex-official for giving a falsely reassuring assessment prior to that disaster. Last May, two other quakes in the same region left more than 20 people dead.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, was initially unsure whether South Yorkshire’s climate could support his fruit plant. The fruit remains on the plant and is not yet ripe, but Grant was delighted with its progress, saying he was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has postponed the release of Grand Theft Auto V on PC from 27 January to 24 March to allow more time for testing and polishing. Online heists, a highly anticipated feature, will arrive on consoles before the new PC launch date. The PC version will support 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and even triple-monitor setups. Rockstar has published minimum system requirements to help players prepare. Grand Theft Auto V originally launched on 17 September 2013 and became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, earning $1 billion in just three days.

The passage describes how the 76-year-old Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for his painting “Squint (19).” He had been shortlisted once before, in 1991, and had also made the competition’s longlist on three other occasions. “Squint (19),” about 7ft in height, depicts a leper squint—holes in medieval church walls allowing so-called “undesirables” a view of services. Judge Ansel Krut commended the painting’s subtlety and depth despite its challenging subject matter. Simpson plans to use the prize money for high-quality art materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is a biennial award previously won by notable artists such as David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked almost simultaneously overnight, resulting in shattered windows but no casualties. Police say four masked assailants targeted the Yeni Safak building, setting a fire quickly extinguished by firefighters, while the Yeni Akit offices—located 20km away—were also hit. Bullet casings were found at both crime scenes, and no group has claimed responsibility. Police have cordoned off the areas and launched an investigation.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer starting 1 January. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, and becomes Bignot’s first signing.

Arsene Wenger, whose Arsenal contract ends in the summer, has been linked with the England manager’s job after Sam Allardyce’s departure. However, Wenger supports Gareth Southgate, noting he has “accumulated experiences” within the national setup. Southgate, 46, will use the upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to secure the role permanently. Wenger himself says he is focused on his current position.

Wenger also addressed Hector Bellerin’s future at Arsenal, stating the club plans to offer the 21-year-old defender a new contract despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. Finally, Wenger confirmed that Aaron Ramsey, sidelined since August with a hamstring injury, will miss “one or two” more matches.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police announced it is conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and reported that the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that resolves the dispute over low pay for crew on two freight vessels operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink. The RMT union had accused Seatruck of paying some non-UK crew members below £4 per hour. Seatruck argued the national minimum wage did not apply to these workers, and declined Serco Northlink’s offer to make up the pay difference. Under the new agreement, the service will revert to Serco Northlink next month, ensuring all crew are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink was originally awarded the six-year £243m Northern Isles contract in 2012 to operate ferries and cargo boats on a route heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after a confrontation at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, had intervened in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, who had been in a relationship with Mr Dickie for several years. All three had been drinking heavily before Mr Mitchell and Mr Dickie clashed outside, leading to Mr Dickie’s fatal injury. Jamie Mitchell admitted to common assault and, together with his mother, pleaded guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially giving false statements to police. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter from Cleethorpes, died at 66 following a brief battle with cancer. Known as the “Invisible Man” for maintaining a low profile, he first found success writing hits like “Boogie Nights” for his band Heatwave. His talent caught the eye of producer Quincy Jones, leading him to pen iconic tracks for Michael Jackson over two landmark albums: “Off the Wall” (including the title track and “Rock With You”) and “Thriller” (including the title track and “Baby Be Mine”). Temperton’s work also extended to artists such as Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin. He won a Grammy in 1990 for “Birdland” on Quincy Jones’s Back on the Block, and was twice Oscar-nominated for his compositions for The Color Purple. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, La Toya Jackson, Mark Ronson, and Chaka Khan, among others. His private funeral has already taken place, and his family has requested privacy.

Researchers, including Swansea University academics, discovered ancient earthworks—possibly 2,000 years old—in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. Modern deforestation revealed more than 450 geometrical “geoglyphs,” likely used sporadically for ritual gatherings rather than as permanently occupied or defensive sites. Soil analyses indicate these enclosures were constructed among tall vegetation, suggesting they were not similar in visibility to Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Their findings also challenge the idea of a “pristine” Amazon before European arrival: evidence suggests people selectively managed forests for useful species, creating a “prehistoric supermarket” of valuable plants. This agroforestry legacy continues to shape Acre’s biodiversity today.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian ranked 12th in the world, defeated Sam Querrey (ranked 29th) 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the Shanghai Masters second round. Having just won the Japan Open, he acknowledged feeling tired and less vocal, attributing it to travel demands and lack of sleep. The stadium’s location, about an hour from central Shanghai, also contributed to his fatigue. Notably, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 at the same tournament last year for a foul-mouthed outburst, describing the event as a “circus.”

Scientists and charities warn that head and neck cancer cases linked to HPV—already known to cause 5% of the global cancer burden—are on the rise, particularly among younger men. While girls in Wales have received the HPV vaccine since 2008, advocacy groups (including Tenovus Cancer Care and BMA Cymru) are urging the Welsh government to extend the program to boys. The government, however, is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes.

Jak Trueman was a 15-year-old student diagnosed with the rare gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Despite his illness, he remained determined and documented his experiences on social media through a page called “Jak’s Journey,” which gathered over 28,000 followers. He enjoyed moments such as meeting footballers, going on special outings, and attending a school prom held in his honor, though he could only stay briefly before feeling unwell. After learning his cancer had spread and further treatment was impossible, Jak focused on spending meaningful time with loved ones. His mother, Allison, announced his passing on Facebook, expressing pride and heartbreak. Jak’s story, filled with positivity and resilience, touched many people in his community and beyond. His final days also included a fundraising effort for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with additional charity events planned in his memory.

Egypt narrowly defeated Uganda 1-0 in a tight match, with Mohamed Salah setting up Abdallah El Said’s decisive goal in the 89th minute. Joseph Ochaya had an earlier effort correctly ruled out for offside. The victory keeps Egypt’s hopes of topping Group D alive ahead of their clash with Ghana—who booked their quarter-final place by beating Mali 1-0—while the defeat eliminates Uganda from the tournament.

Lancashire County Council intends to develop a new railway station in Skelmersdale on land formerly occupied by Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College’s Westbank campus. After a Network Rail study comparing these sites and one near the Concourse shopping centre, the council confirmed plans for two direct trains per hour to Liverpool, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The original Skelmersdale station closed in 1956, and as one of the largest towns in northwest England without a station, the project allows for possible future expansion and includes acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale was designated a new town on 9 October 1961.
Police searched a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning and discovered plants in what they described as “an elaborate grow house.” A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin suffered severe injuries after allegedly being dragged by the neck through several streets by her 38-year-old ex-partner. The suspect later turned himself in. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The victim underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Authorities are investigating, and the motive remains unclear. Police have called for witnesses to assist in the investigation.

The study found that women ask for pay rises just as often as men but are significantly less likely to receive them. Researchers eliminated factors like working hours by comparing full-time women to full-time men, and part-time women to part-time men, and concluded men were 25% more likely to succeed when requesting a raise. Contrary to common belief, there was no evidence that women were more reluctant to negotiate or worried about their bosses’ reactions. Young workers of both genders under 40 appeared more alike in their asking and succeeding rates, suggesting changing negotiation behavior. The research relied on data from Australia’s 2013–14 workplace relations survey, and authors proposed that pure discrimination might be a factor in the persistent pay gap.

Oxford City Council has searched extensively for new burial land, spending considerable money on ground investigations, but no viable sites have been found due to poor ground conditions, limited size, high water tables, and legal covenants. The city’s two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are anticipated to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. Afterward, only reopening of existing family plots, a few reserved plots, and ashes interments will remain possible. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

Visitors at the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway (19–22 July) can use a new augmented reality app to access online content—videos and band interviews—from signs and posters. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that this AR feature not only enhances on-site enjoyment, but also allows people worldwide to access festival updates, buy tickets, and experience a taste of the event’s atmosphere anywhere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary hemorrhage shortly after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Although he had previously exhibited signs of overheating and post-race ataxia, he had never before collapsed, and no significant underlying health issues were identified.
