The British Horseracing Authority notes such incidents are rare, yet continues to investigate how to prevent similar occurrences. Many Clouds, described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as the “horse of a lifetime,” had notably won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

Fifteen at the time, the victim was raped by a person then known as David (now 34, called Davina) in a Portsmouth garage in 2004 while others slept nearby. Davina, who has learning difficulties and previously attempted suicide, has not physically transitioned or taken medication. She changed her name in 2012. Found guilty, Davina faces sentencing on 4 March and will likely be remanded to a male prison. The victim testified that she shouted for the assault to stop and later reported the incident to a care home worker in 2014.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian doubles partner were defeated 6-4 6-4 by Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in the Rio Olympics, one day after Djokovic’s singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro. The 29-year-old world number one had earlier been upset at Wimbledon by Sam Querrey. A 12-time Grand Slam champion, Djokovic rebounded before the Olympics by winning his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

More than 20 chainsaw carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US are set to compete in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms on Saturday, carving animals and people from logs. Last year’s champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, 27, has been sidelined since a serious foot injury during a September World Cup warm-up match against Italy. He is now close to returning and hopes to be fit in time for Wales’ Six Nations campaign, which begins on 7 February. Having renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, Webb turned down other offers, emphasizing his commitment to his home region and his ambition to continue representing Wales.

Two men were stopped by US border agents near Sumas, Washington, on Tuesday while allegedly smuggling MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One suspect fled after firing a weapon; the other, identified as Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately detained. The fugitive, Nathan Hall, was later arrested in Canada. Authorities allege the seized backpacks contained 58lb of ecstasy and a doctored California driver’s license. Subsequently, a Bellingham woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for planning to pick up the smugglers and deliver the drugs. All defendants face conspiracy and drug charges in a known smuggling corridor.

The passage outlines a rise in the number of children seeking support from Childline for cyber-bullying, increasing from around 2,400 in 2011–12 to over 4,500 in the last year. Some victims are as young as seven, experiencing torment and fear that follows them beyond school. Dame Esther Rantzen highlights the severity of the issue and urges parents and schools to intervene. The release of the report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with families, schools, and organizations to address the problem. A young person’s account of being told to harm themselves while gaming online underscores the distress caused by cyber-bullying.

Israel’s government reacted strongly to the UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which passed after the US abstained rather than using its veto. Prime Minister Netanyahu, angered by the resolution, took actions including summoning the US ambassador and recalling Israeli ambassadors from countries that voted in favor. A planned vote on authorizing new homes in East Jerusalem was then postponed at Netanyahu’s request to avoid further tensions ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to address criticisms from Israel, while Palestinian President Abbas views the resolution as a step toward renewed peace efforts, including an upcoming conference in France.

Queen Elizabeth II marks her 90th birthday with a series of celebratory events, beginning at Windsor’s Royal Mail delivery office, where she and Prince Philip viewed an exhibition and met staff. A new set of stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family—Elizabeth II, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George—has also been released in her honor. 

Prince William, in a BBC interview, praised the Queen’s commitment and sense of duty as the ideal model for a monarch. He addressed criticisms labeling him “work-shy,” stating he takes duty seriously but also values striking the right balance in his personal and public life. He expressed that when the time comes for more responsibility, he will fully embrace it.

The Queen’s official birthday celebrations include a plaque unveiling in Windsor to mark The Queen’s Walkway and the lighting of more than 900 beacons across the UK and abroad. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join her for lunch at Windsor Castle. Meanwhile, the BBC’s coverage of the birthday has faced criticism from the republican group Republic, which argues it is excessively celebratory and not sufficiently balanced.

West Ham progressed to the next round of the EFL Cup with a 2–0 win over Cheltenham Town, secured by first-half goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Although Cheltenham threatened through Harry Pell for a moment, the Premier League side largely controlled the match and could have extended their lead further. The result ended League Two’s representation in the competition and mirrored the teams’ meeting at the same stage four years earlier, which West Ham also narrowly won.

Hospital radiographer, 36-year-old Aidan McNicholl, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to spot McNicholl’s motorcycle while turning his VW Transporter, causing the fatal crash. Werner, a father of four, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and was banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim’s family saw no benefit in a custodial sentence, accepting it was a “momentary lapse,” and Werner expressed remorse for the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from West London, traveled to Syria last January and joined the Islamic State–affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. There, he participated in creating propaganda, including gruesome images and videos, and was seen posing with a bag containing a severed head. After faking his own death, he attempted to return to the UK with the aid of his cousin. Khawaja was arrested at Dover and is regarded by authorities as highly dangerous. He has admitted four offenses, and now faces a significant prison sentence.

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 games last season for Wrexham, who finished eighth. He becomes Barnsley’s third signing ahead of their League One play-off final, with caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praising his pace and attacking style. Jackson declined Wrexham’s offer for next season in favor of joining Barnsley.

Bottles of detergent have been washing ashore on several Cornish coves, including Poldhu Cove, after possibly going overboard from a ship during stormy weather. The National Trust is removing the bottles, which pose a risk to wildlife, and advises the public to keep children and pets away from them. While the Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirms the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of “Vanish,” it has not officially linked the washed-up bottles to that incident. Conservation groups are concerned about leaks harming marine life, and local authorities are monitoring the situation.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several individuals. The road was closed, with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich route, and inquiries by Police Scotland are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back, joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 total appearances. Last season he featured 14 times, helping Bolton finish second in League One and gain promotion. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite’s late-season impact, calling him a “forgotten man” who made an “excellent contribution.” He now joins David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in signing a new contract with the club following their promotion to the Championship.

The passage describes a falling out between the Liberal Democrats and Labour in the House of Lords. They had previously worked together to defeat parts of the government’s Brexit legislation, but after MPs rejected their amendments, Labour chose not to insist on them further while the Lib Dems did. Labour accuses the Lib Dems of “grandstanding” and giving “false hope” to people concerned about Brexit, while the Lib Dems accuse Labour of “waving through the government’s plans.” Although they have formed alliances on other legislation, tensions remain, with both sides hinting that future cooperation could still occur on issues where they agree.

Defence ranks low on the list of UK election priorities, despite global threats and the UK’s shrinking military capabilities. Both main parties bury defence policy details deep in their manifestos and avoid making firm spending commitments, meaning the government could fall below NATO’s 2% GDP target. With further cuts likely, the size of the Army has dropped significantly, and the Navy and RAF have reduced warships and jet squadrons. Replacing Trident is another source of debate, with Conservatives and UKIP strongly supporting a like-for-like replacement, Labour open to scaling down, and smaller parties opposing it altogether. New aircraft carriers illustrate the UK’s ambitions but risk being undermined by insufficient personnel and aircraft, raising concerns that Britain’s armed forces could become a “hollow force” unable to match the country’s global aspirations.

Barcelona denies any wrongdoing in the signing of Neymar, stating they have complied with all tax obligations. The club originally announced a €57m (£48.6m) fee, but subsequent revelations—including a £34m payment to Neymar’s parents—indicate the total cost could be about £106.8m. Club president Sandro Rosell resigned amid allegations of misappropriation, though he denies any misconduct. A Spanish judge found sufficient evidence to continue investigating, prompting Barcelona to make an additional €13.55m tax payment while maintaining their belief that their original payment was correct. There is no confirmation whether the case will end following this new payment. Neymar has scored seven league goals and three Champions League goals for Barcelona this season.

A van carrying 27-year-old father Michael Luciw was hit head-on by 77-year-old Albert Newman’s car, which was traveling the wrong way on a motorway near Kegworth, resulting in both men’s deaths. Mr Luciw’s family, citing slower reaction times among older drivers, called for mandatory in-car tests rather than the current self-assessment form required every three years for those over 70. They argue regular testing could help prevent similar tragedies and suggest retirees could maintain freedom with bus passes if they lost their license. The van’s driver, Andy Harrington, who suffered serious injuries, also supports stricter requirements, including medical evaluations. The DVLA currently has no plans to change its rules, stating there is no evidence older motorists cause more serious accidents, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of enabling older people to drive safely for as long as possible.

Independent review findings on transvaginal mesh implants in Scotland have come under scrutiny following concerns from patients who suffered debilitating side effects. Two patient representatives and a consultant resigned from the review group, alleging that the final report was “watered down” and omitted significant content. The final report advises against routinely offering mesh implants for pelvic organ prolapse, recommends providing women with a full range of treatment options and better information, and calls for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Health Secretary Shona Robison confirmed implementation of these recommendations will continue, noting that banning the procedure outright is under the authority of the UK’s Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. Professor Alison Britton will now examine how the report was produced, while the review’s chair, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to reconcile differing viewpoints within the panel. More than 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh or tape implants over two decades, leading to over 400 legal cases against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds with a time of 14:49.12 in Glasgow. McColgan was pleased to see her record fall to a fellow Scot, though initially questioned whether event criteria were fully met—particularly regarding the race setup and drug testing. British Athletics expects Muir’s time to be ratified, clarifying there is no requirement for drug testing if none is conducted at a British-record-setting event. McColgan noted Muir, a world-class athlete who also holds the British 1,500m record and was an Olympic finalist, could run even faster and has the potential to win world-level medals.

Jung claimed victory on Sam—an eleventh-hour substitute mount—while France’s Astier Nicolas took silver and the USA’s Phillip Dutton secured bronze. Great Britain’s William Fox-Pitt, returning to competition just 10 months after a serious injury, finished 12th despite a faultless final show-jumping round; time penalties in the cross-country phase had cost him a leading position. Ireland’s Jonty Evans came in ninth. The passage also mentions opportunities for fans to engage with equestrian activities and ways to stay informed via the BBC Sport newsletter.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini in four sets (6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5) after two hours and 39 minutes, saving five set points in a tense fourth set. The victory puts Murray into the last 16 for the 11th time, where he will face Benoit Paire on Monday. Johanna Konta also reached the second week for the first time by beating Maria Sakkari. Despite feeling the match lacked his best tennis, Murray overcame a 5-2 deficit in the final set and managed to close out the win as darkness approached, expressing relief about avoiding a Saturday continuation under different conditions.

Paramedics were called to Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, where police later found patrons still being served alcohol as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar to close for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, faced two charges of allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours, while James Thomas, 44, faced one. The judge described Ms O’Neill’s record as “appalling,” imposed fines of £3,000 for her and £1,000 for Mr Thomas, but noted he lacked the power to issue a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt launched the Ulster Unionist Party’s “Real Partnership” manifesto by framing the election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, accusing the DUP and Sinn Féin of “incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption.” However, the spotlight shifted to Nesbitt’s call for voters to transfer preferences to the SDLP before Sinn Féin. Responding to criticism, he reaffirmed his stance, saying he had received support in unionist areas and “wouldn’t withdraw a word.” The manifesto focuses on reducing waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, developing infrastructure, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring that no group suffers due to Brexit. Nesbitt maintains that “domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” emphasizing the importance of genuine collaboration after the election.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden plans to introduce a motion in Northern Ireland mirroring England and Wales’ “Turing’s Law,” which automatically pardons men convicted under now-abolished sexual offences. The assembly is expected to consider the same provisions, offering both posthumous and living pardons. Sugden secured executive agreement for the motion to address these past convictions and intends to implement it “as soon as possible,” ensuring equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish mile record by finishing second behind Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12, beating Yvonne Murray’s 1994 mark of 4:22.60. This result moved her to second on Britain’s all-time list behind Zola Budd. Already the Scottish 1500m record holder, Muir is focused on securing an Olympic spot at the upcoming British trials and is balancing her training with her fourth-year veterinary studies.
The passage briefly displays photographs of the 26 Scottish beaches that have been ranked as having the highest water quality.

According to Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC, suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko. He instead pointed to the Russian state as the likely sponsor of the plot, noting it had “reasons aplenty” to want him dead. Litvinenko died from polonium-210 poisoning in London in 2006, allegedly ingested at a meeting with the two suspects. The use of polonium strongly indicated Russian state involvement, although Horwell stressed this did not implicate President Vladimir Putin personally. Litvinenko’s previous FSB accusations and “many personal attacks on Putin” may have been seen as treachery. Both suspects remain in Russia, where attempts to extradite them for murder have failed. Horwell further warned that the full extent of public exposure to polonium and its long-term effects on Londoners may never be known.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as Australia’s new Test captain following Michael Clarke’s retirement at 34. Already leading the one-day side and stepping in for Aaron Finch in Twenty20, he will now captain the Test team on an ongoing basis. David Warner, 28, who has shown notable growth despite past disciplinary issues, has been named vice-captain. Smith previously led Australia in three Tests against India while Clarke was injured and has performed strongly in his 32 Tests with a batting average of 54.66. National selector Rod Marsh expressed confidence in Smith and Warner, emphasizing Smith’s talent and Warner’s development as a senior figure in the team. They will lead Australia in upcoming limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron repeatedly declined to explicitly state whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead emphasizing his view that “we are all sinners.” He affirmed his support for LGBT+ rights, placing “defending equal marriage” at the top of his leadership agenda, and highlighted a desire to extend marital rights to transgender people by removing the “spousal veto.” Regarding his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, Farron cited concerns about “protection of individual liberties” but stressed he fully supports equal access under law for everyone regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi closed its Fawdon manufacturing site in 2015 with the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare will now take over the plant for its pharmaceutical production and aims to re-employ many former Sanofi workers. Local officials, including Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes, view the move as a strong economic boost that enhances the region’s reputation in science and healthcare. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical provider, currently develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to around 60 countries.

Three senior council officials are departing: Richard Ellis is leaving when his contract ends, while both Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Stephen Flynn, opposition SNP group leader, views these departures as evidence of the council’s difficulty in retaining senior staff and anticipates more exits soon. Ellis was interim director of corporate governance and served as deputy chief executive, Monaghan led the chief executive’s office, and Sutherland headed human resources and customer services. Chief Executive Angela Scott thanked them for their dedication and professionalism.

Martin initially announced he was quitting road racing after a difficult TT—where he crashed and the Fireblade suffered mechanical issues—but later clarified he’s not done with racing altogether. Instead, he has no plans to continue on the Honda this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness’s practice crash and will miss the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as disastrous, largely becoming a test rider for the bike, which he deemed uncompetitive. Although withdrawn from the Ulster event, he stated he has no unfinished business there and intends to focus on classic and “oddball” races going forward.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorships and had already defeated President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential election. This marked the biggest setback for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since Nigeria’s return to civilian rule in 1999. After losing key northern states such as Katsina and Kaduna, and failing to prevent defections of governors and MPs, the PDP is now largely confined to its strongholds in the south-east and some oil-producing areas, notably holding Rivers State. The polls saw some violence, particularly in the south, yet they were generally more peaceful than previous elections. As President-elect Muhammadu Buhari prepares to take office, he faces the challenge of addressing militancy in oil regions governed by the PDP and rebuilding unity in a country that has shown an appetite for political change.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, alleges that Singapore-based commodities trader Olam and its primary investor, Temasek, have indirectly encouraged “rogue” palm oil practices by sourcing most of their oil from unverified third-party suppliers. The report links Olam (and by extension Temasek) to the haze crisis in Southeast Asia, attributed to slash-and-burn land clearing. Both Olam and Temasek reject the claims. Olam states it maintains a strict no-burn, no-peat, no-deforestation policy and has recently released its supplier list. Mighty also criticizes Olam’s operations in Gabon, accusing the firm of clearing rainforests for plantations. Olam, however, says its joint ventures in Gabon are conducted responsibly and transparently. More broadly, the palm oil industry faces longstanding accusations of deforestation, labor abuses, and environmental harm, while activists call for stricter government enforcement and companies insist on the difficulty of fully policing third-party suppliers.
A new law now allows dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors, prompting this establishment to serve special puppy platters, as shown in the clip from 27 August 2016.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee issue, having only appeared as a substitute in his last two matches. Derby County’s David Nugent may return after recovering from a groin injury that kept him out of Monday’s draw with Huddersfield. Meanwhile, Jacob Butterfield is aiming for a starting spot following his late equalizer off the bench against the Terriers.

Pakistan lifted its YouTube ban because Google launched a local version offering a government-requested process to restrict specific content within the country. While the government asserts it can block “offending material,” YouTube insists removal is not automatic and follows its community guidelines and legal reviews, with all requests tracked publicly. The ban was originally imposed in 2012 over the film “Innocence of Muslims,” which provoked deadly protests in Pakistan.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, previously stepped aside in 2015 because he shared Swiss nationality with then-incumbent Sepp Blatter. Now, Musa Bility, president of the Liberian FA, insists Scala must withdraw again due to Gianni Infantino’s shared Swiss-Italian nationality. Bility cites FIFA regulations regarding conflicts of interest and threatens to escalate the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala remains. Scala’s spokesman counters that no incumbent president is standing and thus no conflict exists. Bility—previously blocked from running—has endorsed Prince Ali, while Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale also seek to replace Blatter in the 26 February election.

Two men, aged 29 and 56, died at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning, apparently while working in a paint-spraying area. Investigators believe a build-up of toxic fumes ignited, causing a flashover explosion and resulting in a fire-ball effect. A forensic search has been conducted, and both the police and the Health and Safety Executive—along with electrical safety experts—are gathering evidence to determine precisely what happened.

Tunisia risked missing the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to a strongly worded complaint about officiating in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea, but were ultimately reinstated after apologizing to Caf. Morocco had been banned from the 2017 qualifiers over its last-minute withdrawal from hosting the 2015 tournament, citing Ebola concerns, but a Court of Arbitration for Sport ruling overturned that ban. Both teams are now included in the qualifying draw: Tunisia in Group A with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. A successful qualification would mark Tunisia’s thirteenth consecutive appearance at the Nations Cup—a record.

Manchester City lost 3-1 to Chelsea at Etihad Stadium, with a mass fracas occurring in the 95th minute. City’s Sergio Aguero was sent off for a high challenge on David Luiz—his second dismissal for violent conduct this season—earning him a four-match ban, while teammate Fernandinho received a three-match ban after clashing with Chelsea’s Cesc Fabregas. Fabregas faces no further action, and Pep Guardiola apologized for City’s role in the incident. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the related charge.

Wales currently has some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world, partly because patients without clear symptoms can face long waits for a diagnosis. A new six-month pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and a parallel scheme in Neath Port Talbot aims to speed up testing for patients suspected by their GPs of having cancer but who do not show urgent signs. Inspired by a successful Danish model, GPs can refer these patients to a diagnostic centre within seven days, where multiple tests are carried out—ideally on the same day. The hope is to reduce delays so that fewer people begin treatment only after their cancer has advanced. If the pilot proves successful, other health boards in the area will adopt the same approach in the following months.

England leveled the series against Pakistan with a convincing victory at Old Trafford, where they declared on 589–8 and 173–1 for their second-biggest runs win against Pakistan. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, as well as taking four catches and a wicket. Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76 not out. Former captains Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott praised England’s performance, citing Root’s “best Test-match innings” and Pakistan’s apparent loss of spirit. Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged Pakistan’s disappointment, highlighting poor shot selection and a lack of confidence. Despite the strong England showing, Vaughan predicted a tight remainder of the four-match series, with the third Test set for Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley named as part of his backroom staff. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will head Wales for the third time on the simultaneous summer tour, while the WRU plans to appoint assistant coaches to support him. Both the WRU’s chief executive Martyn Phillips and chairman Gareth Davies anticipate that the Lions involvement will benefit Welsh rugby, providing valuable development opportunities for the nation’s coaches and players.

Hull fell behind early when Charlie Austin converted a sixth-minute penalty for Southampton, who looked in control at first. However, Hull’s Robert Snodgrass – introduced after injuries to both Abel Hernandez and Will Keane – turned the match around with a 61st-minute equalizer and then provided the free-kick for Michael Dawson’s winning header moments later. Goalkeeper David Marshall made several important saves, and Sam Clucas cleared off the line in stoppage time to preserve Hull’s 2-1 victory, their first league win since August. The result ended their six-game losing streak, while Southampton’s Claude Puel acknowledged a loss of focus following their midweek European match.

A crash occurred around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, involving a motorcyclist and a tractor. The motorcyclist, who was local, died, while the tractor driver was uninjured. Police asked witnesses to come forward and closed the B1191 between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov canceled an investigation into alleged abuse of power—based on covert recordings that surfaced in 2015—to “put an end to the agony” before early June elections. His decision was widely condemned by the opposition and by EU officials, who said it undermined the rule of law and jeopardized Macedonia’s EU membership ambitions. The recordings, which opposition leader Zoran Zaev has steadily released, purportedly reveal wiretapping of thousands of people and government-level corruption, including vote-rigging and covering up killings. The government denies these claims, instead accusing Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country.

Swansea City sacked Bob Bradley, leaving Alan Curtis and assistant Paul Williams to oversee the upcoming game against Bournemouth. The club hopes to name a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as their leading candidate. Curtis warns that relegation would be hard to recover from given the competitive Championship, and he reflects on Swansea’s successful years under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup. He believes the team has since lost its signature “Swansea Way,” caused by frequent managerial changes and player turnover. Nevertheless, Curtis feels the current squad can survive, emphasizing the club’s journey from near-bankruptcy to promotion in 2011—something new players learn through the documentary “Jack to a King.” He highlights how crucial remaining in the Premier League is for both the club and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. John Still, who once guided the club into League One, is now tasked with taking them back up from the National League. Dagenham have struggled all season, recording the worst goal difference in the division and scoring fewer goals than the previous campaign. Meanwhile, Orient, under interim manager Andy Hessenthaler—following the removal of Kevin Nolan as player-manager—remain two points outside the play-off places.

Steven Gerrard, following his recent retirement, is set to return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February—his first role since ending a 19-year playing career. Manager Jürgen Klopp welcomed the news, noting Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager and highlighting his readiness to learn. The former Liverpool captain debuted in 1998, won multiple trophies (including the Champions League), and moved to LA Galaxy before retiring. Although linked to the manager’s job at MK Dons, Gerrard felt it was too soon and is now pursuing his Uefa A coaching licence.

Morton took an early two-goal lead through McManus (15th minute) and Ross Forbes, before Alloa’s Kyle McAusland pulled one back. A second McManus effort and a late strike from Denny Johnstone then sealed a comfortable home victory.

Ofsted has uncovered evidence of children being taught in unsafe, unhygienic conditions in three unregulated Birmingham schools, now closed. These findings are part of a wider investigation into illegal schools, with 18 unregulated sites—mostly in Muslim communities—already visited. Although places teaching more than 20 hours per week must register as schools, some unregistered “part-time” or “flexi-school” settings are believed to be exploiting home-education rules. Anyone running an illegal school can face up to 51 weeks in prison. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw has urged stronger action, cautioning that these cases could be the “tip of the iceberg,” and the government has set up a team of inspectors and is considering further regulations.

Lilliard Gin is a new, small-scale distillery based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. Led by distiller Kate Macinnes, it aims to capture the local Teviot valley “terroir” by using Borders botanicals. John Henderson, of Born in the Borders, sees its arrival as complementary to the existing Scottish Borders Brewery on the same site. Lilliard Gin takes its name from a legendary heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor and reflects both the local history and the strong female production team. The venture comes as proposals progress to establish the region's first whisky distillery since 1837, contributing to a growing focus on “distilling excellence” in the Scottish Borders.

Harry Whitlam was killed in August 2013 at Swithens Farm when Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed a tractor into him. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed, and was later prosecuted under health and safety legislation because the incident happened on private land. He was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. Harry’s mother, Pam Whitlam, said their family had been “changed forever,” emphasizing that no one should drive a vehicle while drunk, regardless of whether it is on public roads or private property. The Health and Safety Executive described Green’s actions as “reckless.”

Luis Suárez’s four-month ban from “organised” matches for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini was upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), but the ruling now allows him to train, play in friendly matches, attend games, and take part in promotional activities. He can join Barcelona’s training immediately and is set for an official club presentation on Monday, though it is unclear if he will play that day against Club Leon. 

Suárez is still barred from competitive fixtures, including eight remaining international matches on his nine-game ban, but could make his Barcelona debut on 26 October against Real Madrid. Cas considered Fifa’s original ban excessive for blocking all football-related activity and acknowledged the need for a punish­ment proportionate to a repeat offender. While world players’ union Fifpro remains disappointed the sanctions were not reduced further, Suárez’s legal team views the appeal outcome as a success, in part because he may now train with his new club.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre obstacle race against a Lithuanian pair, having trained for a week on a local track. The course included haystack hurdles, a steep climb, and water pistol attacks. The event accepted all competitor combinations (not just married couples), with men carrying women, men carrying men, and a woman carrying a woman. As winners, Richard and Anna will move on to the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond confirmed that, from October, the traditional paper vehicle tax discs would be replaced by an electronic system allowing monthly direct debit payments. While acknowledging that fewer refunds and the end of the paper disc would change some job roles at the DVLA, he assured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that any staff reductions would be handled via redeployment and training rather than redundancies. Mike Hedges welcomed the minister’s clarification and believed it would reassure concerned DVLA employees.

Hungary’s government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, faces EU criticism over three controversial laws—on asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education—that could shut down the Central European University. Despite the EU’s objections and the threat of sanctions, Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto insists Hungary will not reverse these measures, calling them domestic matters. Poland has pledged to veto any attempt to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights, and European officials, including the European Commission’s Frans Timmermans, have warned of further action if Hungary does not address these concerns.

A live-action version of “Beauty and the Beast” is in production, set for US release on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson stars as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Belle’s father, Maurice. An unnamed star will portray Mrs. Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film. Bill Condon, known for directing “Dreamgirls” and the final two “Twilight” movies, will direct, and filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill was a prominent Sunday Times columnist, renowned for his witty and fearless writing style, who died from advanced cancer after publicly revealing his diagnosis. A dyslexic who dictated his copy by phone, he nonetheless produced influential columns spanning travel, TV, and food reviews. Though widely praised by fellow journalists and editors for his intelligence and compassion, Gill also courted controversy with harsh criticisms of places and public figures. Married twice—first to Cressida Connolly, then to Amber Rudd—he was later engaged to his long-time partner, Nicola Formby, with whom he shared two children. His final Sunday Times column appeared shortly after his death, marking the end of an extraordinary, often provocative, journalistic career.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator by a Russian diplomat after performing in a traditional Mongolian robe featuring a swastika, a symbol that pre-dates Nazism in Mongolia. He was hit in the face, spent about 10 days in a coma, and suffered serious brain injuries. The Russian embassy disputed local reports and said it was investigating. The suspect’s identity has not been revealed, but police confirmed he is a Russian diplomatic officer who was not detained because the injury was considered “not serious,” rather than due to diplomatic immunity. Sukhbaatar’s father and lawyer emphasized that the swastika is not intended as a hate symbol and denied claims the rapper used Nazi slogans. The case remains under investigation.

Campaigners from the Plane Stupid group protested on the northern runway early Monday, opposing the airport’s expansion. They have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area, and are due in court on 19 August. Police have indicated they will review airport security following the incident.

Nick Selman’s century (101) led Glamorgan to 220 on a bowler-friendly day in Cardiff, with Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles taking wickets at regular intervals. Despite a run of four ducks after his previous hundred, Selman showed resilience, supported only briefly by Aneurin Donald’s 36. Michael Hogan captained Glamorgan in Jacques Rudolph’s absence. Gloucestershire also had a tough time batting, and the day ended evenly poised.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested for threatening to ambush and shoot police officers after making false crime reports. He made these threats while talking online to a crisis center in Tennessee, admitting in court to two charges. Hughes had a previous firearm conviction, and the police were particularly concerned because he was on bail for other firearms offences (from which he was later cleared). He was remanded in custody and will be sentenced next week.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to reach 255-7, largely thanks to a 130-run partnership between Steven Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire’s chase collapsed under a three-wicket burst by Stuart Meaker, who removed Bairstow and Ballance. Although Tim Bresnan hit 68, Yorkshire were bowled out for 236. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised Davies and Foakes for their pivotal stand, while Yorkshire skipper Alex Lees lamented his team’s missed opportunities in the run chase.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST due to flooding. Its pump could not handle the incoming water, so an RNLI lifeboat crew provided a replacement pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, has decided not to compete for Scotland at the Commonwealth Games in Australia because her veterinary medicine exams in May conflict with the April event. She placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships and expressed disappointment about missing the Commonwealths, but prioritizes completing her degree. Muir still plans to target the World Indoor Championships in March. She ran her fifth race in 10 days in the 5,000m final in London, finishing in a personal-best 14 minutes 52.07 seconds and is optimistic about her future, anticipating at least two or three more Olympics.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are far off replicating last season’s title challenge, especially given the loss of Luis Suarez and repeated injury problems for Daniel Sturridge. Current striker options (Balotelli, Lambert, Borini) lack the work-rate and goal threat of last year’s attacking setup, while fewer goals before half-time underscore the team’s diminished intensity. Defensive issues remain unresolved despite significant spending, and Savage believes there is no single on-field leader at the back. Steven Gerrard remains vital, but he faces ongoing scrutiny over his physical capabilities and the psychological impact of last season’s slip against Chelsea. Although Gerrard is still among Liverpool’s key players, Savage expects Chelsea to leave Anfield with a win, highlighting the gulf between the two sides this season.

A £45m education campus is set to be built in Kilmarnock, comprising primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek the McIlvanney family’s permission to name the facility in honor of William McIlvanney, a renowned Kilmarnock-born writer once called the “Godfather of Tartan Noir.” Initially an English teacher, McIlvanney turned to writing full time in 1975, producing works such as Remedy Is None, the Laidlaw trilogy, and other notable Glasgow-based novels. He also wrote poetry, contributed to journalism and broadcasting, and remained deeply engaged in Scotland’s political and sporting life until his death on 5 December.

A British sea mine, believed to date from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered near a swimming pool in a town, leading to an evacuation in three nearby streets and wider safety advice for residents within 500m. There was also an exclusion zone both on the river and at sea while experts dealt with the device, resulting in disruptions to ferry services. Authorities stressed the actions were precautionary and that there was no immediate danger, but due to the mine’s uncertain amount of explosive material, it needed to be moved before being made safe. The local council thanked residents and businesses for their cooperation during the evacuation.

UK Sport will invest £345m—£2m less than for Rio 2016—across 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports ahead of the Tokyo Games. While successful disciplines like cycling see a funding reduction, badminton’s entire budget has been removed despite winning bronze in Rio. Badminton England criticizes the move as “incomprehensible,” calling it catastrophic for its athletes. Judo’s funding, by contrast, has risen slightly. UK Sport defends prioritizing medal potential to maintain Britain’s strong performance, targeting 51–85 Olympic and 115–162 Paralympic medals. Team sports such as basketball, volleyball, and handball remain aggrieved by continued lack of support, while new Olympic and Paralympic sports await final funding decisions.

Three Victorian hotels on Bournemouth’s East Cliff will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment buildings. Despite strong objections from English Heritage regarding potential harm to the conservation area, councillors voted seven to three in favor, citing the need to support tourism and update facilities for older residents. The development, by The East Cliff Project LLP, includes a 90-room hotel and two blocks (nine and seven storeys) providing 122 assisted-living apartments. While 246 letters backed the plans, 49 objected, alongside the Ancient Monuments Society and English Heritage, concerned about losing historic character.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was off-duty in Brecon when he was attacked by 24-year-old Jake Vallely outside a bar called The Cellar. Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and calling himself “the hardest man in Brecon,” punched and beat Boyd until he was unconscious, then dragged him away before fleeing. Boyd, originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, served with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment and was in Brecon for training. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter after evidence showed he was not present during the violence. The police called the attack “a despicable act,” and Boyd’s family described him as loving, caring, and full of life, saying Vallely’s actions created a permanent void in their lives.

Andrew Travers stepped down from Barnet Council “by mutual agreement” after a polling station error where voters’ names were missing from the register at all 155 polling stations. An independent investigation has been launched, and a council review—set to finish by the end of May—will present its findings publicly. Meanwhile, deputy chief executive John Hooton will serve as interim chief executive. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and acknowledged voter concerns about the fairness of the election. The review will also assess preparations for the upcoming EU Referendum.

Gateshead opened the scoring through a Josh Gillies free-kick, with Wrexham quickly drawing level via Sean Newton’s own impressive set-piece. Ryan Bowman headed the decisive goal for Gateshead in the second half, securing a 2–1 victory. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby credited better passing after half-time, while Wrexham boss Gary Mills lamented his team’s inability to convert chances and maintain their first-half momentum.

The passage explains that the 2014 Global AgeWatch Index assessed the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranked highest, while Afghanistan performed the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb and Airbus are collaborating on a large satellite constellation—initially more than 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding beyond 2,000—to deliver global broadband connectivity, with plans to connect every corner of the globe, including schools. Airbus is adopting high-volume, low-cost production methods akin to automobile assembly lines, aiming to build satellites at under a million dollars each. 

The constellation’s deployment requires an unprecedented rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz launches putting batches of satellites into orbit. OneWeb has raised US$1.7 billion and is seeking additional financing. Registered in the UK’s Channel Islands, it works under the UK Space Agency’s regulatory framework, promoting local economic benefits. The project prioritizes debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit defunct satellites within two years. While other companies, including SpaceX and Boeing, plan similar constellations, OneWeb believes its first-mover advantage and innovative manufacturing approach set its new venture apart.

Mr Swinney contends that the UK government’s recent spending review imposes significant cuts on Scotland, leading to a projected 12.5% real-terms reduction in Scotland’s budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. He argues that the chancellor chose a level of austerity which will still remove more than £1bn from Scotland by the end of the decade. Nevertheless, Mr Swinney insists the Scottish government will protect key public services like schools, hospitals, and policing. The UK government counters that Scotland will actually see higher spending next year, and urges Scottish ministers to focus on using newly devolved powers. Meanwhile, Labour calls on Mr Swinney to present a long-term budget strategy that genuinely challenges austerity rather than offering temporary measures.

Many people with severe disabilities require toilet facilities beyond those provided by standard accessible restrooms, including space for two carers, bench areas, and hoists. Currently, “Changing Places” toilets meet these needs but remain only a recommendation in UK building regulations (BS 8300:2009), not a requirement. Families describe being forced to change loved ones on dirty floors or in cramped car spaces, leading to feelings of isolation and distress. Campaigners, supported by personal stories and petitions, are urging that larger venues such as shopping centers, cinemas, and stadiums be required to install these fully accessible facilities. Some venues, like Arsenal Football Club, have adapted their existing setups and found positive reactions from both users and the wider public.

A group of Italian consumer organisations has lodged a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald’s of using its dominant market position to force franchisees into paying excessive rents and fees, as well as signing long-term contracts that limit their ability to switch to competitors. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and other European unions support the complaint, which alleges these practices result in higher prices and reduced choices for consumers. McDonald’s denies the accusations, stating it shares risks and rewards with its licensees, while the Commission has said it will examine the submission and may investigate if the allegations warrant further action.

Thirteen-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was unexpectedly diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, initially thought to be appendicitis. In response, Bangor Elim Church—where his father is on staff—created the #prayforjosh hashtag on Facebook and Instagram to rally support. The campaign quickly went viral, drawing encouragement from across the globe. A mystery donor even funded a large “#prayforjosh” billboard in Holywood, surprising Joshua’s family and church with its public showing of support. Classmates at Bangor Grammar and many others worldwide continue to follow Josh’s progress, offering prayers and solidarity as he recovers.

The UK government plans to close Brecon Barracks, a historic site that has been home to troops since 1805 and played a role in notable conflicts such as Rorke’s Drift. Local MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the closure, citing the barracks’ long service record, important military heritage, and potential negative impact on employment and tourism in the area. He has launched a petition against the move but notes that nearby military facilities at Sennybridge and Dering Lines will remain operational. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon confirmed broader military reorganisation across Wales, including a future light infantry centre at St Athan, as well as the eventual closures of Cawdor Barracks and a storage depot at Sennybridge. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports the overall need to restructure but warns of the uncertainty it creates for those affected.

The passage explains that while many in the UK fishing industry see Brexit as a chance to regain control over British waters and boost exports, a new House of Lords report warns the sector may be overshadowed in broader negotiations. The EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is widely disliked by fishers, yet the UK might need to allow EU vessels some access to its waters in order to maintain tariff-free export rights. The Lords report advocates retaining key CFP elements, such as scientifically based quotas, and highlights complexities from shared stocks and potentially fragmented fisheries management across England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. Despite concerns, recent quota agreements and government statements leave some in the industry optimistic about future opportunities.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed he was behind leaks showing that the US National Security Agency (NSA) collects and analyzes vast amounts of data from phone records and internet services. The US government, citing national security, confirmed it obtained millions of phone records from providers like Verizon, tracking call details such as duration and location. Documents also describe an NSA program called Prism, allegedly giving “backdoor” access to servers of major tech firms (all of which deny direct involvement) to monitor private communications, including chats and social media posts. Officials say these surveillance tools help prevent terrorism, though they do not share full details. Privacy advocates and some experts question the scope and legality of this surveillance, highlighting the implications for individuals worldwide—especially since user data can be stored in different countries and subject to US law, such as the Patriot Act. European authorities have expressed concern, yet there is no clear legal route for citizens to opt out. Snowden’s action was motivated by alarm over this level of government access to personal information.

OpenAI, backed by figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, is a billion-dollar venture aiming to develop AI that benefits humanity without profit-driven constraints. While AI’s potential risks have been highlighted by Elon Musk—calling it humanity’s “biggest existential threat”—and Stephen Hawking, other experts argue the danger is remote. OpenAI’s statement stresses AI should serve as an extension of human will, be broadly and safely distributed, and have positive human impact. It also notes only a small fraction of the pledged $1 billion will be spent in the near term.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, who was severely injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, recently carried the Olympic torch for nearly half an hour with assistance. The public response to his nomination and story has been overwhelming: thousands of Facebook friend requests have surpassed the 5,000 limit, and his mother Diane describes the show of support as “phenomenal.” Despite his injuries, Ben has regained his speech, spends 12 hours daily on rehabilitation, uses crutches, and devotes significant time to raising money for military charities, including acting as patron for Pilgrim Bandits. Facebook advises that high-profile individuals open a page or use the subscribe feature to accommodate such large numbers of followers.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate held at 15%—representing 46.2 million people—after three consecutive years of increases. Real median household income declined by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase in the Gini index since 1993. Meanwhile, the share of Americans without health insurance fell from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, moved from Somerset to Lancashire (the Red Rose) in 2013. He has now extended his contract until 2019. Buttler holds England’s three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Lancashire coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler’s talent and influence, describing his role in the T20 Blast win and his positive presence in the dressing room. After playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL, Buttler will return to Lancashire for Friday’s T20 Blast match against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, HMS Cornwall) are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. No proposals to preserve them have been formally submitted, but interested parties are finalizing bids. The government’s Disposal Services Authority aims to have at least one recycled in the UK to test domestic capacity. MP Penny Mordaunt supports saving at least one ship, possibly as an artificial reef and diving attraction. Final decisions will be made in the spring, with the Ministry of Defence weighing both preservation and best financial return.

Fiji has experienced repeated coups since 1987, largely driven by tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. These events, including the 2000 coup led by George Speight and a bloodless military takeover in 2006, led to economic damage—especially in tourism—and international isolation, including suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. After promising free elections in 2014, Fiji restored relations with neighboring countries and rejoined the Commonwealth. The population, now majority indigenous, remains socially divided from Indo-Fijians, who departed in significant numbers following the political unrest. Although Fiji’s economy relies heavily on sugar and tourism, it has a diversified base with mining and services but continues to face persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a major recipient of foreign aid.

Syria’s Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad insists the government is “doing its best” to comply with the chemical weapons handover, despite missing Wednesday’s deadline. He blames delays on two attacks against shipments traveling from Damascus to Latakia, asserting they were targeted by “terrorist groups.” Meanwhile, the US and opposition activists accuse Syria of using barrel bombs against civilians in Aleppo—an allegation Mr Mekdad rejects. Conflicting reports also surround an attempted rebel takeover of Aleppo’s central prison: the Syrian government claims it thwarted the assault, while rebel groups say they have seized full control. With 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, Syria has so far transferred only 4% out of the country. US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons have voiced concerns over delays, but Mr Mekdad maintains that Syria will meet all obligations on time.

This passage describes the 2014 Booker Prize shortlist, noting that, for the first time, the award is open to any English-language author regardless of nationality. The favorite to win is Neel Mukherjee’s “The Lives of Others,” set in 1960s Calcutta. Also shortlisted are Howard Jacobson (“J”), Ali Smith (“How to Be Both”), Joshua Ferris (“To Rise Again at a Decent Hour”), Karen Joy Fowler (“We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves”), and Richard Flanagan (“The Narrow Road to the Deep North”). Fowler’s novel has sold the most copies so far, and Jacobson, who won in 2010, is again considered by some to be a strong contender. This year’s judges, led by AC Grayling, will announce the winner at London’s Guildhall, with each finalist receiving £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. Last year, Eleanor Catton became the youngest-ever winner with “The Luminaries.”

A celebrity referred to as PJS is appealing to the UK Supreme Court to maintain an injunction preventing his identification in England and Wales. This follows a Court of Appeal decision lifting a ban on naming him in connection with alleged extra-marital activities. Although stories have circulated elsewhere and online, the Supreme Court will now decide whether to hear his appeal and rule on continuing or overturning the injunction. Until the hearing concludes, an interim injunction remains in place, but the Court of Appeal judges indicated that details of the allegations are so widespread that full privacy may no longer be sustainable.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and purchased for £345.5 million in August, is set for improvements to relieve parking and traffic congestion and to enhance its overall appearance. Blaby District Council’s leader, Ernie White, confirmed that the new owners have engaged with the council to address planning considerations, viewing Fosse Park as a “gateway” from Blaby into the city. Paul Clarke from Crown Estates highlighted the need to upgrade tired “common areas” such as walkways and parking facilities, aiming to ensure Fosse Park remains an appealing destination.

Disney’s “Beauty and the Beast” was postponed in Malaysia due to a “gay moment” involving LeFou’s feelings for Gaston. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film under a “P13” rating, requiring a “minor edit,” though a new release date was not confirmed. The country’s tourism minister deemed banning it “ridiculous.” Local cinema chains offered ticket refunds. Director Bill Condon acknowledged the “exclusively gay moment” as a side-plot. Online critics, meanwhile, called the temporary ban “stupid and laughable.”

Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people must secure an HMO licence, which can cost about £1,000, but failing to do so risks a fine of up to £20,000. Southampton City Council estimates there are about 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Many HMO tenants worry about eviction and poor living conditions due to a shortage of affordable housing. Nationally, HMO licensing covers houses of three storeys or more with five or more unrelated occupants, while in Southampton it additionally applies to properties in specific neighborhoods under two designations introduced in 2013 and 2015. Although most landlords comply, a minority has resisted licensing, and the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals so far.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are seeking to form a minority government to avoid a second election, but water charges remain a major hurdle. Fianna Fáil wants the charges dropped immediately, while Fine Gael believes they have a role. A commission to consider Irish Water’s future is under discussion. Following the recent election, no party won a majority and TDs have yet to elect a new taoiseach.

A fire broke out on the ferry Sorrento while it was en route to Valencia, forcing a full evacuation. Passengers and crew abandoned ship on lifeboats and were rescued by another ferry, the Puglia. At least three people were injured—one seriously—and taken to hospital by helicopter. The fire began on one of the car decks when the vessel was about 27km from Mallorca, though the cause remains unknown. Spanish officials warned that the Sorrento might sink and arranged for psychologists to meet the rescued passengers upon their return to Palma de Mallorca. The ship, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, had issued distress signals at 13:50 local time, and the situation escalated when the flames grew too intense for the crew to remain on board.

The passage highlights concerns from the Electoral Commission about possible double voting in the 8 June election, particularly among students registered in multiple constituencies. Despite having a record 46.8 million people on the rolls and a high turnout (68.7%), there were up to 4.9 million registration applications between December 2016 and May 2017, with many likely duplicates due to the lack of a linked national database and no easy way to check existing registration. The Commission recommends clearer guidance and a verification system—already in use abroad—to reduce duplicate entries and address the complexity of managing dispersed electoral registers. Although Labour agrees voting twice is a serious offense, it warns against making it harder for young people and students, who often have legitimate reasons to be registered in more than one place.

Lawrence Phillips, once a star running back at the University of Nebraska and later an NFL player, was serving a prison sentence of more than 30 years for assault convictions when he took his own life. He had been accused of killing his cellmate, and on Tuesday, a judge ruled there was sufficient evidence for a trial in that case. Phillips had long struggled with legal troubles, including driving his car into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend. His former coach, Tom Osborne, noted that Phillips was intelligent and had positive qualities but could not overcome his anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classed as a soldier and the 30th in a historic line of mascot rams, was promoted to lance corporal at a celebration in Chester commemorating the Mercian Regiment’s eighth anniversary. Awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams for good behavior, Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined in 2014, has an army number, is paid for his rations, and takes holidays on the Chatsworth Estate. He follows a tradition tracing back to the first Private Derby, acquired in 1858 during the Indian Mutiny War. Notable appearances in his career include helping switch on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool staged a dramatic comeback to defeat Borussia Dortmund 4-3, echoing past European heroics such as Istanbul in 2005. Jürgen Klopp’s passion and insistence on transforming “doubters into believers” defined both the team’s spirit and the raucous Anfield atmosphere. Despite trailing early and needing multiple goals twice, Liverpool’s refusal to concede—exemplified by standout performances from Origi, Coutinho, and Sakho—ultimately secured a place in the Europa League semi-finals. While vulnerabilities remain in defense, Klopp has rapidly stamped his identity on players and supporters alike, rekindling hopes of both lifting the trophy and returning to the Champions League.

At a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, David Davis promised regular (monthly) updates and a two-way information flow with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. However, Scotland’s Brexit Minister Michael Russell called for clearer details on the UK’s plans, especially on whether it intends to remain in the single market or customs union. The UK government seeks to overturn a High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 at the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government plans to oppose them in that appeal.

Scientists at the University of Nottingham are closely monitoring a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four that share the same genetic origin as Dolly, the first cloned mammal. Veterinary exams focus on potential signs of aging-related conditions such as osteoarthritis and other co-morbidities like cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Dolly died relatively young, and her premature osteoarthritis sparked concerns that the cloning process could accelerate aging. To address this, the researchers repeated the cloning from Dolly’s original cell line to create more sheep and have been testing them thoroughly (using joint X-rays and fMRI scans). Although final study results are pending, the now 9- to 10-year-old clones appear healthy, suggesting Dolly’s early death may have been an isolated case rather than due to cloning.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, remained unbeaten by winning the Musidora Stakes at York despite soft ground. Gosden plans to send her to the French Oaks at Chantilly rather than the Epsom Oaks, in which stablemates Enable and Coronet will compete. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, took the Duke of York Stakes ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden may not run his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes, due to both the ground conditions and the short gap before the Derby.

The passage describes how the pound fluctuated against other currencies—initially slipping, recovering, and then falling again—amid heightened market volatility not seen since the 2008 crisis. Investor uncertainty grew as polls showed rising support for the Leave camp, reducing the perceived probability of a Remain vote. Concerns over Brexit also rattled global stock markets, notably in Asia and on London’s FTSE 100. Analysts observed that any further poll shifts could cause more severe swings in sterling, and some investors have begun short-selling the currency. In contrast, Leave campaigners noted that the pound remains above March levels and argued that a weaker currency could boost UK exports.

Braintree Town, nicknamed “The Iron,” sit sixth in the National League, a point and place outside the play-off spots. After conceding early against Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine, the Iron’s own losing streak reached three games. Despite the setback, manager Danny Cowley remained upbeat, emphasizing the team’s part-time status and describing their season so far as “nothing short of remarkable” as they continue to embrace the challenge of competing at this level.

From April 2015, decision-making on most planning applications in Northern Ireland will shift from the Planning Service (part of Stormont’s environment department) to local councils, meaning elected politicians will have final authority. Supporters, such as Michael Corr of PLACE, see this change as an opportunity for councils to shape their own development plans. However, critics warn that historically there has been discrimination in housing allocation and a risk of favoritism or lax regulation due to ties between developers and politicians. Groups like Friends of the Earth argue that stronger transparency, including disclosure of political donations, will be needed to ensure fairness and prevent a return to past abuses. Under current law, the Northern Ireland Secretary retains the power to decide when greater disclosure of political donations should apply.

A cat named Teenie was shot three times with an airgun—twice in the shoulder and once in the left hind leg, leading to the leg’s amputation. The cat’s owner, Sarah Nisbett, found Teenie injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The Scottish SPCA condemned the attack and highlighted the urgency of licensing air weapons, a proposal under consideration by the Scottish government. While the plan would require anyone wishing to own an air gun to show a legitimate reason, a majority of respondents to a government consultation last year opposed the move as “draconian” and “heavy-handed,” although some felt the proposed plan did not go far enough.

Liverpool have made Christian Benteke their second most expensive signing by triggering the release clause in his Aston Villa contract. The Belgian international, who scored 49 goals in 101 appearances for Villa, joins after Liverpool sold Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Manager Brendan Rodgers hopes Benteke will help solve the club’s goal-scoring problems following Luis Suarez’s departure and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries. Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles injury, returned last season to help Aston Villa reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa boss Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge believe Benteke’s strength and scoring ability will greatly benefit Liverpool’s attack.

The passage describes a study on the growing use of tablets in schools, finding that while tablets are increasingly common and may help engage pupils—including those who might otherwise disengage—there is no conclusive proof that they directly improve academic results. Schools report a positive impact on motivation, with tablet use also encouraging parental involvement when devices go home. Usage is particularly high in academy schools, and overall numbers of tablets in schools are predicted to rise steeply. A separate study suggests tablets are especially helpful for boys and poorer pupils when learning to read. Many students use devices late at night for social media or videos; some even consider themselves “addicts.” Despite the difficulty of directly linking tablets to academic improvement, school leaders see value in reflecting real-world technology use and fostering a sense of empowerment among students.

The exhibition “Growing Up in the City” at the Museum of Liverpool presents 25 photographs spanning the 1880s to the 1990s that document children’s lives and changing childhood experiences in Liverpool. Curated by Kay Jones—who selected the final images from hundreds of museum archives—the display ranges from formal portraits of affluent families to candid shots of children at work, reflecting both the joys and hardships of youth. Viewers see how special occasions were celebrated, as in the earliest 1887 photo of the Rollo children at a fancy dress ball, and are reminded that many children also labored, such as the young maid pictured around 1900. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival. The former Aldershot and Exeter player, who has played in Italy, may face his old club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, was recommended to Torquay United boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, having previously featured for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Nicholson described Anderson as a leader-type and Keating as raw yet eager to prove himself. Torquay sit four points above the relegation zone, with just one win in their past six matches.

Bolivia has approved a law allowing children as young as 12 to work under contract, provided they have parental authorization, in recognition of the country’s economic realities. It also sets harsher penalties for violence against minors, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in President Evo Morales’s absence, the measure seeks to reduce extreme poverty but faces scrutiny from the International Labour Organisation, which is reviewing whether it conflicts with global child labor standards.

Rosie O’Donnell, aged 50, experienced heart-attack symptoms at home and researched “women’s heart attack symptoms” online. Feeling sudden nausea, aches, and chest pain, she took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, where a stent was inserted into an artery that was 99% blocked. In a blog entry titled “my heart attack,” she described her condition as the “widow maker.” Despite not calling emergency services initially, she urged others to be aware of warning signs and dial 911. O’Donnell, known for roles in several TV shows and films, had recently hosted The Rosie Show, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was attending a well-supervised party in Belvedere Way when a group of youths tried to gain entry. Although he was not involved in the initial altercation, he was later stabbed in an alleyway around 00:30 GMT and died about an hour afterward. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and remains in stable condition. A 21-year-old man and two teenagers (15 and 16) were arrested on suspicion of murder, with the teens bailed until mid-December; a 14-year-old was held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon. Police are appealing for anyone near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at the time of the stabbing to come forward.

A Danish initiative restructured cancer diagnosis by introducing three referral routes:  
• Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for “alarm” symptoms  
• Diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms that are difficult to diagnose  
• “Yes-no” centers offering quick tests or scans for minor symptoms unlikely to be cancer  

These changes address the problem of delayed diagnosis, especially for patients with vague or less obvious symptoms. By providing faster tests and avoiding prolonged specialist “ping pong,” Denmark improved overall cancer survival rates. Denmark’s system—similar to Wales in funding and organization—demonstrates how better coordination between GPs and specialists can enhance timely diagnoses and treatment.

Powys council has been selected to replace the disbanded Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in regulating estate agents. It can issue warning and banning orders against agents who act dishonestly or breach estate agent laws, receiving £170,000 annually for this work. Complaints will still go through local authority trading standards departments, which will refer suspected Estate Agents Act violations to Powys. James Munro leads the new team and hopes to expand Powys’s external contracts in the future.

NHS Employers has endorsed a plan, based on a Nuffield Trust review, to expand nurses’ and other health staff’s roles to help fill workforce gaps, particularly among doctors and GPs. Examples include nurses performing some doctor responsibilities. However, unions and the BMA caution against using this as a shortcut to address shortages and stress the importance of proper funding and training. The organization sees “huge opportunities,” but warns that implementation requires dedicated resources.

A collision on Lower Bristol Road in Bath led Avon and Somerset Police to close the A36 at Rackfield Place from 03:00 GMT until 14:00 GMT, causing significant disruption to commuters and bus services. Investigations into the crash are ongoing. Though parts of bus operations have resumed, First’s managing director, James Freeman, indicated it will take a few more hours for all services to return to normal, thanking the public and staff for their support and efforts in managing the situation.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) predicts the Swansea tidal lagoon could kill about 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually, a figure Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes as lacking a clear scientific basis. TLP says its own modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of only 2% fish mortality. TLP also accuses NRW of not sharing its calculation methods, while NRW insists its estimates come from the best available evidence, supported by independent experts. The £1.3 billion project is seen as a test bed for larger lagoons around the Welsh coast, with the Welsh government supportive but awaiting the UK government’s review and decision on the scheme’s viability.

Northern Ireland’s Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster has announced the creation of a new, industry-led agri-food marketing body to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). Modeled on the success of Scotland Food and Drink, it aims to unify and strengthen the marketing efforts of government and private sector organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move, citing the agri-food sector’s vital role in export-led growth, while acknowledging that this body could affect the work of other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is creating one of four new UK woods at Brackfield Wood, near Derry, to commemorate those who died in WWI. They aim to plant 40,000 native trees here, representing the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives. Members of the public are encouraged to participate in planting events, with the trust providing saplings and guidance. The site will feature wildflowers such as poppies, offering a place for wildlife to flourish and for visitors to reflect on the conflict’s legacy.
