Mourinho, known for his confident sideline persona, describes himself as a good person who supports family, friends, and even strangers. Despite Chelsea’s success—currently topping the league—and his own claim of a “competitive and emotional” professional environment, he insists that he reserves his prayers for personal matters rather than sporting outcomes. He was previously fined for suggesting a campaign against Chelsea but continues to stand by his beliefs both on and off the pitch.

Bob Barker returned to host “The Price is Right” on April 1, taking over from Drew Carey for the first portion of the program. At 91, the longtime host handled a classic price-guessing game before Carey resumed his usual duties, with Barker showing little sign of having been away for eight years.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in southeast Washington, D.C., around midnight Friday and charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. His security clearance was revoked, and he was placed on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which works with the State Department. His arrest followed the suspension of a high-ranking supervisor for alleged misconduct. Both incidents are under investigation, adding to existing scrutiny of the agency by the Homeland Security Department’s inspector general.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed from Lahore, Pakistan, spotted a hungry male lion in a safari park and decided to approach it on foot, armed only with his camera. He crept to within about 10 feet, managing to capture a few frames before the lion noticed him. Forced to retreat quickly, he scrambled back into his car. Reflecting on the close call, Mr Saeed admitted it was a dangerous encounter he might not attempt again.

A woman—estimated to be between 25 and 45—was found unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 in Brooklyn’s Gravesend area. With no identification on her, police have released images of a distinctive heart tattoo on her right leg bearing the name “Monique,” potentially etched across a ribbon beneath a rose. Authorities await the medical examiner’s report for the cause of death and urge anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

Hannah and Alex returned to New Zealand from the UK without the funds to buy conventional property, so they bought a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent a year and a half converting it into a cozy, mostly self-sufficient home. Built using wood and a steel frame, the two-bedroom house features solar panels for power (with a minimal power bill), a gas-powered stove and hot water, and water from a nearby spring. Their total investment was about $25,000, and the couple loves their wood-lined, nature-surrounded abode—so much so that they plan to build another.

Researchers found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class achieved notably higher early literacy test scores—about 30 points higher—compared to students who either used individual iPads or had none. Studying 352 students over an academic year, Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University attributed these results to the collaborative learning fostered by sharing the devices. She suggested schools reevaluate how tablets are used, especially in early grades, to maximize their educational impact.

A piglet in Sichuan province, born without hind legs, has learned to walk on its front trotters and become an internet sensation. Nicknamed “super pig,” it balances unsteadily but manages to mix happily with the rest of its litter. Villagers flock to see the piglet, and similar two-legged animals—like a rabbit in Liuzhou Zoo that hops on its front paws—have also captured widespread attention in China.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips of Dale Coyne Racing, was injured during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana when Francesco Dracone’s car spun exiting the pit box on lap 25 and clipped Phillips’ leg. Phillips was treated for a leg cut and released. Rainy conditions caused traction issues throughout the race. Dracone did not finish, placing 23rd.

A husband, identified as 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, 29-year-old Cicera Alves de Sena (known by the stage name Amanda Bueno), just four days after their marriage in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. CCTV footage captured Severiano dragging her into a garden, repeatedly smashing her head into the concrete, punching her, and then shooting her in the face five times at point-blank range. He confessed jealousy over other men’s attention toward her. After fleeing in a neighbor’s car, he was caught by police, who discovered multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. He now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of “I Quit Sugar,” candidly discusses her struggle with mental illness. She reveals that mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated led her to a point where she questioned the purpose of continuing her life. Wilson explains that anxiety and depression are closely linked and believes that acknowledging this connection is vital to addressing the rising rates of mental health challenges among Australian women. Although she once felt she lacked a “guide book” for coping, Wilson has since found some peace in accepting her anxiety. She notes that anxiety is increasingly common and points to resources like Beyond Blue and Lifeline for help.

Elena Curtin, seven months pregnant at the time, returned home to discover her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom. When the ex-girlfriend refused to leave, Curtin beat her with a crowbar. Although Curtin was initially charged with second-degree assault, the charge was dropped under Oregon law allowing physical force against intruders who refuse to leave. She later gave birth in January, ended her relationship with the boyfriend, and moved in with her parents. Had she been convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.

Gemma the pit bull in California was filmed receiving treats, but when a piece of broccoli was slipped into the mix, she bit into it, made a disgusted face, and spat it out. Despite setting a poor example for the children she lives with, other videos show that, aside from rejecting broccoli, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC mistakenly directed visitors to a porn site through its official website after the link for its discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards was not renewed and taken over by a pornography business. Once HSBC discovered the error, it removed the hyperlink and issued a public apology, clarifying it had no connection to the external site. The bank assured customers its main website and banking services remain secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 on Sunday when a fire broke out on the first floor of his family’s home in Clinton. Trapped upstairs with his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah, Marcus remained calm during the 11-minute call, gave firefighters clear directions on how to reach them, and reassured his sister by reminding her to stay low and breathe. Firefighters entered the home, broke a window to reach the siblings, and provided a gas mask to the little girl. Both children and the other family members were taken to hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries.

Blue fluorescent algae, identified as Noctiluca scintillans, have been sighted along Australia’s east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured images of the neon glow, describing it as a “beautiful supernatural scene” caused by millions of plankton emitting light. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales noted that the algae commonly blooms in spring and autumn for natural reasons, producing its glow as a protective response. A similar display was observed at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014, with experts indicating no cause for concern.

New genetic tests can determine how aggressive breast cancer is and help identify if chemotherapy is necessary. By analyzing tumor samples after surgery, doctors can accurately assess an individual’s risk of recurrence—sometimes as low as five percent. This spares some women from undergoing chemotherapy’s significant side effects. While the tests, including EndoPredict, typically cost about £2,500 privately, specialists hope they will soon be offered routinely through the NHS, arguing that the cost is offset by reducing unnecessary chemotherapy.

More than 25 female Royal Navy personnel have been airlifted from ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. The Ministry of Defence enforces a “no touching” rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before deployment or while on leave. Nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK amid allegations of a relationship with a crew member, an investigation was launched and she was replaced. Women, who have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, currently make up about 9% of personnel, and three recently became the first female submariners. Meanwhile, nearly 100 pregnant British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan (between 2006 and 2013), with similar rules banning mothers-to-be from active war zones.

A drone containing small traces of radioactive material was discovered on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence, raising terrorism concerns. Found on the same day Japan approved restarting two nuclear reactors, the device had a camera, smoke flares, and a bottle with suspected cesium. Although not immediately harmful, the incident prompted officials to highlight the security threat drones could pose—particularly during major events like the Olympics and G7 summit—and highlighted gaps in Tokyo’s drone flight restrictions. Prime Minister Abe was in Indonesia at the time of the discovery.

A security guard in Zhejiang province, China, named Lu Xincai, cares for his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer’s by taking her to work with him each day. He ties a sash around both waists and travels four kilometers by motorbike at a slow pace so as not to frighten her. His mother has her own room at the bank where he works, allowing him to check on her often. Lu explains that his mother devoted her life to him, and he feels it is now his duty to ensure she remains safe and does not wander off.

Heavy drinking in the United States increased by 17.2% from 2005 to 2012, mainly due to rising rates among women. Binge drinking (defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on one occasion) grew especially fast among women, narrowing the gap with men. County-level data show wide variation: some areas report far higher or lower drinking levels than others. Contributing factors include changing social norms for women, relative affordability of alcohol, more alcohol advertising, and relaxed alcohol control policies. Excessive drinking is linked to a high societal cost—over $220 billion per year—and roughly 88,600 deaths in 2010.

UN officials, specifically the World Health Organization (WHO), warn that caesarean sections are being performed too frequently, increasing health risks and costs. In England, the caesarean rate has climbed to over a quarter of births—more than double the early 1990s rate—yet the WHO recommends a rate between only 10% and 15%. While some women choose planned caesareans due to anxiety (tokophobia) or various medical reasons, the WHO emphasizes that non-medically necessary caesareans can lead to infections, complications, even death, and divert funds away from other healthcare needs. Despite current NHS guidelines permitting caesareans for anxious patients, the WHO contends that doctors underestimate the risks and should limit the procedure to situations of clear medical necessity.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, is accused of breaking into a Martha’s Vineyard home, living there for about a week, and selling the owners’ belongings in a yard sale. Homeowner Mark Conklin found Filkins in his living room on April 17, at which point she fled. Police later arrested her the same day after she tried to re-enter the property. Filkins faces charges including breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, and is due in court on May 14. Various household items were taken, and police ask anyone who bought or received them to return them for potential restitution.

Bella from Melbourne lost her iPhone at a friend’s birthday party, and it was handed to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Finding the phone unlocked, officers posted humorous selfies and puns on Bella’s Facebook page to locate her. Friends saw the posts and shared them widely, amused by the police’s creative approach. When Bella arrived to pick up her phone, the officers recognized her immediately. She has since put a password on her device and thanked the police for both returning it and providing plenty of laughs.

A five-day-old hippopotamus calf was tragically killed after straying into the middle of a violent fight between two adult males in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. Witnesses, including tour operator Stacey Farrell, saw the calf hurled into the air and dragged along the water, while its mother looked on helplessly. The two male hippos had been fighting for some time, and in the chaos, a sub-adult hippo grabbed the calf in its jaws. Despite the mother’s attempts to save her baby, it eventually died from its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom Knightsbridge apartment is on sale for £575,000—which is far below neighboring properties—because it only has three years remaining on its lease. If the lease is extended, the cost to do so is estimated between £3.35 million and £4.5 million, and the property’s value could rise to around £6 million (or £7.5 million for the larger, similarly short-leased apartment). Both homes need modernization, but agents note the rarity of such opportunities in Knightsbridge. This situation highlights the financial trade-off of acquiring a property at a seemingly low price but facing a substantial premium to extend a short lease.

Starbucks experienced a widespread computer outage affecting 8,000 stores across the U.S. and Canada on Friday, causing registers to go down and prompting many locations to give away free drinks before some stores closed early. The glitch, attributed to a “failure during a daily system refresh,” was resolved by Saturday, allowing normal operations to resume. During the outage, customers shared their free beverages and store closure updates on social media. The incident occurred shortly after the chain reported record quarterly earnings.

Terrorist training and radicalization are reported in rural west Wales—specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire—where individuals engage in ordinary community activities with ulterior motives. Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit highlights that extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998 with Abu Hamza’s followers training in the Brecon Beacons. Incidents include two of the 7/7 bombers visiting Bala in 2005, a 2010 “Mumbai-style” plot linked to Cardiff-based extremists, and one of Lee Rigby’s murderers having studied Arabic at a local institute. Authorities stress the importance of community intelligence in identifying and countering these threats.

A rare Omura’s whale, believed to have been virtually unknown in Western Australia, was recently found on an Exmouth beach after a cyclone. DNA testing confirmed this 5.68-metre juvenile female as the first recorded sighting of its species in WA and only the second in Australia. Very little is known about Omura’s whales, which were first described in 2003 and are thought to inhabit tropical and subtropical waters near Indonesia, the Philippines, and Japan. Authorities plan to recover the buried skeleton later for scientific study and potential museum display.

This passage critiques the notion that female “hormones” should disqualify women from leadership. It points out that men’s hormone-driven behavior has caused wars and scandals, while research shows women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. Despite advances, gender bias persists—women face overt and subtle discrimination, and Hillary Clinton’s candidacy highlights the challenge. The author argues that true equality benefits everyone, from families to businesses, and rejects the idea that women should be limited by outdated stereotypes.

Robert Hardy, aged 89 and famed for roles such as Winston Churchill and the vet Siegfried Farnon in “All Creatures Great and Small,” is auctioning more than 200 antiques from his personal collection as he downsizes his home. The items, offered through Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, include a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, chandeliers, and a large library—some volumes dating to the 17th century. Hardy, who studied under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford and has written extensively on longbow history, expressed sadness at parting with the pieces but wishes future owners the same enjoyment they brought him. He continues to work in television, having appeared as Minister for Magic Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films, despite retiring from stage work after an injury.

Michael Scott Shemansky is suspected of killing his mother, Sandra Shemansky, at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida. The body was discovered when an out-of-state family member requested a well-being check. Authorities say Shemansky failed to appear for a scheduled supervised visit with his son on the day his mother was found dead. He has a criminal background, a history of bipolar mental illness, and was previously involuntarily committed for an attempted suicide. Neighbors suggest that looming divorce proceedings may have been a source of stress. Police have the murder weapon (details not publicly disclosed), and Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without supplies or medication. Law enforcement encourages anyone with information to contact them at 407-656-3636.

Eugene in the United States has been granted the 2021 IAAF World Championships after the IAAF Council bypassed the standard bidding process, considering it a “unique strategic opportunity” to bring the event to the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously lost its bid to host the 2019 championships to Doha, but a subsequent presentation convinced the IAAF of the city’s capability. This decision follows a similar precedent set in 2007, when Osaka was awarded the championships without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger lured professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death, leaving her boyfriend and an accomplice to enter Hassan’s flat, rob him, and beat him to death. Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years. Co-defendants Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. The judge described the crime as “pitiless and wicked.” Hassan, a father of three, was bound, viciously attacked, and left in his flat, while the killers stole cash and his belongings.

Cesc Fàbregas began the season in outstanding form for Chelsea, quickly amassing assists and looking on course to break Thierry Henry’s Premier League record. However, consistent with the “post-Christmas slump” noted by his former club Barcelona, his performances have dipped significantly since January, culminating in a poor showing in Spain’s recent 2–0 loss to the Netherlands. Despite his fatigue and drop in form, Fàbregas remains a pivotal figure for Chelsea, who are pushing to secure the Premier League title. With nine matches remaining and opponents he has already excelled against still to come, both his personal aim of breaking the assist record and Chelsea’s title hopes hinge on a potential resurgence in form.

West Ham are closing in on a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed coaches during a two-week trial. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, also has offers from Belgian clubs and is seen as one of the Caribbean’s top prospects. Meanwhile, West Ham have announced season tickets at their new 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium will start at £289 for the 2016–17 Premier League season.

Police dropped their investigation into the assault on huntsman Mike Lane, despite video footage, car registration numbers, and the suspect’s photograph. Lane, who was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters wielding iron bars, suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Although evidence was provided, police halted the case for lack of progress, leaving Lane and other hunt supporters angered and disappointed. The incident highlighted concerns about saboteurs wearing face coverings, prompting calls to ban them so attackers can be identified more easily.

Adam Gadahn was an American who converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998. He joined al Qaeda, becoming its chief English-language propagandist and appearing in numerous videos threatening Western targets. Indicted in 2006 for treason, he was among the FBI’s most wanted terrorists. The White House announced he was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, the same month another American al Qaeda member, Ahmed Farouq, was killed. Neither man was specifically targeted. Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was notable for his online propaganda, calling for attacks on the United States and its allies. His final video was released by al Qaeda in September 2014.

A new Chinese child basketball prodigy named Mai Zizhuo, who has been playing since he was two and a half, has captivated fans across China. In a viral video, the five-year-old effortlessly scores multiple baskets and dribbles two basketballs at once without missing a beat. His performance has sparked widespread admiration, with many online commentators expressing astonishment at his talent and comparing themselves unfavorably to his skill level. This highlights China’s enthusiasm for nurturing young prodigies—much like past examples in academia and entertainment—and recalls the country’s established basketball legacy led by figures such as Yao Ming.

Tom O’Carroll, formerly a key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and ’80s, attended a Hacked Off rally on February 25 at the Houses of Parliament. Hacked Off, formed after the phone-hacking scandal, is pushing MPs to enact statutory press regulation as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O’Carroll’s support is seen as an embarrassment for Hacked Off, given his history: he was jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals,” and PIE had links to the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which at one time lobbied to lower the age of consent to ten. A Hacked Off spokesperson noted their meeting was free and open to the public.

Bondi’s iconic Icebergs club pool was drained on Thursday for the Ten Pieces show during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Ten Pieces, led by restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, presented a monochrome, unisex capsule of ten items, designed to be worn in multiple ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall, offering onlookers an ocean backdrop. Guests enjoyed refreshments in the warm, sunny weather, while curious beachgoers and passers-by stopped to watch the unique catwalk setting.

Amir Khan, the Bolton-born boxer, visited a safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa, feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. Shortly afterward, he confirmed his next welterweight fight on May 30 against former light-welterweight champion Chris Algieri, having been under pressure to face Kell Brook and also linked with Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was killed by three Israelis, was initially included on Israel’s national memorial for fallen soldiers and terror victims. However, his family objected to his name appearing on the memorial wall, stating they were not consulted and did not want him listed alongside Israeli soldiers. An Israeli victims’ advocacy group, Almagor, also opposed his inclusion, calling it a "rogue attack" rather than terrorism. In response to these objections, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove Abu Khdeir’s name from both the memorial wall and its associated website.

A young boy repeatedly tries to use his cat’s belly as a pillow, chasing the feline around the garden in search of a place to rest. Each time the boy settles down on the cat, the cat moves to another spot. Eventually, the cat tires of this and heads indoors. A later video shows the pair reconciling as the boy gently feeds the cat treats.

Robert Kushner testified in a Philadelphia police corruption trial that officers once stole cash and drugs from him, prompting the revelation of his past marijuana dealing. He subsequently lost his job as a varsity basketball coach at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, where he had passed a background check in 2010 and had not disclosed his arrests. Kushner said his 2007 charges were expunged after probation, that he was arrested again in 2011 (which he disputes), and that he pleaded guilty to DUI in 2008. The trial centers on six former Philadelphia drug squad officers accused of racketeering and other crimes, with defense lawyers arguing the case relies on untrustworthy witnesses.

An explosion at a paraxylene-producing chemical plant in Zhangzhou, southeastern China, injured six people after an oil leak caused a large fire. Five of the injured were hurt by broken glass; more than 600 firefighters contained the blaze. No toxic chemical spill was reported. The plant had previously suffered an explosion in 2013. Originally slated for the nearby city of Xiamen, it was relocated after public protests over pollution concerns—similar demonstrations against PX plants have erupted in other Chinese cities.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland Under-21 international, is known for wearing his socks low—just above child-size shin pads. He insists this is a long-held superstition and refuses to change, despite Premier League referees urging him to pull his socks up. Grealish recently made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing pleasure at finally getting the opportunity and citing the manager’s confidence in him, although he was disappointed with the result. He plans to keep his signature look and hopes to avoid any future shin injuries.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, is out of a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive with “global and irreversible brain damage.” According to her grandmother, Cissy Houston, she does not respond to visitors or follow movement with her eyes. While her father, Bobby Brown, claimed she was “awake” and “watching” him, the family’s attorney clarified that her condition has improved but remains uncertain. Doctors believe she may have a long life, though the quality of that life won’t be known for years, and she is now undergoing a challenging rehabilitation process.

Russia built a 2-0 lead in their Fed Cup tie against Germany after Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets, and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova rallied from a match point down to beat Sabine Lisicki in three sets. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki’s power and recorded 13 double faults, but Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors were pivotal. Russia now needs just one more win from Sunday’s matches to advance to the final, aiming for their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Another east coast low is likely to bring heavy rain and possible flooding to parts of New South Wales later this week, worrying residents and the State Emergency Service (SES) still dealing with damage from last week’s storm. Around 4,000 of over 24,000 SES requests remain unresolved, and there are particular concerns about the Hunter region, which was hard-hit by flooding. Meteorologists expect the new system—though it may move faster and stay a bit farther offshore—to affect northern coastal areas most, with possible impacts extending into southeast Queensland. The SES is urging residents to prepare, noting that any additional rainfall could quickly raise flood levels on already saturated ground, and uprooted trees remain vulnerable to strong winds. The Bureau of Meteorology is monitoring the situation but says it is too early to confirm the storm’s full severity.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loca” music video, was reported by Italian media to have attempted suicide, but she denies this claim. Instead, she explains she collapsed at home due to low blood pressure, was taken to the hospital, and is now recovering. Moric posted photos of her bruises on Instagram, clarifying that her boyfriend was away at the time and that she had no intention to end her life. She was once married to paparazzi Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities, and they share a son.

A recent poll shows the British public favor a girl for Kate and William’s second child, with “Diana” (after William’s late mother) as the top name choice if it’s a girl, followed by Alice and Charlotte. If it’s a boy, “James” is favored, with “Alexander” as the second option. Overall, many respondents support William’s plan to take six weeks of paternity leave, indicating broad public approval for both the anticipated new arrival and his family’s decisions.

A suicide bomber struck a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding at least 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves, having won multiple titles over seven successful years with Barcelona, will leave the club this summer. Despite a proposed three-year extension, Alves rejected the offer—tied to him playing 60% of matches—and his agent, Dinorah Santana, announced negotiations are now over.

Pablo Osvaldo, on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has quickly impressed by scoring three goals in six appearances. He is urging his former Italy teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club, believing their style of play and high profiles would be perfect fits at Boca. Osvaldo insists the Bombonera fans would “go crazy” for the two Italian legends, highlighting Totti’s status as a Roma icon and Pirlo’s reputation as one of the world’s premier midfielders.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey in Paul Nicholls’s yard, took a spectacular double somersault fall from Merrion Square at Wincanton, which attracted hundreds of thousands of online views. Despite only sustaining a cut on his nose, Ferguson said he wasn’t entirely sure what happened until he watched the replay. Fellow jockeys expressed concern, but he returned to riding, remains undeterred, and even joked about considering a gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, dressed up as Iron Man in an Instagram post to mark the release of the new “Avengers: Age of Ultron” film. The movie premiered at Westfield London, drawing fans to see stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell began his career at Wasps in 2002, left in 2009 for spells with Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and the Highlanders in New Zealand, then returned to Wasps in 2012. Since coming back, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 England caps.

Wide-leg trousers are presented as a fresh alternative to long-dominant skinny jeans, referencing their 1970s roots and previous comebacks. They can be styled in various cuts—from cropped to flared denim—and work best with high-heeled shoes to elongate the leg. Keeping the top half simple (e.g., knit, shirt, or tee) preserves proper proportion. Designers such as Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney have showcased them, while high-street options like Topshop’s Miller jean and Finery London offer budget-friendlier versions. The key advice is to maintain balance with a fitted or minimalist top, high waistlines, and heels, ensuring a flattering, updated look for any season.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a planned screening of “American Sniper” after more than 200 students petitioned, citing its potentially negative portrayal of the Middle East. Following backlash and a counter-petition, the university reversed the decision, calling the cancellation a mistake and emphasizing freedom of expression. “American Sniper” was ultimately shown, with the family-friendly “Paddington” offered as an alternative, and head football coach Jim Harbaugh praised the reinstatement.

Two French tourists on Rottnest Island, off Perth in Western Australia, allegedly lit an aerosol spray with a lighter on April 3, causing a large flame to make contact with a quokka. The animal was singed but survived. Detectives questioned the men, aged 18 and 24, confiscated video evidence, and evicted them from the island. Both were charged with animal cruelty and are due in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, about the size of a domestic cat, are found on small islands off the West Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed at famous New York venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and ’40s alongside stars such as Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen the filmed performances she appeared in. All her photographs and memorabilia were lost. Recently, Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled “soundies”—early music videos—featuring Barker and showed them to her at her nursing home, leaving her delighted.

A new survey shows that washing your own car, once a common Sunday tradition in Britain, is on the decline. A third of men and three-quarters of women say they have never washed their own car, with many opting for automatic or hand car washes instead. Time constraints, the availability of other Sunday activities, and the growing size of vehicles contribute to this trend. The study also notes that Brits wash their cars more often during holiday breaks—though sometimes as an excuse to get out of the house—and reveals regional differences (with people in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield washing most frequently) as well as variations by car brand (Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs more likely to be personally washed compared to Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes).

Martin Skrtel highlights the profound influence Steven Gerrard has had on him since joining Liverpool in 2008 and still considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world. Gerrard is preparing to feature in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with a potential send-off in the final on his birthday before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel credits Gerrard for helping him settle at the club and acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without their iconic captain, but believes there are players who can fill Gerarrd’s role if supported properly. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return from bans for the Villa match.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus dazzled the crowd at Augusta National’s par-3 contest by making his first ace on the course, holing out from the 130-yard fourth hole. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus’s feat was part of a day that featured five total holes-in-one—Camilo Villegas managed two but ultimately lost in a play-off to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, who first wore the green jacket in 1963 and won his sixth in 1986, is one of five players to complete the career Grand Slam—an achievement Rory McIlroy could replicate if he wins this year.

Storms triggered tornado sirens in Kansas Wednesday night, including a reported tornado near Goddard, west of Wichita. Additional tornado sightings were noted in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri also experienced severe weather, with a possible tornado in Potosi causing wind damage, flooding, and large hail reported in nearby Farmington. The National Weather Service warned of more storms Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve deputy with the Tulsa County Sheriff’s Office, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter charges after fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he meant to deploy a Taser instead. Despite the ongoing legal proceedings, a judge approved his request to vacation in the Bahamas, drawing criticism from Harris’s family. They also challenge Bates’s qualifications, alleging he received preferential treatment due to donations and personal connections. The Sheriff’s Office denies accusations of forged training records, though Bates’s lawyers maintain his training was valid. A preliminary hearing is set for July 2.

Conor McGregor revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach ahead of his July 11 featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo. He already has a gorilla tattoo on his chest and posted the new artwork on Instagram, emphasizing his predatory mindset. McGregor believes he is more motivated than Aldo, claiming the champion “doesn’t want it” as much. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo’s belt, fueling the tense relationship between them leading up to their Las Vegas showdown.

Tony Abbott, then Prime Minister of Australia, publicly “skolled” a beer in about six seconds at an Australian rules event, prompting criticism from anti-drinking advocates. They argue that his action—and the approving reactions from onlookers—encourages a culture of rapid and excessive drinking rather than social, responsible consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert, among the critics, cites the act as problematic because it reinforces the idea that heavy drinking is tied to masculinity and Australian identity. While some political figures and media outlets poked fun or dismissed concerns, others stressed that public figures should be mindful of shifting attitudes toward binge drinking and its harmful effects.

Indiana has recorded at least 120 confirmed HIV cases and 10 preliminary positives in Scott County, largely among intravenous drug users who share needles, particularly while using the painkiller Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence authorized a 30-day needle exchange program, which has already distributed thousands of clean syringes but is due to expire soon. This short-term measure faces scrutiny from Pence—an opponent of needle exchanges—and legislators, who are also considering a bill that would enable similar programs in other high-risk counties. Questions remain about long-term funding and whether the initiative will be extended or replicated elsewhere to address the HIV outbreak.

An Arsenal superfan created a school-style exam for his girlfriend, Saskia, testing her knowledge of the club. She scored 87% (43.5 out of 50), sparing her from a joking threat of a breakup. The detailed quiz included multiple-choice questions, tables to fill, and open responses about players, positions, and key match details. Saskia received extra marks for creative answers—especially her comments on Alexis Sánchez versus Eden Hazard—and despite mixing up some player positions, she earned an “A.” Social media reactions ranged from praise for both her and the boyfriend to criticism of his overzealous approach.

Carlos Toro, 66, formerly part of the Medellin cartel, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years, providing crucial information that led to prosecutions of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. In exchange, he was promised U.S. citizenship but never received it, and following retirement due to declining health, he now faces possible deportation. He fears for his life if sent back to Colombia. Despite his extensive cooperation with the DEA, they have refused further assistance, and Toro currently has no valid visa, cannot collect benefits, and may consider going into hiding if he is forced to leave the country.

A 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh’s Mathura district allegedly suffered gang rape by five men while outside her home. Afterwards, she set herself on fire using kerosene; she is now hospitalized with severe burns. The suspects have been arrested. This incident arises amid heightened scrutiny of sexual violence in India, compounded by the recent banning of the “India’s Daughter” documentary, which examined the 2012 gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh in New Delhi. Protests have erupted over such attacks, with some instances of vigilante violence—one involved a mob beating a man to death over allegations of rape and murder. The public outcry over Jyoti Singh’s case led to severe penalties for the perpetrators and global condemnation of the crime.

Louis van Gaal confirms that Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw are not fit to face Manchester City, stressing that “fitness” means meeting his standards. He emphasizes the importance of beating City to climb the table (potentially securing third place and avoiding a Champions League qualifier), referencing the 1–0 loss in the previous derby and the need to control aggression. Van Gaal looks forward to experiencing the Old Trafford atmosphere and praises the support of United fans.

Fans of Arsenal and Liverpool staged a protest against high ticket prices during their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. Some supporters left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes, while others displayed banners reading “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket.” Organized by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, the demonstration focused on the growing cost of attending matches (tickets started at £64) in the wake of the league’s multibillion-pound TV rights deal. Protesters called the prices “extortionate” and warned that fans, especially those on lower incomes, are being priced out of attending games. Further protests were planned after the match.

A newborn named Star was diagnosed shortly after birth with biliary atresia, a serious liver condition in which bile ducts are blocked or absent. Initial attempts to unblock her bile ducts were unsuccessful, and her parents were informed a liver transplant was the only option. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but Star’s maternal aunt—and her mother’s twin sister—proved a perfect match. She donated part of her liver, saving Star’s life. Both Star and her aunt have recovered well following the operation, and Star will continue to undergo regular tests and take anti-rejection medication.

Chelsea’s Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian compete in an Audi-sponsored football challenge. Hazard and Ake win the first two rounds: aiming balls into a car boot at close range, and then playing a makeshift tennis match using an Audi R8 as the “net.” Remy and Willian ultimately take the final round, firing balls from long range into a convertible. In the process, Willian accidentally smashes a wing mirror with a stray shot, drawing a shocked reaction from Remy.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a December 2013 crash in New Hampshire that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy (eight months pregnant) and Jason Timmons. Investigators initially said Dellinger claimed he was suicidal when he crossed the median at over 100 mph, but during sentencing he denied having suicidal intent. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces 12 to 24 years in prison, as well as a wrongful death lawsuit. Dellinger’s defense argues he was affected by medication issues and multiple sclerosis. His wife testified that he was a man of integrity, expressing devastation over the victims’ deaths.

Lacey Spears was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul, with salt and received a 20-years-to-life sentence (less than the maximum 25 to life). During sentencing, Spears showed no emotion, and the judge noted she suffers from a mental illness while calling the crime “unfathomable in its cruelty.” Prosecutors argued she harmed her child to gain attention, citing her frequent online posts about his supposed illnesses, while her defense claimed she was a loving, hardworking single mother. The boy’s father, Chris Hill, reacted angrily on Facebook, wishing Spears would be placed in the general prison population and expressing his hope that she would not survive her sentence.

An updated flu vaccine designed to protect against two new strains (H3N2 and B/Phuket) is arriving in Australia about a month later than expected. These strains contributed to a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the US, where the existing vaccine was not a good match. The improved vaccine, which also covers H1N1, will be available free to high-risk groups (including the very young, the elderly, most Indigenous Australians) from April 20. Experts, such as Dr. Alan Hampson, recommend vaccination for everyone, noting it offers stronger protection and matches what will be used in the Northern Hemisphere next season.

The passage describes ongoing concerns over Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield, Illinois. A recent National Geographic article criticized the tomb’s interior, calling it lacking in historical character. Meanwhile, Illinois faces a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed consolidating the state’s historic preservation agency—potentially reducing funding and staffing for the site. Despite recent renovations costing over $2.5 million and some visitors praising the tomb’s appearance, caretakers worry about additional budget cuts. Originally built on an inadequate foundation, Lincoln’s tomb underwent reconstructions in 1899 and 1930; its present interior features black and tan marble, bronze trim, and halls leading to the burial chamber. Some believe the National Geographic critique is unfair, citing the tomb’s upgraded condition and its continued importance as a historic attraction.

Nineties fashion trends are making a comeback, from chokers to wide-leg rave jeans (such as JNCO). The passage highlights several once-popular items—like bucket hats, camouflage prints, and corsets worn as outerwear—now revived by modern celebrities (e.g., Rihanna, Kylie Jenner). Other returning trends include over-the-top denim, UGG boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture velour tracksuits, colored sunglasses, and harem pants. While some embrace these retro looks, many who wore them originally find the revival surprising or impractical.

There was a burst of attention-worthy stories: four rainbows graced the New York sky after heavy rain, and in rural China, exotic dancers at wakes are under government crackdown. Robert Downey Jr. grew frustrated with a UK interviewer asking about his private life. A new lip-plumping trend surfaced online (the so-called #kyliejennerchallenge). Filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker revisit her past performances. A prom-posal referencing bombs caused controversy, with the student accusing administrators of racism. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in “Beauty and the Beast,” Johnny Depp appears almost unrecognizable in a “Black Mass” trailer, a pregnancy was announced referencing “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,” and a military dad photobombed his son, earning originality points for the week.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory at the Miami Open with a giant cake, mirroring Andy Murray’s similar celebration for his 500th win. She defeated Sabine Lisicki in three sets, gaining partial revenge for her 2013 Wimbledon loss. Venus Williams was eliminated by Carla Suarez Navarro, ruling out another sister showdown. Serena will now face Simona Halep in the semifinals after the Romanian defeated Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud was a Pakistani activist who ran a café called the Second Floor (T2F) in Karachi, where she fostered open discussions on technology, human rights, and other taboo subjects. Shortly after hosting a talk about disappearances in Baluchistan—an issue authorities had tried to silence—she was shot and killed, and her mother injured. Renowned for her courage, Mahmud’s death sparked grief across Pakistan, where she was admired for championing free speech, non-violence, and cultural expression in a region where voicing dissent is perilous.

Thousands of Hindu families, including 82-year-old Mangu Ram, fled violence during India’s 1947 partition and settled in Jammu and Kashmir, India’s only Muslim-majority state. Classified as West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), they have been denied the right to own property, vote in state elections, or work in state government positions, leaving three generations mired in poverty. Successive Kashmiri governments have feared that granting full rights to these overwhelmingly Hindu refugees would alter the region’s delicate demographic balance. However, the rise of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist party (BJP) in state government has sparked new hope that the WPRs might finally receive the rights they have long been denied. Even so, tensions remain high in Kashmir due to an ongoing conflict involving separatist rebels, and WPR community leaders warn they may resort to further action if once again denied the chance to integrate fully as citizens of the state.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward at FC Tokyo, is weighing a proposed move to Chelsea, which reportedly offered around £4 million. Muto’s primary concern is securing regular playing time and professional growth, even though Chelsea plans to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem. His former coach, Ranko Popovic, praises Muto’s speed, intelligence, and strong character, suggesting he could succeed at a high level. Chelsea manager José Mourinho acknowledges both the club’s interest in Muto and the importance of commercial factors (such as the club’s sponsorship with Yokohama Rubber), but emphasizes that Chelsea only signs players with genuine quality or potential.

Australia recently reversed its policy to exclude overseas-based players, which the writer applauds as forward-thinking. In contrast, England remain bound by a rule preventing selection of players who have left domestic clubs. The passage argues that England’s best players should be picked regardless of where they play, especially for an event as important as a home World Cup. Examples cited include Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell (both reinvigorated at Toulon and now potential Wallabies), Steffon Armitage (whose move to France has greatly enhanced his game), and Nick Abendanon (also improved abroad). The writer contends that denying such talent harms England’s chances and fosters doubt among current squad members. The overarching message is that coaches must be free to choose the strongest possible team without constraints based on geography.

FireChat is an app developed by Open Garden that enables messaging via a wireless mesh network rather than relying on mobile or internet signals. It uses Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (and a similar feature on Android) to link nearby phones via Bluetooth and Wi-Fi Direct so that each device acts as a node passing data along. This makes messaging possible even without a traditional connection, useful in places like planes, subways, and large gatherings where networks can fail.

To address the limited range of mesh messages (about 200 feet), Open Garden created Greenstone—an egg-shaped device that extends coverage by storing and relaying messages until another FireChat user comes within about 20 feet. Greenstone runs for a year on one battery, can hold up to 1,000 recent messages, and is intended for use in areas or events where resilient, off-grid communication is needed. It is still under development and currently works only with FireChat.

Lillian Bustle is a New Jersey burlesque performer who aims to remove the negative stigma from the word “fat” by treating it as a simple descriptor—just like “short” or “wife.” In her TED talk, she notes that “fat” need not mean “ugly” and cites statistics showing increasing size discrimination in the workplace and how many young girls simply wish to be thinner. However, she highlights research suggesting the more people see diverse body types, the more open and accepting they become. Having started burlesque in 2012, Lillian found her performances empowering, and her TED talk, posted on YouTube, has largely received positive reactions, reinforcing her body-positive message.

Theo Walcott has spent much of the season on the bench, having been a substitute in 17 of Arsenal’s 33 Premier League matches. Recently, he joined several teammates for a Lanvin photoshoot, highlighting the fashion house as Arsenal’s official tailor (players will wear similar attire at the upcoming FA Cup final). Walcott was brought on late in Arsenal’s 0-0 draw with Chelsea and hopes to earn a starting spot in the next match against Hull.

A collection of more than 400 original movie props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker’s 30-year career will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at propstore.com. Valued at around $746,100, pieces from famous films—including Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, Gremlins 2, Harry and the Hendersons, Moonwalker, and others—are expected to fetch anywhere from a few thousand dollars to over $40,000. Highlights include items such as the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, the Grinch costume, and various Gremlins puppets. This sale offers fans and collectors a rare opportunity to own iconic Hollywood memorabilia from Baker’s Cinovation Studio.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell was on a family ski holiday in Flaine, France, when he became separated from his mother, entered dense woodland, and fell 164 feet to his death. Described as a daring, outgoing, and determined child whose smile lit up any room, he was an experienced skier who had been on the slopes since age three. Despite his mother’s urgent search, footprints led police to his body. His family, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, is devastated, describing Carwyn as an affectionate boy who loved adventure and filled their lives with laughter.

Laura, 15, developed anorexia after wanting to lose weight and experiencing bullying. She hid food, survived on as little as one piece of fruit a day, and lied to family about eating. Her health deteriorated rapidly—her heart rate slowed, she collapsed, and she spent a week on a heart monitor in intensive care. With help from eating disorder services and mental health teams, Laura gradually recovered. Now she has regained confidence and is a semi-finalist in Miss Teen GB, a competition advocating healthy body image, distancing itself from the “size zero” ideal.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit at Anfield, supplied by New Balance on a record-breaking £300million four-year deal. Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet modeled the new strip, with fans urging Sterling to remain at the club despite his recent contract dispute. Sterling had rejected a £100,000-a-week offer and admitted being flattered by links to Arsenal, but Liverpool insist he will not leave this summer. The kit features white branding, a redesigned collar, and the Hillsborough memorial flame. Players also discussed their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, hoping to bring success to the club’s passionate supporters.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky so far. Created using the powerful Dark Energy Camera in Chile, this is the first in a series of maps that will eventually provide a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky. The map shows how dark matter (shown in red for denser regions) affects galaxies through gravitational lensing, allowing scientists to study how galaxies form around these clumps. Part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, the project aims to use supercomputing power to analyze the shapes of 130 million galaxies, revealing the interplay between dark matter, visible matter, and the mysterious force of dark energy that accelerates the universe’s expansion.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV for their 21-year-old winger, Memphis Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season. Depay worked under Louis van Gaal during the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup campaign, where he impressed as a substitute and helped the team finish third. Previously valued around £15million when Tottenham tried to sign him last summer, Depay is now attracting bids “talking about bigger amounts,” with interest from Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club. Known for his pace, dribbling ability, and powerful right foot, he has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo. PSV recently won their first Eredivisie title in seven years, with Depay playing a key role.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 advantage over Manchester City in the Youth Cup final, with Tammy Abraham netting two volleys and Dominic Solanke adding a late third after Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly drawn City level. The passage details standout performances and backgrounds for both sides, highlighting City’s promising players—like captain Tosin Adarabioyo and Brandon Barker—as well as Chelsea’s strong defensive core in Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter. It emphasizes how each player fared, notes some injury concerns, and underscores the talent on display in a competitive match that saw Chelsea’s attacking power ultimately prevail.

Marco Rubio, who recently announced his presidential run, has stated that while he believes people are born with their sexual preference, he does not view same-sex marriage as a constitutional right. Instead, he feels such decisions should be made at the state level through legislative debate rather than by the courts. Despite his personal opposition to same-sex marriage, Rubio said he would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cares about, underscoring that disagreement should not prevent loving or respecting others. He likened this stance to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong yet would not lead him to stop caring for someone who divorces. Rubio’s campaign donors have claimed commitments surpassing $51 million to support his bid for the presidency.

Pablo (27, Spanish) and Ilze (31, Latvian) left their restaurant jobs in Manchester and have spent nearly a year biking through 16 countries, covering about 7,000 miles. They travel on a minimal budget of under three euros each per day, mostly camping or staying with hosts via Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Food is their largest expense; they cook basic meals, occasionally accept donated produce, and even dumpster-dive where possible. Their journey began in London and continued south into France, Spain, Portugal, and East through Italy and the Balkans. After riding across Turkey’s northern coast, they entered Georgia and Armenia, with plans to keep cycling across Asia, then eventually the Americas. Their open-ended trip focuses on seeing the world slowly, at “a pedal at a time,” without a fixed schedule or agenda.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 discovered that a photo booth at their wedding produced prints with a racist slur at the bottom, allegedly reading “poor n***** party.” They learned about this several months later from the bride’s sister, who had been trying not to upset them during the celebration. James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, denies the accusations; when the groom contacted him, Evans allegedly refused to apologize and told the couple to “sue” him. Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, the couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract, and primarily want an apology. Evans claims there is no proof connecting his company to the slur and says the couple showed no sign of distress. Mediation is scheduled, with a possible trial in July if no agreement is reached.

Mike Brown, England’s full-back, is uncertain when he will return to play after suffering concussion symptoms following the France match. He emphasizes caution, noting other players such as George North and Johnny Sexton who have faced prolonged absences due to repeat head injuries. Brown discusses the importance of increased awareness of concussion symptoms—largely reinforced by online training modules—and highlights that taking time to recover properly is vital, even if it means missing significant matches.

Sex frequency among heterosexual couples in Britain has declined over recent decades, from five times a month in 1990 to four in 2000 and three now. Professor David Spiegelhalter suggests that smartphones—and technology in general—are partly to blame, as constant connectivity erodes the boundaries between work, home, and personal time. This leaves couples with less uninterrupted, “quiet” time, causing sex to fall lower on their list of priorities. Additionally, more people living alone may also be a contributing factor.

Tibetan mastiffs were once highly prized in China, selling for up to £1.2 million thanks to their status-symbol appeal. However, a government anti-corruption campaign curtailed gift-giving to officials, and new city regulations banning large dogs further lowered demand. Unscrupulous breeding led to poor-quality dogs and oversupply. As a result, many mastiffs now end up in slaughterhouses for meat and leather. Despite once symbolizing wealth, the breed’s unsuitable nature for urban living and diminished value have driven it from favor.

Every woman surveyed in Paris reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half first assaulted before turning 18. The harassment ranges from insults, whistling, and unwanted flirting to sexual assault and rape, often going unreported. As a result, six in ten women fear attacks on buses or trains, leading them to alter their routines, dress, or travel modes. A report by the High Council for Gender Equality highlights how widespread the problem is and calls for a campaign to address sexist behavior and raise awareness that such acts are punishable under French law.

Direct Line ran a #everydayfix competition, asking Makerversity design teams to tackle common “everyday emergencies” identified in a survey of 2,000 people (top issue: not being able to sleep). Three shortlisted prototypes emerged: “Snooze,” an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to improve sleep; “Forget Me Lock,” a key attachment that shows via green/red whether a door is locked; and “Nipper,” a tiny phone charger powered by any household battery. Twitter users can vote for their favorite by retweeting with #everydayfix before 46 April; the winning product will be launched on Kickstarter and developed further. Several additional ideas—like a parking space tracker and a phone message relay app—did not make the final shortlist.

Vera Baird, Northumbria’s Police and Crime Commissioner, allocated over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria—a charity she co-directs with Chief Constable Sue Sim—prompting a Ministry of Justice probe into potential conflict of interest. Critics, including MP Keith Vaz, labeled the arrangement “totally inappropriate,” calling it a “soap opera.” Baird defended her decision, stating that all ministry protocols were followed. Meanwhile, Sim, who previously faced bullying allegations and is scheduled to retire in June, is also under scrutiny for her role at the charity. The Ministry of Justice can halt funding if it determines conflict-of-interest rules were violated.

Three people—all in their teens or early 20s—brutally assaulted and tattooed a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, in the basement of Corry “Corey” Campbell’s mother’s house in northeast Philadelphia. Believing Valecce had injured his cat and stolen from him, Campbell led the attack, with accomplices Sandra Ng and Carl Halin also participating. Over roughly 42 hours, they beat Valecce, tied him to a chair, and tattooed offensive images and slurs on his body. Valecce escaped, and the perpetrators were charged with aggravated assault and related offenses. Campbell and Halin were each sentenced to 20 years in prison, Ng received 23 months, and two others, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, await sentencing or trial.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign Memphis Depay, the 21-year-old winger who worked under Louis van Gaal during the Netherlands’ third-place finish at the 2014 World Cup. Tottenham’s earlier £15 million bid was rejected last summer, and clubs such as Paris Saint-Germain are also interested. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games this season, helping PSV win their first Dutch title in seven years. Renowned for his pace, dribbling, and powerful shooting, Depay has been compared to Arjen Robben and even a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Despite occasional flaws in decision-making, he is regarded as a player with the potential to reach the very highest level.

Chelsea earned a 3-1 advantage in the Youth Cup final in Manchester thanks to Tammy Abraham’s two volleys and a late Dominic Solanke strike, with Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scoring City’s lone goal. Both sides showcased promising talent: City defenders Adarabioyo and Humphreys-Grant were strong, while kean Bryan and Brandon Barker had notable moments despite failing to finish. Chelsea’s defense (Clarke-Salter, Tomori, Aina, Dasilva) was mostly in control, and midfielders Sammut and Colkett did well at protecting the back and driving play forward. Abraham’s brace and Solanke’s powerful play ultimately sealed a commanding lead to take back to West London.

Marco Rubio, who recently announced his presidential candidacy, contends that sexual orientation is innate but does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right. He insists states, rather than courts, should regulate marriage and maintain the traditional definition of one man and one woman. Despite this stance, Rubio says he would attend the same-sex wedding of someone he cares about, explaining that he would not stop loving someone over a decision he disagrees with. He also notes that as a Catholic, he opposes divorce yet would still care for someone who divorced. Rubio has already secured substantial financial commitments for his campaign.

Spanish cyclist Pablo (27) and Latvian cyclist Ilze (31) quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to travel around the world by bicycle, with no fixed plans or agenda. Over the course of one year, they have pedaled nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on under three euros per day by camping, using Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and relying on the kindness of strangers. Most of their budget goes toward simple food such as pasta, rice, fresh produce, and occasional shared meals or foraged items. Having crossed Europe into Asia, they plan to continue riding across continents, embracing an open-ended journey to explore the planet one pedal at a time.

Mike Brown, England’s full-back, is taking a cautious approach to concussion recovery after feeling lingering symptoms following the match against France. Having experienced a knockout during the Six Nations against Italy, Brown is determined to avoid a lengthy layoff like other players have suffered, and he is undergoing gradual “stage by stage” assessments before returning to action. Increased awareness of concussion symptoms—gained through online courses—prompted Brown to pull out of previous matches and prioritize safety, illustrating a growing emphasis on concussion protocols in rugby.

Research by Professor David Spiegelhalter at Cambridge University indicates that the frequency of sex among heterosexual couples in Britain has declined from five times a month in 1990, to four in 2000, and three now. One proposed reason is that as smartphones and the internet have become more integrated into daily life, people spend more time checking emails and staying connected. This continual connectivity erodes the separation between work and home, squeezing out the “quiet empty time” that used to be spent with partners. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British national survey, adds that late-night work demands further push sex down the list of priorities.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once prized as symbols of status and fetching prices up to £1.2 million, have seen their value collapse in China. The government’s anti-corruption crackdown and bans on large dogs in major cities contributed to the decline. As a result, many Mastiffs have been abandoned or sold to slaughterhouses, where they are used for meat and leather. Animal-welfare workers have uncovered harrowing conditions for some of these dogs during rescue operations. Overbreeding and cross-breeding for profit have further diminished the dogs’ quality, while the rapid pace of urbanization has made people realize that these large animals are ill-suited to city living.

Direct Line ran an #everydayfix competition, asking groups at MakerVersity to design solutions for common “everyday emergencies.” From a survey of 2,000 people, the top-rated emergency was not being able to sleep, inspiring “Snooze” by Instruments: an alarm clock that connects with your phone and silences its notifications for better rest. Another product, “Forget Me Lock” by Onn Studio, attaches to a key and shows in red or green whether the door is locked. “Nipper,” created by Impulse, is a tiny phone charger powered by any household battery. Voters can retweet their favorite design with #everydayfix, and the most popular prototype will be developed through a Kickstarter campaign. Other ideas that did not make the shortlist include a “parking pin’’ to reserve spaces, a relay app to pass on messages if a phone dies, and a helmet with built-in navigation.

The passage states that a 2009 convention hosted over 512 guests and musical performers, including well-known figures such as Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
