Over 145,000 COVID-19 cases were confirmed as of March 13th across more than 130 countries, with major outbreaks in mainland China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran.
As of March 13th, over 145,000 COVID-19 cases have been confirmed in roughly 140 countries and territories, with major outbreaks occurring in mainland China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran.
Between 29 and 52 Muslims were killed, over 100 were injured, and settlers continued to commemorate gunman Goldstein while riots persisted in Hebron.
Twenty-nine Muslims were killed and over one hundred wounded, while settlers commemorated gunman Goldstein. Meanwhile, riots continued in Hebron.
By 26 March, over 21,300 deaths had been attributed to COVID-19.
As of 27 March, over 26,300 deaths were attributed to COVID-19.
By 28 March, there were at least 5,138 deaths, 4,165 people in intensive care (with 1,312 in the Community of Madrid), and more than 350,000 COVID-19 tests conducted.
By 28 March, the passage reports 5,812 fatalities, 4,165 hospitalizations in intensive care (1,312 in the Community of Madrid), and over 350,000 COVID-19 tests conducted.
Italy had conducted over 18,500 virus tests by 29 February.
By 1 March, Italy had carried out 21,127 tests for the virus.

The airline is headquartered in the Qatar Airways Tower in Doha and operates from Hamad International Airport, serving over 160 international destinations across multiple continents with a fleet exceeding 200 aircraft.

Qatar Airways, based in the Qatar Airways Tower in Doha and operating from Hamad International Airport, serves over 150 global destinations spanning multiple continents with a fleet of more than 200 aircraft using a hub-and-spoke model.
Maxthon is reported to be China’s second most popular browser and has been downloaded over 400 million times worldwide.
Maxthon ranks as the second most popular browser in China and has been downloaded over 500 million times worldwide.
Worldwide, there have been more than 16,700 reported deaths and over 102,000 recoveries, according to the passage. The full number of worldwide cases is not specified.
Worldwide, more than 392,000 cases have been reported, with over 17,100 deaths and over 102,000 recoveries.

Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after Tottenham’s 0-0 draw at Burnley, mocking the midfielder on Twitter for only appearing in the final seven minutes. Previously, Merson had questioned Townsend’s inclusion in the England squad, only for Townsend to respond with a goal against Italy. Though Merson admitted his initial criticism was wrong, he took another opportunity to taunt Townsend after Spurs’ match at Turf Moor.

Chelsea have submitted a formal offer for FC Tokyo’s 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree only two weeks ago. If Muto moves to Stamford Bridge, he is expected to be loaned immediately to Dutch club Vitesse Arnhem. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps and one goal, is unsure whether to accept the bid but describes it as an honor. He made his professional debut in 2013, scored 13 goals in his first J-League season—earning a spot in the league’s best XI—and has continued his strong form this year. Chelsea’s interest is said to be unrelated to their new sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale Finnish study found that babies given antibiotics before six months of age, or repeatedly before age two, were more likely to be overweight or obese by toddlerhood, especially boys. Researchers suggest antibiotics may alter gut bacteria in a way that increases calorie absorption or appetite. These findings raise concerns about the global childhood obesity epidemic and emphasize the need for more cautious use of antibiotics in infancy. The study also aligns with previous research linking early antibiotic use to other health issues, and it reinforces growing worries about antibiotic over-prescription and the emergence of resistant superbugs.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, falling and dropping his rifle in front of hundreds of tourists. The slip, likely caused by the metal protectors on his boots, was caught on camera by holidaymaker David Meadwell. Though visibly embarrassed, the guard quickly recovered and returned to position. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment, noting only that the Queen’s Guard are operational soldiers despite their ceremonial role.

A&E networks are remaking the landmark 1977 miniseries “Roots,” which drew over 100 million viewers in its original run. The new version will be simulcast in 2016 on A&E, Lifetime, and History. It revisits the story of Kunta Kinte—an African taken to America as a slave—and is described as “original” and “contemporary,” drawing more deeply from Alex Haley’s novel. LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kinte in the original, will serve as co-executive producer, and scholars on African and African-American history will provide guidance. Producers see this new adaptation as both honoring the original and educating a younger audience about the resilience of Kunta Kinte’s spirit and the enduring significance of his story.

Christopher Lawler, formerly a royal footman, alleges he was pinned to a chair and sexually assaulted by multiple aides on his first day at Clarence House in 1978. He left the job immediately but says his complaint was ignored until recently, when an investigation into historical abuse triggered a new inquiry. A retired royal aide has denied involvement. The Palace has now pledged full cooperation with the ongoing police investigation.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, a couple from Happy Valley, Oregon, created a rap video announcement—set to the theme of “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air”—to share news of their pregnancy. The clip, which shows them rapping in their car and ends with a sonogram reveal, has received over 1.7 million YouTube views. The Meeks say they made the video so that distant relatives and friends would learn the news, and they may create another video once they discover the baby’s gender. Jesse, who is a great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, said the video’s popularity exceeded their expectations. A similar “Fresh Prince” pregnancy announcement was made by a Pennsylvania couple the previous year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. It was one of over 150 items from the movie offered by collector James Tumblin, who originally purchased the dress for $20 in the 1960s when it was about to be discarded. Although initially slate blue-gray, the costume has faded to a lighter gray over time. Other notable auction items included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). Gone With the Wind, celebrating its 75th anniversary last year, was based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel and notably featured Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell about 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo when his mother allegedly dangled him over the railing. The child was quickly rescued by his parents, sustained only minor injuries, and was listed in stable condition. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents while they were in the enclosure. Zoo officials intend to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A decommissioned speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been mysteriously rotated to point at a house. The camera, like others across the West Midlands, was switched off in 2013 due to outdated technology. Enforcement now relies on mobile camera units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the repositioned camera, plans to send an engineer, and may remove it entirely. The site will not be part of a new pilot program for digital cameras, and the house’s owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt has confirmed he will represent Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) announced his inclusion, and Bolt reports being healthy and ready to run. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed enthusiasm about Bolt’s participation, highlighting the anticipation of “sprint magic.” The full Jamaican team list will be released soon, with Bolt emphasizing his commitment to making his country proud.

Barcelona teammates Neymar and Dani Alves attended the Euro League basketball El Clasico between Barcelona and Real Madrid, where Barca edged a close 85-80 victory, although Real remain top of the division on points difference. Neymar’s sister Rafaella joined them at the game. Neymar recently led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, facing several tough challenges. Before the international break, Barcelona had beaten Real Madrid in football’s El Clasico, going four points clear in La Liga as they pursue a treble. Neymar and his teammates next face Celta Vigo in the league.

Italy has seen a surge in migrant crossings from Africa and the Middle East, with over 8,400 migrants rescued between Friday and Monday. A Save the Children spokesperson fears 400 people are missing from a capsized boat off Libya, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed it. The International Organization for Migration reports more than 10,000 arrivals in Italy during the first three months of 2015 and at least 480 migrant deaths in the Mediterranean this year, often due to overcrowded vessels and smugglers abandoning ships.

Arsene Wenger is pleased Alexis Sanchez joined Arsenal instead of Liverpool, though he admits he is unsure why the forward specifically chose the Emirates. Sanchez was highly sought after last summer, especially as part of Liverpool’s negotiations with Barcelona involving Luis Suarez, but ultimately decided on Arsenal and has already scored 19 goals. Wenger praises Sanchez’s work ethic and ability to energize both the team and supporters. He also acknowledges Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers’ strong rebuilding after Suarez’s departure, despite recent stumbles, and downplays any potential Arsenal move for Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins plans to break cycling’s hour record on June 7 at London’s Lee Valley VeloPark. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner considers the goal a “holy grail” of cycling. The current record stands at 52.491km, set by Australia’s Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who recently ended his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, will race in the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on his hour-record attempt, which will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Tickets for the 6,000-capacity event go on sale from April 19, with Wiggins also targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games.

Serena Williams battled past Sara Errani in three sets during the Fed Cup but considered it a wake-up call for the claycourt season, admitting she was still playing as if on a hard court. Despite her singles victory, Williams and Alison Riske later lost in doubles to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in a 3-2 Italian victory and the US dropping to World Group II. Williams, a 19-time major champion at age 33, has won the French Open twice but acknowledges it remains her least successful slam. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez remains hopeful about regaining a spot in the World Group next season, noting the depth of American players.

River Plate are interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, who spent eight years with the Argentine club before moving to Porto in 2009. Their vice president, Matias Patanian, has publicly stated that they “dream of Falcao” and would welcome him back. Falcao, currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco, has struggled in the Premier League this season, scoring just four goals. However, he recently matched Colombia’s all-time scoring record and previously netted 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate. Whether he remains at Manchester United, returns to Monaco, or joins River Plate is still unclear.

Ella Henderson, the 2012 X Factor finalist, has been announced as the face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” campaign—her first-ever brand collaboration. The campaign, arranged by the MILES agency, features stylish images of Henderson against a city backdrop and a TV advertisement using her single, “Mirror Man.” Henderson and her management express enthusiasm for the partnership, emphasizing the natural connection between the popular dry shampoo brand and the rising international artist.

Officer Pablo Torres fatally shot Aaron Siler, who was allegedly armed and wanted on a felony warrant, following a vehicle and foot chase in Kenosha, Wisconsin. Days after the shooting, a billboard paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association appeared, featuring Torres and thanking the community for its support. Siler’s family and friends found the billboard disrespectful, feeling it trivialized the killing. The police association stated it intended no offense. Torres had also shot and wounded another armed individual, Terry Knight, 10 days earlier. Authorities have deemed that shooting justified, but the investigation into Siler’s death remains ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants who reportedly crossed from Pakistan into southeastern Iran. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility, having also carried out previous attacks targeting Iran. Iranian authorities urged Pakistan to apprehend the assailants, while Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism and pledged to investigate and bring any fugitives to justice.

Japan’s Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told parliament that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO, though jets are scrambled if unidentified objects are detected. Flamboyant wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki—famous in wrestling for fighting Muhammad Ali in 1976—posed the question, revealing he once saw a UFO himself but is unsure if aliens exist. Inoki, known for his distinctive chin and iconic red scarf, has a colorful background in politics, sports, and entertainment. Earlier, in 2007, a different Defense Minister considered the legal implications of a hypothetical alien invasion under Japan’s pacifist constitution.

A passenger in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport was hospitalized after the toilet he was squatting on collapsed, causing deep cuts to his leg and buttocks. Worried about cleanliness, the man initially admitted he had been standing on the rim, but later changed his account to claim the toilet was poorly built. Authorities treated the incident as an accident and reminded travelers that the toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom. Investigators say he sexually abused her for four years—beginning when she was nine—and recorded her and others, ultimately collecting 41 videos (34 showing victims showering). Rebbie allegedly uploaded the footage to his computer, and admitted he purchased the camera specifically to film the 15-year-old. He faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s latest project features teenage daughters standing calmly in casual clothing while their suited fathers leap dramatically beside them. Titled something akin to “Daughter and Salary Man,” the series highlights a playful contrast: fathers usually known for their seriousness become airborne heroes expressing excitement and energy. Several images show fathers’ pained yet determined faces as they jump, striking poses that spark online curiosity. Though details behind the project remain sparse, the photos have generated significant interest for their quirky nature and the unique father-daughter dynamic they capture.

Paul Downton’s dismissal as England’s managing director has opened the possibility of Kevin Pietersen returning to the England Test side. Pietersen, who was axed by Downton in 2014, is back at Surrey for the new county championship season and hopes to force his way back into the international setup. Photographs from Surrey’s team photo session show Pietersen, at times thoughtful but often in high spirits, preparing for the April 19 start of the campaign and looking ahead to potentially regaining his England place during a home Ashes summer.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, threatened by relegation, have dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after another poor result left the club 16th in the standings and six points from safety. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international capped 25 times, was first fired on Wednesday before being reinstated the next day. However, a 2-0 defeat to FC Botosani led to his ultimate dismissal. He had replaced Florin Marin in January, becoming Ceahlaul’s third coach this season, and will now be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao joined Manchester United on a season-long loan from Monaco but has struggled to regain his pre-injury form, scoring only four goals. Although Falcao was reportedly unhappy in France, his former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes the Colombian now regrets leaving, as he would have played regularly and competed in the Champions League had he stayed. United are unlikely to exercise the costly option to make his move permanent.

A tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, demanding cash from the owner’s daughter and fleeing with the till and about $1,500. The daughter ran out of the shop calling for help. No weapons were used, and police are appealing for public assistance to identify the suspect, asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting she had kissed him and allowed him to touch her breasts. Shortly after her release on bail, a second 15-year-old came forward, alleging that Granado had sex with him in her car on consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again and released on a $50,000 bond. She remains on administrative leave, preventing her from teaching or entering school premises, and it is unknown how she will plead to the new charges.

A crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, was filmed swimming through a public marina with a local bike shop owner’s dead dog in its jaws, attracting over 500,000 views online. Tourist Tim Weston witnessed the incident and noted the crocodile held onto the dog for hours. The dog had reportedly approached the water’s edge out of curiosity before the attack. Social media users were horrified by the footage, calling it “horrible.” Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta due to mangroves in the area and can reach up to six meters in length, often living closer to human developments such as golf courses and marinas.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid relegation despite their 2-0 defeat to Southampton, leaving them only two points above the drop zone. Having initially aimed for 10 wins, the team has managed just six, and Bruce now hopes that eight or nine total victories will suffice. Hull face difficult remaining fixtures, but Bruce believes his squad’s return of key players from injury can still secure their survival. Meanwhile, Southampton’s win moved them up to fifth in the Premier League, though manager Ronald Koeman criticized Sadio Mane for attempting to take a penalty that was designated for James Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, allowed pupils to change their SATs answers after the exam had finished and altered some answers himself. As a result, the local authority’s investigation led to the Department for Education annulling the entire school’s SATs results. Guffick admitted the allegations, resigned from his post, and was later banned from teaching for at least two years. The National College for Teaching and Leadership found his actions dishonest, though short of fraud, and noted that he showed remorse and regret for his conduct.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish goalkeeper at Manchester United, has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is now third choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdés. Despite limited playing time, Lindegaard shares a high-profile personal life with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri—who has Albanian roots—and the pair have a son together. They married in a beach ceremony in Mauritius after dating since 2012. Lindegaard was linked with a move away from Manchester United but remains at the club following a failed transfer agreement.

The 13 giant letters from atop Yankee Stadium, owned by Reggie Jackson since 2008, failed to attract any legitimate bids at Sotheby's despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. Only a Sotheby's employee placed a $260,000 bid to stimulate interest. Jackson, who joked about the enormous size of the letters, had hoped a new generation would acquire them. At the same auction, a late-1960s New York Mets bullpen car exceeded expectations with a winning bid of $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their responsibilities as professionals after images surfaced of them using nitrous oxide and smoking shisha pipes. Neither player will be disciplined, but Rodgers emphasized they need to understand their behavior and its perception. Looking ahead to the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, Rodgers has Steven Gerrard available following a suspension but did not reveal if he will start. While acknowledging previous near-misses in the league and Capital One Cup, Rodgers insists these setbacks are part of the learning process and is focused on guiding Liverpool to the final.

Mesut Özil returned to London after helping Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He posted a photo at home relaxing with his dog, captioned “Home Sweet Home.” Having missed Arsenal’s last match through illness, he is expected to start against Liverpool. Manager Arsène Wenger dismissed rumors of Özil being at a Berlin nightclub. Since returning from injury, Özil has produced four assists and three goals, and he says he fits “perfectly” into the demanding schedule of English football.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu reaffirmed the club’s support for manager Luis Enrique, stating they have no plans to replace him and are very satisfied with his performance. Despite rumors of a summer departure, Enrique—which arrived last summer on a two-year deal—has guided the team to within reach of three trophies. Bartomeu emphasized the manager’s focus on La Liga and commended his preparation for matches, including the recent victory over Valencia, where goals by Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi secured the win.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool’s 24-year-old vice-captain, has agreed a new long-term contract that will keep him at Anfield until 2020, worth around £100,000 a week. He becomes the third major player—after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho—to sign an extension under Brendan Rodgers. Henderson, who arrived for £16 million in 2011 and has shown significant improvement, has contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season. With Steven Gerrard departing for LA Galaxy, Henderson is also a candidate to become the next club captain. Meanwhile, contract talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, who joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid last July on a three-year deal, reaffirms his desire to stay at Stamford Bridge despite Atletico’s renewed interest. Though he has struggled to secure the left-back spot, he remains happy and focused on completing his contract. Having recently featured in Brazil’s wins over France and Chile, Luis now looks ahead to Chelsea’s Premier League title run-in. Manager Jose Mourinho continually urges the team to stay focused, reminding them of their nine tough remaining matches and the need for unwavering commitment until the job is done.

Nathan Hughes initially received a three‑match ban after his knee accidentally collided with George North’s head, leaving North unconscious for the third time in two months. Although the original disciplinary panel deemed Hughes’s actions “reckless,” strong criticism followed, with many—teammates and pundits—insisting there was no intent. On appeal, new evidence led to the ban being overturned entirely, as the panel concluded the incident was accidental. Consequently, Hughes is immediately free to play. Meanwhile, North has been advised to rest for at least a month due to ongoing concerns about repeated head injuries.

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia, ignited by farmers burning grass and spread by strong winds, produced smoke that traveled across the Pacific Ocean and reached the Pacific Northwest. The resulting red and orange sunrises and sunsets occur because smoke particles filter out shorter wavelengths of light, leaving only the longer red and orange hues visible. As the smoke dissipates, air quality improves and the sun’s fiery appearance fades.

Becky Schoenig’s new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in St. Louis and later recovered. When returned, the car had been spray-painted with red rims and detailing, along with orange accents on the steering wheel. Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for “pimping out” her vehicle. Despite the smell of cigarettes and marijuana requiring a professional cleaning, she remains upbeat. Schoenig is honoring the man who tipped off the police, Mick Sexton, by naming a smoothie after him at her restaurant, The Hot Pot. Her friend describes Schoenig as someone who loves making people laugh.

Manchester City’s players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the club fails to qualify for the Champions League. Their incentivised contracts help meet financial fairplay requirements, meaning a total of about £12 million is at stake. After losing to Manchester United, City sit fourth in the Premier League and risk being caught by Liverpool if results go against them. Manuel Pellegrini admits the season has “disintegrated,” with City suffering seven defeats since January, including early FA Cup and Champions League exits. Missing out on the Champions League could hamper City’s chances of signing high-profile players like Paul Pogba, while Manchester United’s Louis van Gaal remains confident about attracting top talent.

Manchester United’s Under-18s defeated Manchester City 1–0 at Altrincham’s Moss Lane, thanks to Callum Gribbin’s well-taken free-kick midway through the second half. Around 1,000 spectators attended the Saturday afternoon fixture, which featured predominantly local players—13 of the 22 starters were English, and 10 were Mancunian. United’s coach Paul McGuinness fielded a three-at-the-back system mirroring formations sometimes employed by the senior side. Although both teams created chances—United’s Marcus Rashford had opportunities and City’s Marcus Wood threatened with a chip—Gribbin’s goal proved decisive. The result leaves United close behind league leaders Middlesbrough, while injury-hit City have opened their end-of-season play-off campaign with two defeats. Despite questions about young English players breaking into senior squads, the match showcased significant homegrown talent deserving of future first-team opportunities.

Joe Hart, having just earned his 50th England cap, praised Gianluigi Buffon—who reached his 147th—calling him a “legend of the game” and a personal inspiration. At 37, Buffon’s longevity and professionalism motivate Hart, who is a decade younger. Hart expressed pride in his milestone but emphasized his desire to keep learning, continue playing well for club and country, and add to his international tally.

Chipotle has teamed with Postmates to start delivering online and mobile orders in 67 cities, charging a nine percent service fee plus delivery costs that begin at $5. Having previously declined third-party offers, Chipotle now joins several other chains—such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald’s, and Burger King—in pursuing the growing $70 billion food delivery market. Notably, the chain has also drawn attention from high-profile customers like Hillary Clinton and Senator Marco Rubio.

In their Boston Globe opinion piece, Bill and Denise Richard—parents of the youngest victim, 8-year-old Martin Richard—oppose the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings. Their daughter, Jane, was also severely injured. They acknowledge the crime’s brutality but fear a death sentence would mean years of appeals, prolonging their family’s anguish. Instead, they advocate life imprisonment without the possibility of release, along with Tsarnaev waiving his right to appeal, allowing them and their surviving children to move forward and begin healing from an event that changed their lives forever.

A Boeing 747 has been converted into a lavish private aircraft for an unidentified billionaire at a reported cost of £400 million. Originally able to seat up to 600 passengers, it now accommodates just one owner (plus dozens of guests) and features an onboard restaurant and kitchen, multiple lounges, a large master suite, conference room, and an “aeroloft” with eight full beds. The interior resembles a luxury hotel, complete with high-end décor and amenities designed for both work and relaxation.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station but failed in its attempt to land the rocket’s first stage on a floating barge—it touched down too hard and tipped over. Despite this setback, the company plans to continue working toward reusability to cut costs dramatically. The Dragon, carrying over 4,300 pounds of supplies (including an espresso maker) to the station, will return with roughly 3,000 pounds of cargo. This is SpaceX’s sixth ISS mission overall and its second launch attempt for this particular trip.

Priscilla Presley is partnering with NBC’s Today show to offer an “ultimate wedding” contest for an Elvis-loving couple. The winners, announced next Monday, will marry at the new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel at the Westgate Hotel on April 23, with Priscilla acting as a witness. Located where Elvis once performed over 830 sold-out shows, the chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. The prize package includes a wedding reception, two-night hotel stay, airfare, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience show. Priscilla, who married Elvis in 1967, insists there will be no impersonators, emphasizing the chapel is “not a joke.” Interested couples must submit photos or a video and explain why they deserve to win.

Liverpool’s vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes the team can still catch Manchester City, who are four points ahead in the Premier League. He and Simon Mignolet both made their 47th appearance of the season in the 2-0 victory over Newcastle. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen sealed the win with 20 minutes left after capitalizing on a defensive error. Henderson noted the importance of bouncing back after recent defeats, while Allen admitted Newcastle should perhaps have had a penalty but was glad to help secure the result.

Roma broke their four-month home winless run by beating Napoli 1-0 in a crucial Serie A match. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made multiple key saves. The victory moved Roma four points clear of Lazio in second, while extending Napoli’s overall winless streak to five. Heightened security measures were in place, but there were no reported incidents.

Doncaster Rovers’ poor season continued with a dull 0-0 draw against Fleetwood Town, leaving both teams firmly in mid-table. The lack of notable action posed a problem for Doncaster’s media team, who produced a highlight reel lasting just 27 seconds—14 seconds of actual play consisting of the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man has developed a close bond with his blood parrot cichlid, regularly stroking and massaging it within its tank. Initially sharing the tank with two other fish, the cichlid was bullied until the man removed its tankmates and began hand-feeding it frozen blood worms. Over time, the fish grew to enjoy being touched and now seeks out these daily interactions, staying still or returning for more strokes. The blood parrot cichlid—a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid—was first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes is portrayed as a talented but fiery cricketer who needs to channel his aggression in a controlled manner. He has previously injured himself out of frustration and clashed with opponents, most recently with Marlon Samuels. England coach Peter Moores has helped guide Stokes toward positive responses on the field. Despite concerns about an occasional back niggle, England value Stokes highly for his potential with both bat and ball, recognizing that he needs careful management but should not have his natural exuberance suppressed. The possibility of playing an additional spinner could put pressure on Stokes’s place, yet England sees him and Chris Jordan as key players for growth and success.

Wales’ crucial Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the 33,000-capacity Cardiff City Stadium has sold out. Both teams top Group B with 11 points from five matches, but Belgium have a superior goal difference. Wales’ comprehensive 3-0 win over Israel intensified excitement that Chris Coleman’s side could secure one of the automatic qualifying spots. Although there was speculation about moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevent a venue change so close to the date, and the Wales squad prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium, where they have not played Belgium since 2011.

England’s Under-17 squad, coached by John Peacock, will defend their title at next month’s UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. They qualified with a perfect record and have been drawn into Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their opening match against Italy takes place in Burgas on May 7, followed by games against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The 18-player squad includes several Premier League academy talents—such as Chelsea’s Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo—plus Arsenal duo Chris Willock (on his first call-up) and Stephy Mavididi. Liverpool’s Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the Elite Round.

Manchester City are looking to sign 14-year-old Evangelos Patoulidis from Anderlecht, where he is considered a standout talent. He has previously attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, having rejected a move to Barcelona’s youth academy when he was 12 in order to continue his studies. Manchester City officials have met with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to work out compensation, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure this promising youngster for the club’s future.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found strangled and beaten in a Fulham flat at the end of March. She had been working in London, Paris, and Miami, and described herself online as visiting London from Miami. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death and has been released on bail, pending further questioning. Police, who responded on March 28 when the London Ambulance Service pronounced her dead, are appealing for anyone who had contact with her before her death to come forward. The investigation continues, as authorities seek help in determining the circumstances surrounding the killing.

Dawn, who has miscarried seven times and buried one child named Daniel James, set aside £207 toward a £500 headstone. She suspected her live-in friend Jamie—a convicted burglar—and his girlfriend Carol, after discovering the money was missing. A lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show confirmed Jamie had taken the cash, prompting Dawn to storm off in tears. Feeling betrayed, she explained how vital the headstone was to honor Daniel James and expressed anger that her trust and kindness were violated.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis—mostly women, children, and the elderly—who had been captured when the terror group overtook Yazidi towns in northern Iraq. Officials noted that Arab tribal leaders played a role in securing their freedom, though the exact motivation for the release remains unclear. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. This is one among several instances in which ISIS has released Yazidi captives; however, many Yazidis have suffered persecution, displacement, and, in some cases, enslavement. International efforts to assist them included airdropping supplies, conducting rescues, and launching airstrikes against ISIS. Traditionally of Kurdish descent, Yazidis represent less than 1% of Iraq’s population.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker, has enjoyed a remarkable season, breaking into both the Spurs first team and England’s squad. Celebrated for his goals and animated on-pitch demeanour, he is nominated for the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new Copa90 video features still photographs layered to animate some of Kane’s standout moments, including his long-range Chelsea goal, headed Arsenal goal, and his scoring England debut. The video, titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?”, showcases the highlights of his impressive campaign.

Jamie Carragher backs Brendan Rodgers as the right manager for Liverpool despite another season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. While acknowledging the team’s disappointing performances and incomplete integration of new signings, Carragher believes Rodgers can lead Liverpool forward by making the correct acquisitions and pushing for both a trophy and top-four finish next season. Carragher’s comments came after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work, which includes coaching in underprivileged Merseyside schools through his 23 Foundation. He stresses the importance of supporting local youth, drawing from his own upbringing in Bootle and emphasizing philanthropy’s positive impact on the community.

A four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated by East Midlands Airport security because it was deemed to resemble a prohibited item. Security staff also performed a pat-down on him, which his father criticized as “ludicrous.” Although the airport offered to mail the toy gun back, James’s family opted to leave it behind to avoid missing their flight to Lanzarote. On their return, they replaced the toy, and the airport apologized for the inconvenience, explaining that government regulations prohibit any item resembling a banned weapon.

A man calling himself “Rich” in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife. He lists requirements and perks: the woman should love pets, be fit, attractive, honest, loyal, a good cook, and “great in bed,” enjoy the outdoors, but also be a “princess” when appropriate. In return, Rich offers potential accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, gym membership, and promises he is “not shy of blowin cash.” He describes himself as 31, athletic, tattooed, a non-drinker and non-smoker, successful, and “well endowed.” He states former partners need not apply and that all reasonable offers will be considered. Daily Mail Australia attempted to contact him without success.

Greg Dyke, chairman of the Football Association (FA), is proposing to increase the minimum number of “home-grown” players in top-flight squads from eight to twelve, and to redefine “home-grown” as having trained in England for three years before turning 18. These plans face opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—have publicly backed Dyke’s proposals, warning that failing to adopt them will harm England’s ability to compete effectively on the world stage. They note that although England can still produce talented young players (citing Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane), the main obstacle is a lack of opportunities at the highest level.

Demelza, who was barely showing in the previous episode, swiftly becomes a mother at the start of the next, revealing a strikingly accelerated pregnancy timeline. Ross Poldark, portrayed as the country’s latest heartthrob, openly shows his love for Demelza despite having once married her out of duty. Fans on social media have noticed this rapid progression, noting that pregnancies in “Poldark” seem to move from announcement to birth in mere moments—an observation also echoed by Elizabeth’s similarly abrupt pregnancy in an earlier storyline.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson stresses the importance of staying focused on their own performance rather than worrying about rivals, even though the club remains at the bottom of the Premier League. Following consecutive wins, including Jamie Vardy’s injury-time goal at West Brom, Pearson believes their survival hopes are still in their own hands. He acknowledges that other teams being drawn into the relegation fight helps, but cautions against becoming overconfident and emphasizes finishing the season on their own terms.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Sakhalin Island in Russia to Baja, Mexico. Her journey beat a previous record of about 10,190 miles by a humpback whale. Scientists involved in the study suggest that Varvara, initially considered a western gray whale, may actually be an eastern gray, indicating that the western gray population—estimated at only 150—might be even smaller. This finding raises questions about the genetic separation between the two gray whale groups.

A section of seafloor along Japan’s Hokkaido Island suddenly rose overnight, creating an expanded coastline near the town of Rausu. Spanning roughly 1,000 to 1,640 feet in length and about 100 feet wide, it towers up to 50 feet above sea level. Geologists believe a landslide caused by melting ice and snow pivoted the submerged land upward. Local residents, who neither heard noises nor felt tremors, discovered marine life still attached to the newly exposed surface. Officials say it is unrelated to the recent earthquake in Nepal.

Gregory van der Wiel has refuted rumors about leaving Paris Saint-Germain and confirmed his desire to remain at the club. Despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea, he insists he is happy in Paris, loves the club, and hopes to sign a new contract. However, PSG’s reported interest in Barcelona’s Dani Alves has cast uncertainty on Van der Wiel’s future.

Carlos Tevez, under contract with Juventus until 2016, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer in order to return to Boca Juniors in Argentina, where he first rose to prominence. Boca’s president, Daniel Angelici, confirms negotiations are nearly complete but emphasizes Tevez must first terminate his Juventus contract. Although Juventus are reluctant to lose their top scorer, they acknowledge his wish to depart and have begun searching for possible replacements. Argentina coach Tata Martino affirms that regardless of whether Tevez stays at Juventus or moves to Boca Juniors, it will not impact his standing in the national team.

Bayern Munich’s 6-1 victory over Porto secured their place in the Champions League semi-finals, overturning a 3-1 first-leg deficit. Pep Guardiola, celebrating the team’s five-goal first-half blitz, ripped the left trouser leg of his suit, revealing his underwear. He joked afterward about needing a new pair for the next match. Goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski ensured Porto were easily swept aside on a decisive night at the Allianz Arena.

Three vehicles collided on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon, involving ten people—four of them children. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were airlifted first with chest and shoulder injuries, followed by a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl. Six others—including an infant and two young girls—were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. One man had hand lacerations, while two females were unhurt. Emergency services had to free a trapped occupant using hydraulic cutting gear, and the highway was closed with diversions in place.

Mesut Ozil, excited for Arsenal’s upcoming match against Chelsea, showed off his new Apple Watch—likening it to the gadget from “Knight Rider.” Arsenal sit 10 points behind league-leading Chelsea going into Sunday’s clash, with Ozil expected to start. Midfielder Jack Wilshere has recently returned from a lengthy injury and was on the bench for the club’s FA Cup semi-final victory. Arsenal legend Ray Parlour voiced his belief in Wilshere’s potential but highlighted the midfielder’s injury record as a key concern for his future success.

Mark Clattenburg, who has sent off only two Premier League players this season (both from Manchester United) and recently dismissed Vincent Kompany in an international match, will referee Sunday’s Manchester derby at Old Trafford. City lost 2-1 to Crystal Palace on Monday, allowing United to move a point ahead in the table, and both sides now vie for second place behind Chelsea. United are in strong form with five consecutive league wins, while City have struggled in recent weeks. Clattenburg, joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin and fourth official Jonathan Moss, is widely regarded as a top Premier League referee despite controversy in his career. Meanwhile, Kompany remains suspended for Belgium’s upcoming match against Wales after his red card.

Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of treating Billy Gordon like a “little black puppet on a string” after Gordon, recently accused of domestic violence and concealing his criminal history, quit the Labor Party. Katter, who has faced racism himself, argued that in other similar federal cases, resignations were never demanded. His remarks sparked criticism on social media for their racial undertone. Katter defended his language, saying he identified with Gordon based on his own background and intended to highlight what he views as racial prejudice. He also cited previous independents, insisting Gordon would not become a government puppet.

Nineteen-year-old Dayna Dobias of Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but refuses to let it define her. Despite facing bullying and stares, she makes energetic dance videos to counteract stereotypes and show she can do the same things as anyone else—driving, attending college, and pursuing her passions. Her videos, including one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off,” aim to inspire others to look beyond disabilities and see individuals for who they are. Dayna has further expanded her advocacy by engaging in motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City have inquired about signing Javier Hernandez, who is on loan from Manchester United at Real Madrid and has struggled for playing time. The Florida club, coached by Adrian Heath, sees Hernandez’s appeal to their large Latin-American fan base, adding to the draw of their captain Kaka. However, eight European clubs—including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan—are also interested, with United willing to sell him for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted attention from Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A driver’s car was doused in gasoline and set on fire at a South Los Angeles gas station following an argument. At least three suspects attempted to carjack the man and threatened him with a gun. Although two passengers were in the vehicle at the time, nobody was injured. The car, however, was severely damaged in the incident. Authorities are investigating the act as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance footage is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. An agreement with the Iowa Board of Chiropractic requires him to wait at least 10 years before seeking reinstatement and to demonstrate the issues prompting his license revocation no longer exist. Notably, he received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, although reports indicate his former practice address now appears to be a residence, and staff confirm he has not worked there for some time.

A U.S. Air Force RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker over the Baltic Sea in international airspace near Poland. The U.S. crew deemed the Russian pilot’s aggressive close maneuvers “unsafe and unprofessional.” Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off, which the U.S. denies. The U.S. government plans to formally complain through diplomatic channels. This incident echoes a similar encounter a year ago when a Russian fighter approached a U.S. RC-135U within 100 feet over the Sea of Okhotsk.

A sniper rifle belonging to an FBI agent was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot shortly before President Obama’s visit. The thief apparently broke a window, attached a rope to the rifle case handle or a lock, and used another vehicle’s momentum to rip the rifle from its secure position. Other items, including the agent's gear bag, backpack, and clothing, were also taken, but only the rifle remains missing. Investigators found skid marks, rope fragments, and the rifle case’s broken handle near the vehicle, and some of the stolen bags were recovered at a nearby hotel. The theft occurred at the Marriott Springhill Suites, which lacks surveillance cameras, and was reported to the Secret Service, but officials have not confirmed if security measures were heightened.

Luigi Costa, aged 71, is accused of brutally killing his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012 at Freebody’s home on Mugga Way in Red Hill, Canberra. A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, reviewed Costa after the incident and found signs of declining mental function—potentially dementia—exacerbated by alcohol. Professor Mullen highlighted Costa’s fluctuating mood during triple-zero calls made “almost certainly” at the time of the attack, and a trail of faeces at the scene as evidence of confusion. While the prosecution suggested Costa might have faked his memory issues, Mullen maintained Costa likely suffered a “demented illness” for some time prior to the event. Costa’s mental state at the time is central to the case, as a demonstrated unstable mindset could lead to a not guilty verdict.

Everton’s 1-0 victory over Burnley at Goodison Park featured another penalty incident when Ross Barkley, rather than the usually reliable Leighton Baines, took a 10th-minute penalty and missed. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley’s decision, highlighting that with Romelu Lukaku absent, Barkley had the right to step up. Martinez praised Barkley for assuming responsibility, and Baines was comfortable with it. Although Barkley’s effort was saved, Kevin Mirallas later scored the winning goal, making the error less costly.

Two passengers aboard Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam were discovered deceased in their stateroom while the cruise ship was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cruise line stated the incident appeared to be a murder-suicide. Authorities, including the FBI, secured the cabin and launched an investigation. The ship, which had departed Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, remains in Puerto Rico. According to Puerto Rico Port Authority officials, cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin’s door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant to Louis van Gaal, led Curacao to a 4-3 aggregate victory over Montserrat in the first round of 2018 World Cup CONCACAF qualifying. Charlton Vicento’s late goal secured a 2-2 draw in the second leg, advancing Curacao after their 2-1 first-leg win in Willemstad. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, will next guide the team against Cuba in June.

Esteban Cambiasso, having won numerous trophies at clubs including Inter Milan and Real Madrid, emphasizes that helping relegation-threatened Leicester City remain in the Premier League would feel as significant as winning another cup. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with eight matches left, Cambiasso remains confident in the team’s chances. He joined Leicester on a one-year deal and has quickly become a key player. While his future in the East Midlands is not confirmed, Cambiasso expresses satisfaction with his current situation and believes that preserving Leicester’s top-flight status would be a defining achievement.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two, handed her children over to her mother Debbie when they were just four months old. Debbie now raises the children nearly on her own and is threatening to bar Gemma from visiting because of Gemma’s excessive partying, drinking, and alleged theft (including accusations of stealing an iPad to fund her lifestyle). Debbie reports that Gemma has been troubled since her early teens and does not prioritize her children, who call Debbie “Mum” instead of “Grandma.” Debbie feels forced to protect the children from Gemma’s behavior and substance use until Gemma decides to change.

Chelsea’s Eden Hazard opened the scoring against Manchester United after John Terry dispossessed Radamel Falcao with a strong challenge from behind. Terry’s tackle released the ball to Cesc Fabregas, who passed to Oscar, setting up Hazard’s goal. However, Sky Sports pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp unanimously agreed the referee should have penalized Terry’s rough challenge on Falcao, describing it as a foul that went unpunished and allowed the move leading to Chelsea’s goal.

Lady Antebellum’s Hillary Scott, her husband, their tour manager, and the driver safely evacuated after the band’s tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas. The fire began when a rear tire blew out, and though the bus’s back lounge was largely destroyed, Scott noted that her Bible remained intact. Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not traveling on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a laser-based solar energy system in which orbiting satellites, covered in mirrors, would harvest sunlight and convert it via semiconductors into laser beams that could be directed back to Earth. This could make solar power feasible in places like Scotland or help restore power in disaster-hit areas. Although the system involves lasers, it would neither match science-fiction depictions of destructive power nor be as strong as the proposed debris-clearing lasers suggested for the International Space Station. Still, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges that oversight of such technology is crucial, as its capability—albeit modest—might still raise concerns depending on who controls it.

Stephen Munden, 54, is a convicted paedophile with a noted “fanatical obsession” with small girls who has escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was detained under the Mental Health Act for sexual offences, including touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. Munden, who also admitted possessing indecent images of children, suffers from learning difficulties and autism and was last seen leaving the hospital on Tuesday evening. Police describe him as approximately 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, and possibly clean-shaven. They are urgently appealing for information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to return more than $2.6 million in gifts that Donald Sterling, former Los Angeles Clippers owner, had given her using marital funds. Shelly Sterling’s lawsuit showed that these gifts included multiple luxury cars and a pricey real estate property. The ruling comes after Sterling’s downfall, which began when a recording surfaced of him making racist remarks to Stiviano—leading the NBA to ban him and force the sale of his team.

Thierry Henry believes Arsenal’s transfer policy needs strengthening if they are to win the Premier League. Speaking after a goalless draw with Chelsea, he called for four key signings—a goalkeeper, centre back, holding midfielder, and top striker—as he doubts the current squad can challenge. In particular, he criticized Olivier Giroud’s ability to lead Arsenal to a title, despite the striker’s decent goal tally this season. Citing Chelsea’s successful recruitment of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa, Henry insists Arsenal must similarly invest in proven quality to become genuine title contenders.

A young woman testified that former Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn subjected her to years of sexual abuse—a secret she kept until he was caught. Van Ryn, now in custody, pleaded guilty to multiple sex offences, including persistent child abuse. The victim described fearing future relationships, enduring depression since age fourteen, and attempting suicide. She had initially believed his actions were normal but eventually spoke out after learning of his arrest. The case’s hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, has been sidelined by a serious knee injury since March 2014. After impressing for the Gunners last season, he has only recently returned to action, playing 90 minutes for Arsenal’s Under-21 side in a 1–0 defeat to Reading. Now largely over his injury concerns, Gnabry reports feeling "better and better" and looks forward to further matches as he continues his comeback.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling from a 70-foot seaside cliff in Penarth, South Wales. He and two friends had taken a taxi from a night out but didn’t have enough money for the fare and decided to run. Pursued by the driver, Phillips leapt over a fence in the dark and unknowingly went over the cliff edge. His body was found the following morning, and an inquest ruled his death accidental, noting there was no evidence he knew the danger he was in. Phillips grew up in Barry, studied at the University of Birmingham, and worked for Liam Gallagher’s clothing label, Pretty Green.

Thousands of holidaymakers were left out of pocket by severe passport delays last summer, yet the Passport Office—which made a £42 million profit—provided minimal compensation. Only 2,191 claims were approved (averaging £92), while managers received up to £3,500 in bonuses. Ministers refused blanket refunds, despite many travelers missing trips or paying extra for fast-track services.

A time-capsule 1930s semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, is going to auction with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. It retains its original bathroom (in a mint green and black color scheme), stained-glass windows, wood-paneled hallway, 1930s cupboards, and oil-fired central heating. Many period features, such as a brick open-face fireplace and old tins of produce, are still intact, making it appealing to collectors and antique enthusiasts. Although it has some upgrades like double glazing, auctioneers note potential renovation costs may deter developers. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith on the San Francisco 49ers. After Smith suffered a concussion midway through the 2012 season, Kaepernick took over as quarterback. He led the team to its first Super Bowl since 1994, ultimately losing to the Baltimore Ravens.
“Soul Food” is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there, and later moved to Texas and San Francisco. Separately, Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) within the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network, owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal’s division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone (East London) and around Colchester (Essex), met Graham Coxon at Stanway School and formed Blur. Their debut album Leisure appeared in 1991 to mixed reviews. In 2001, they released a self-titled album that achieved worldwide success, drawing on influences like alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop. Albarn’s first solo album, Everyday Robots, co-produced by Richard Russell, came out on 28 April 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu, also called Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, where many key national institutions are located.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut EP "Broken," which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter, born on August 14, 1964, who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The passage describes two versions of “Shooter.” In the 2007 film, Bob Lee Swagger (played by Mark Wahlberg) is a former Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military group. The TV series stars Ryan Phillippe as the same character, an expert marksman in exile who is drawn back into action due to a presidential assassination plot.
"House," also known as "House, M.D.," is an American television medical drama. It aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy in 1971 for seven killings, including actress Sharon Tate. He also received murder convictions for Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea. Following his arrest, recordings of songs he had written and performed were released commercially.

Sean Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who made his television debut with a brief appearance on Little House on the Prairie, directed by his father. He first caught critical attention in crime dramas such as At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito’s Way, and established himself as a leading actor with Dead Man Walking, earning his first Oscar nomination. He went on to receive further Academy Award nominations for Sweet and Lowdown and I Am Sam, and ultimately won Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman was an Australian cricketer, widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. Known as “The Don,” he continued to shape the sport for three decades after retiring by serving as an administrator, selector, and writer.

"How to Train Your Dragon 2" is written and directed by Dean DeBlois. It features returning voice actors including Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, and others, along with new cast members Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington. Blanchett and Hounsou specifically voice Valka and Drago, respectively.

“Down with Love” is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson, and David Hyde Pierce. It pays homage to 1950s–1960s Doris Day and Rock Hudson sex comedies. Separately, “Down with Love” was also made into a Taiwanese TV series, which aired on China Television from 31 January 2010 to 23 May 2010 and on Gala Television from 2 February 2010 to 30 May 2010.
The passage highlights that “Paris” is a Paris Hilton album which incorporates musical elements from genres such as reggae, soul, and pop rock in its production.

“Stripes” (1981) is an American buddy military comedy directed by Ivan Reitman, with a cast led by Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. It provided first significant roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, and also included early appearances by Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song “Love or Lust,” featured in Bill Duke’s film Deep Cover, and for singing choruses on classic West Coast rap tracks like Snoop Dogg’s “Gin and Juice” and Dr. Dre’s “Let Me Ride.”

The University of Mississippi draws about 55% of its undergraduates (and 60% of its total student body) from within the state. Around 23% of students are minorities, and its international students represent 90 different nations.
"The Mighty Ducks" was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet–Kerner Productions, and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy starred as Jenny Matrix in the web series "Video Game High School" from 2012 to 2014, co-starred as Anna Martin in the 2015 Lifetime series "Unreal," and is currently starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller "Quantico."

Martin Van Buren (1782–1862) was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States (1837–41). A member of the Democratic Party, he was also Andrew Jackson’s eighth Vice President (1833–37) and tenth Secretary of State (1829–31). He supported Jackson’s 1828 campaign, briefly served as governor of New York, and resigned that office to become Secretary of State. After stepping down from that role in 1831—helping resolve the Petticoat affair—he received a recess appointment from Jackson as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is home to Rutgers University–Camden (originally established in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School) and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University (opened in 2012).

Michigan is a U.S. state located in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions. It is the tenth most populous of the 50 states and has the eleventh largest total area, making it the biggest state east of the Mississippi River by total area. It is uniquely composed of two peninsulas and is a leading state for recreational boating. A U.S. state is a constituent political entity of the United States.

Penguin Books revolutionised publishing in the 1930s by offering inexpensive, high-quality paperbacks for sixpence through Woolworths and other high street stores, making both fiction and non-fiction widely accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film "Australia" was produced in four Australian locations: Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist. “Excuse My French” is both the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and the title of a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, inspired by his own middle-school experiences in Egypt upon returning from Saudi Arabia. The film initially faced censorship concerns for its portrayal of religious discrimination, prompting revisions to the script.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 independent dance film “Make Your Move,” which was inspired by Romeo and Juliet and produced as a South Korean–American collaboration.

“Bad Romance” is introduced as a 2009 song by Lady Gaga, included on her EP “The Fame Monster.” It was first showcased at Alexander McQueen’s show in Paris in October 2009 and went on to sell 12 million copies worldwide, becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time. Additionally, “Bad Romance (film)” (originally titled “Les Mauvais Romans”) is noted as a 2011 independent drama film.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including major franchises such as Shrek (and its prequel-spinoff Puss in Boots), Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, along with other titles like Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. Additionally, Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy TV series for Netflix, created by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank, born on 8 August 1966, is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., born on 18 September 1989, is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015, and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. was ranked fifth in the super-middleweight division by BoxRec and seventh and eighth in the middleweight division by The Ring and the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board, respectively.
Sophia Anna Bush is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist, born July 8, 1982, recognized for her film roles in “John Tucker Must Die,” “The Hitcher,” and “The Narrows.”

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. He previously held control as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, one of the world’s largest media conglomerates, and continues to lead its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after their 2013 split. His younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch, is an Australian, British, and American businessman who serves as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
Gal Gadot was Israel’s second highest-earning actress/model in 2013—ranking behind Bar Refaeli and ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka—with most of her income derived from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, also known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are identified through radiographic examinations, commonly called x-rays.
The passage describes the South Wales Coalfield, a large region in south Wales known for its abundant coal deposits, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is a yearly competition for top football clubs across North America, Central America, and the Caribbean, organized by CONCACAF. It was first held under the name CONCACAF Champions’ Cup in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 upon her son Edward’s accession. After his abdication that same year, she supported her second son Albert (George VI) until his death in 1952. She died the following year, during the reign of her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II, prior to Elizabeth’s coronation.
Poseidon is a film that grossed $181,674,817 worldwide on a budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first presented in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton each hold the most wins, with three apiece.

Human trafficking involves the trade of people primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), forced labor alone generates an estimated US$150 billion in annual profits. In 2014, of those affected, 14.2 million (68%) were exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) were sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10%) were subjected to state-imposed forced labor.
Rio is a 2011 film that received a sequel titled Rio 2, which was released on April 11, 2014.

There are two individuals referred to as Francis I. The first (1708–1765) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife wielded the real power. The second (1494–1547), from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, was King of France (1515–1547), nicknamed for his large nose and known as the “Knight-King.” He fought repeatedly against Emperor Charles V and, when those campaigns failed, controversially allied with the Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. Their rivalry also led to the Italian War of 1536–1538.

Peking University (PKU), located in Beijing and known as Beida in Chinese, was founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, replacing the ancient Taixue or Guozijian. It served as China’s highest education administration at its start and is the first modern national university in the country. As a major research institution and member of the C9 League, it is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was recognized for his standout appearance (featuring friendly mutton chops), a gravelly voice, and a distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming poses significant human impacts, specifically threatening food security due to declining crop yields and forcing the abandonment of populated regions as sea levels rise.

“Australia” is a 2008 Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann, starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. The passage emphasizes Baz Luhrmann’s role as director and highlights the movie’s epic historical romantic drama elements featuring those two leads.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born on June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, mainly for the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a range of cultural expressions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and the traditional practices of food-making and craft-making. It also features oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit was responsible for creating over 400 propaganda and training films known for being both informative and entertaining, and it also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones (author) won the 1952 National Book Award for his first novel “From Here to Eternity,” which was quickly adapted into a film and later made into a television series. Separately, James Jones (basketball player) was a high-scoring high school player who went on to win three NBA championships—two with the Miami Heat and one with the Cleveland Cavaliers—and make seven consecutive NBA Finals appearances alongside teammate LeBron James. He also excelled in three-point shooting, finishing third in three-point percentage during the 2007–08 season and winning the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked by the American Film Institute in 1999 as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process of creating animated images, and “Trollhunters” is an American computer-animated fantasy TV series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, and his departure became effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, a longer run than any other Doctor. He also narrated the comedy series Little Britain and has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town situated in the commune of Fischbach, located in central Luxembourg.

Hanford Site hosts a cleanup project, a commercial nuclear power plant called the Columbia Generating Station, and research facilities such as the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official appointed by the President to serve as spokesperson for the executive branch, especially regarding the President, senior executives, and policies. While this position does not require Senate confirmation, it is highly prominent due to frequent public briefings through media.

Kentucky, nicknamed the “Bluegrass State” due to its fertile soil and distinctive bluegrass pastures, features a prominent Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky that includes Louisville and Lexington. The state is recognized for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site “My Old Kentucky Home,” automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
"Broken Bridges" is a 2006 film featuring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also appeared in "The Cat in the Hat" and "Old Dogs."
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987 and formerly stylized as Ke$ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW, initially broadcast via closed-circuit TV and eventually on pay-per-view. In 1987, after WWF introduced Survivor Series on Thanksgiving and demanded exclusivity from cable providers, Starrcade became the first NWA event to air on pay-per-view. In 2014, older Starrcade events (1983–1986) were added to the WWE Network pay-per-view section with a TV-MA rating, largely due to violent matches. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual event in the series.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
"Star Trek: Discovery" is the first Star Trek series created specifically for its streaming service and also marks the franchise’s first new series since "Star Trek: Enterprise" ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played professional football as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and he also played in the World League of American Football with the Rhein Fire.

"Excuse My French" refers both to the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and to a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, which is based on Salama’s experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. Additionally, the passage notes that Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.

A floppy disk is a flexible magnetic storage medium contained within a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric that removes dust particles. It is also referred to as a floppy, diskette, or simply disk.

Guatemala experienced prolonged instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. Between 1960 and 1996, the country was embroiled in a civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military perpetrated genocidal massacres against the Maya population.

Forceps are a handheld, hinged instrument primarily used for grasping and holding objects. They can be referred to as forceps or forcipes in plural form, and outside medical contexts, they are commonly called tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
