TLP also accuses NRW of not sharing its calculation methods, while NRW insists its estimates come from the best available evidence, supported by independent experts. The £1.3 billion project is seen as a test bed for larger lagoons around the Welsh coast, with the Welsh government supportive but awaiting the UK government’s review and decision on the scheme’s viability.

Northern Ireland’s Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster has announced the creation of a new, industry-led agri-food marketing body to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). Modeled on the success of Scotland Food and Drink, it aims to unify and strengthen the marketing efforts of government and private sector organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move, citing the agri-food sector’s vital role in export-led growth, while acknowledging that this body could affect the work of other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is creating one of four new UK woods at Brackfield Wood, near Derry, to commemorate those who died in WWI. They aim to plant 40,000 native trees here, representing the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives. Members of the public are encouraged to participate in planting events, with the trust providing saplings and guidance. The site will feature wildflowers such as poppies, offering a place for wildlife to flourish and for visitors to reflect on the conflict’s legacy.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for “Someone Else’s Skin,” praised as “finely written” and “an emotionally exhausting and powerful story” dealing with domestic violence and honour crime. The award ceremony opened Harrogate’s annual crime writing festival, chaired by Ann Cleeves, who noted a very strong shortlist. Meanwhile, Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her work creating detective VI Warshawski, a groundbreaking female protagonist. Paretsky was also recognized for founding Sisters In Crime, an organization supporting women crime writers worldwide.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, scuttling both his personal plans and the team’s qualification hopes. He will return to the club after June’s ICC Trophy, aiming to make up for lost playing time. Worcestershire’s director of cricket, Steve Rhodes, expressed confidence in Santner’s abilities and lamented his early departure. In August, the county also signed Australia’s John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, aged 47, died in 2008 in Kiev when he was struck by a speeding car with stolen license plates as he stood on the hard shoulder, allegedly inebriated and trying to hail a taxi. At the time, his wife, Ganna (“Anna”) Ziuzina—19 years younger and met online—had briefly returned to a restaurant. Soon after Pring’s death, Ziuzina attempted to claim his assets, and his family believes the hit-and-run was staged to secure his inheritance. An inquest in the UK determined it was an unlawful killing. Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but reopened it in 2011 as a murder investigation; however, it is not being actively pursued.

Charlie, who has been ill since he was three, urgently needs additional T-Cell Therapy in Seattle after his previous transplant failed. His parents, Sophie and Rob, had no further treatment options in the UK. An anonymous donor, described as “selfless” and “amazing,” offered to cover the cost, and the hospital confirmed the financial clearance. The family, from Merseyside, is overwhelmed and plans to begin therapy as soon as possible.

Apple has introduced two-step verification for iCloud backups in response to recent hacks that exploited third-party software to download personal data from the cloud. This enhancement extends the existing login-focused two-step system to cover device backups, requiring an additional four-digit code or a 14-character recovery key for access. Although the measure blocks the hacking technique used by Elcomsoft’s software, it remains optional, prompting experts to suggest making it the default. Apple plans to increase awareness of the new security feature and encourage stronger passwords, with CEO Tim Cook highlighting the need for greater user education around safeguarding accounts.

Mark Wright is set to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town, though the exact details of the deal remain undisclosed. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old, who once played non-league football for teams including Lewes and Crawley Town, may become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently taken over by millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who invests £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr Ashley has been asked by the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to give evidence about working conditions at Sports Direct’s Derbyshire warehouse following a BBC investigation. He must respond by 21 March to a letter from committee chair Iain Wright, which states that the committee intends to meet in public at Westminster. Although alternative dates were suggested, Mr Ashley has not accepted or agreed in principle to attend. If he fails to comply, the committee may pursue a complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not commented but previously pledged a review of worker rights overseen by Mr Ashley.

The passage discusses a report, “Putin. War,” compiled by associates of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, primarily led by Ilya Yashin. It argues that Russian soldiers and equipment have played a decisive role in major rebel victories in eastern Ukraine, contradicting official denials that Russia is directly involved. The report brings together evidence from Russian and foreign media, including accounts of volunteers being paid substantial salaries and allegations that top Russian generals are in charge of military operations. It also highlights the high financial cost of the conflict—estimated at 53 billion roubles—and notes that relatives of dead soldiers have remained silent, possibly due to fear. Despite efforts to publish and distribute the report, its authors question how many Russians are willing to confront these findings, as previous exposés by Nemtsov on corruption and the Sochi Olympics failed to spur widespread protests.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem confirmed he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the Welsh first minister, criticized the UK government for not letting him see or contribute to the Article 50 letter before its publication. He views this as part of an ongoing lack of respect toward the devolved administrations. UK ministers note that Wales was consulted informally, with Prime Minister May visiting multiple times. May’s letter promises consultation on the return of powers from the EU, hinting at new responsibilities for Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, but without clarifying precisely which powers or whether funds will accompany them. This uncertainty, particularly concerning post-2020 regional aid, has generated tension, and details may emerge in the forthcoming Great Repeal Bill white paper.

Two cars were damaged during an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the attacks on PSNI officers and the local community. A PSNI post stated that police were performing their duties when attacked and urged parents to be aware of their children’s activities.

Mr Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was dismissed following employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In a court document responding to his defamation lawsuit, the board alleges that Mr Charney sent illicit emails with sexual content to female staff and used racially offensive language. It maintains that no reputable company would rehire him because of the legal and reputational risks. Mr Charney’s lawyer denies the allegations, accusing the company of privacy invasions and extortion. A restraining order prevents Mr Charney from publicly criticizing the firm or attempting to remove board members.

Great Britain’s only home game before competing at FIBA EuroBasket 2017 will be against Greece at London’s Copper Box, with coverage on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website. Greece won their previous match 92-64, but will be missing three players for the London game. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, excited to play in his home city, views the match as key preparation ahead of EuroBasket, where Britain’s qualifying group will be in Istanbul, Turkey, starting in early September. After facing Greece, GB will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament—their final warm-up games before EuroBasket begins.

The passage recounts how, soon after Steve Jobs unveiled the iPhone in 2007, a BBC journalist managed to briefly borrow Phil Schiller’s device for a news segment, drawing both excitement and criticism for giving the new product major coverage. Reflecting on the moment years later, the journalist notes that the iPhone introduced a step change in personal technology—revolutionizing photography, internet use, and overall mobile habits—and paved the way for modern smartphones. This marked the shift into a new “mobile connected era,” later advanced by companies like Amazon and Google.

Several cats in the Victor Avenue area of Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting antifreeze, although it is not yet clear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. A seven-month-old cat named Meereen was the most recent to die; three others died in the past week, and another died two weeks ago. Meereen’s owner, who found the cat foaming at the mouth, described being devastated by the loss. The RSPCA confirmed that all affected cats had consumed antifreeze and is urging residents to store chemicals safely and check for leaks or spills, particularly during this time of year when antifreeze is commonly used in cars.

Greece is poised to accept a third bailout with more austerity and liberalization, even though Syriza previously opposed such measures. Surprisingly, there are no large protests, and tourism is booming with record arrivals. Prime Minister Tsipras, still popular, appears to have been forced into accepting these terms by Greece’s near-collapse in July, turning Syriza into believers in “TINA” (“there is no alternative”). Yet the economy still suffers from partially shut banks, hindering both credit and confidence. Many argue that meaningful debt relief—perhaps by a third to a half—is essential if this bailout is to spur genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor’s character, Peggy, who is dying from cancer. Peggy reappeared after several years away to tell her son Phil that her illness had returned. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990 to 1999 and again in 2005–2006, is returning to reunite the Mitchell family during Peggy’s last storyline. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the significance of bringing the Mitchell brothers back together for these emotional scenes.

Alice Ruggles was stalked by Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon before he fatally attacked her. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recalled knowing immediately that Dhillon was responsible when police informed them of her death. Alice’s mother expressed deep guilt for not taking her daughter’s fears more seriously, and her father noted that none of them recognized how severe the threat was. They have since set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDF’s board approved funding for an £18bn nuclear power plant at Hinkley Point, with one-third of the investment coming from China. However, immediately after EDF’s decision, the UK government announced a further review, delaying final approval. Critics warn of high costs, environmental risks, and EDF’s own financial strain—two senior executives have already resigned over these concerns. Supporters argue Hinkley Point would supply about 7% of the UK’s electricity and deliver benefits for both the UK and French nuclear industries. The government’s postponement raises questions about whether it is simply reviewing details or reconsidering the entire policy.

The newly introduced divorce form in England and Wales explicitly asks applicants to provide the name of the person their spouse is accused of committing adultery with, although doing so is not mandatory. Lawyers warn that naming a third party can escalate conflict, delay proceedings, and increase costs. The updated form aims to be more user-friendly, yet critics argue the clear invitation to name the third party may be hard for some to resist. Official statistics show that of approximately 100,000 divorces in 2015, 12,148 cited adultery. Legal experts emphasize that judges discourage bringing the new partner into the proceedings, as it can cast the petitioner in a negative light. The Ministry of Justice maintains that while the form allows naming the third party, there is no requirement to do so.

Britain is a major wood importer, yet commercial forestry groups worry current policy prioritizes environmental goals over growing conifer forests for timber. They note that more than 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost in Wales since 2001, threatening an industry worth over £450m annually. Welsh government strategies promote native species, recreational access, and conservation, but Confor argues that bureaucratic hurdles and limited replanting (only 90 hectares recently vs. the 20,000 needed) hamper timber production. The government aims to balance economic, social, and environmental needs through initiatives like its Glastir scheme, but tensions remain over land use and community impact.

A boy was struck in Coatbridge on Bank Street, near Langloan Primary School, at about 16:40, sustaining serious injuries. Emergency services attended, and he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Russia’s Ushakov medals were awarded to British veterans of the WWII Arctic Convoys, who had braved extreme weather, German U-boat and aircraft attacks, and severe winter conditions to supply the Soviet Union. Initially, the British Foreign Office blocked the honor due to rules on foreign awards, but later allowed an exception. Previously, the UK introduced the Arctic Star to recognize the sailors’ service. Eventually, President Putin presented the first medals in June 2013, recognizing their essential contribution in aiding the Soviet Eastern Front.

HM Inspectorate of Probation’s report revealed considerable delays in starting community payback projects and frequent lack of enforcement when offenders failed to attend. In one example, an individual had completed only 16 hours of work over 17 months. Some 70,000 offenders were given unpaid work in 2014, including tasks like gardening and litter-picking, but significant organizational issues and difficulties managing those with chaotic lifestyles undermined this “tough” alternative to prison.

Despite praising some high-quality placements and the skills gained by certain offenders, inspectors noted that too often the work was treated merely as punishment. They urged community rehabilitation companies to reduce turning away offenders who arrive on time and to design objectives better suited to each person. The chief inspector called for “urgent remedial action,” and the Ministry of Justice has accepted the recommendations, promising more effective rehabilitation and stronger consequences for non-attendance.

Russell Brand has been labeled a “hypocrite” by The Sun for advocating economic and political revolution on behalf of poorer people while living in a luxury home. During a campaign outside Downing Street, a reporter pressed him on his own expensive accommodation, prompting Brand to cut the interview short. Though he has not replied to inquiries about potential legal action against The Sun, he has addressed the accusations on Twitter using the hashtag #TheSunLogic. In past statements, Brand acknowledges his wealth and fame but insists personal and systemic change are both necessary. He admits to having made mistakes under capitalism, yet argues that highlighting inequality remains crucial, even if it exposes him to charges of hypocrisy.

Dr. Craig Venter gained prominence by transforming the Human Genome Project into a high-stakes race, attracting criticism for his competitive approach and disregard for certain scientific conventions. Originally an unremarkable student, he served in Vietnam, which inspired his pursuit of medicine and shaped his sense of urgency. Transitioning from the US National Institutes of Health into private ventures, he accelerated gene sequencing methods, first decoding a free-living organism’s genome in 1995, then co-leading the successful effort to map the human genome by 2001. His financial success led him to establish the J Craig Venter Institute, where he spearheaded the creation of “Synthia,” the first synthetic life form. Alongside these pursuits, he also conducted extensive oceanic research to sequence marine microbes. Venter continues to embrace controversies, believing synthetic microbes could spur an industrial revolution, reduce reliance on oil, and mitigate environmental damage.

Researchers surveyed around 1,000 parents in England and found that four in five children who ate school lunches had tried foods at school they had not eaten at home. Half of those parents said their children had asked for these new foods at home. Popular vegetables included carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least favored. Driven by a suggestion that some parents pack lunches because of picky eaters, the School Food Trust highlighted the benefits of school meals for broadening children’s diets. About 40% of English primary pupils and 46% of Scottish pupils currently eat school lunches.

Alvaro Morata, aged 23 and playing for Spain at Euro 2016, originally came through Real Madrid’s youth system and made his first-team debut at 18, scoring 10 goals for the club. In 2014, he transferred to Juventus with a reported buyback clause for Real, believed to be up to €30m. During his two seasons in Italy, he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in the 2015 Champions League final (scoring in a 3-1 defeat to Barcelona). Morata, previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, has netted three goals for Spain in the current tournament.

Wilson, aged 30, returned to Nottingham Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5m. He made 51 appearances in this second spell before being released in May. Previously, he spent four seasons at Forest prior to joining Celtic and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world’s third largest retailer, is disposing of its loss-making US chain, Fresh & Easy, to private equity firm Yucaipa. About 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while around 50 of the 200 stores are expected to close. As part of the deal, Tesco will provide an £80m loan and incur up to £150m in disposal costs, though a portion may be reimbursed. Tesco retains an option to buy a stake if Fresh & Easy becomes profitable. This move follows Fresh & Easy’s consistent losses since its 2007 launch and coincides with Tesco’s first fall in annual profits in 20 years.

An athlete who faced racial abuse discusses with BBC Sport's Nick Hope how he overcame those challenges. After briefly considering competing for France, his current goal is to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, the passage directs readers to a special guide for getting involved in martial arts.

Over the past four decades, glaciers in the French Alps have diminished significantly—dropping from about 375 sq km of ice coverage in the late 1960s/early 1970s to roughly 275 sq km by the late 2000s, representing an average 26% loss. A new inventory from researchers led by Marie Gardent shows that shrinkage is greatest in the southern massifs, such as Belledonne and Ecrins, which have lower elevations and different climatic conditions. Meanwhile, northern regions with higher peaks and more precipitation—like Mont Blanc—have seen slower retreat rates. Manual checks supplement automated methods of mapping glacial extents, helping account for debris cover and shading that can cause underestimation.

Scotland’s women’s team is on the brink of qualifying for their first major tournament, having won all five of their qualifiers so far. The upcoming matches against fellow unbeaten side Iceland—who sit just one world ranking place above Scotland—are likely to determine who tops the group, although Scotland could still qualify automatically as one of the best runners-up.

Forward Lisa Evans, a 24-year-old Bayern Munich player, highlights the heartbreak of narrowly missing out on the Euros in 2013 and last year’s World Cup. She stresses the benefit of having more national-team players competing abroad—such as Kim Little in the US—believing their diverse experiences strengthen Scotland’s push for a place in the finals.

Stuart Campbell, a pro-Scottish independence blogger who runs the “Wings Over Scotland” site, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint by a woman in south London alleging two years of online harassment. He was released on bail and denies any threatening behavior, stating the arrest concerns tweets that remain publicly visible. The Metropolitan Police confirmed an ongoing investigation into the harassment claims. Campbell criticized media coverage for encouraging speculation and maintains that no serious or sinister actions were involved beyond the tweets.

Peta has proposed replacing Skegness’s Jolly Fisherman mascot, claiming it promotes animal cruelty, with a fish character under the slogan “Skegness – A Happy Plaice.” They argue that the Jolly Fisherman symbolizes the harming of sea life. The design, originally commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908 with the slogan “Skegness is so bracing,” is strongly associated with the town. Skegness’s mayor welcomes suggestions but doubts there is support to remove the mascot, seeing Jolly as a positive and long-standing symbol for residents and visitors.

Scotland fell behind early to a Vasil Lobzhanidze try but quickly took control, racking up tries through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try (after Georgia collapsed a rolling maul), Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson’s powerful run extended the lead soon after the break. Georgia’s scrum then drove Scotland back for Lobzhanidze’s second try, but Scotland hit back with an exhilarating length-of-the-field counter-attack finished by Hogg for his second score. Despite Georgia’s scrum causing problems in the second half, Scotland’s dominance in possession, territory, and clinical finishing proved decisive. Head coach Vern Cotter praised his team’s first-half performance and overall game management, noting Greig Laidlaw’s key role in controlling play. Both teams’ full line-ups are listed, highlighting Scotland’s and Georgia’s starting XVs and replacements.

Widnes led 14–6 at half-time through tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, with Castleford’s on-loan Widnes player Paddy Flynn replying. Further scores from Ah Van, Lloyd White (twice), and Joe Mellor stretched the lead to 38–12 soon after the break. Despite three Castleford tries in quick succession—one each from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and a final hat-trick effort by Flynn—Widnes held on for victory. The result moved Widnes up to seventh, just a point behind sixth-placed Castleford, who slumped to their fourth straight home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, held at Guantanamo since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban (which he denies), was released after a US review board deemed he no longer posed a significant threat. He returned to Kuwait, where he must spend at least a year in a rehabilitation program. His case was part of broader efforts by the Kuwaiti government to secure the release of all its nationals from Guantanamo, and aligns with President Barack Obama’s repeated pledge to close the prison, now down to 148 inmates.

Thousands attended a dawn Anzac Day service at Hyde Park Corner, followed by a parade at the Cenotaph where wreaths were laid. The commemoration, which marks the first major World War One battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces, also included a service at Westminster Abbey. Anzac Day services in London date back to 1916 and draw many expats who pay tribute to those who served in all conflicts. Speeches at the dawn service highlighted the courage and sacrifice of the Anzac troops during the Gallipoli campaign, a key and costly attempt to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

David Clarkson, aged 30, rejoined his former Premiership club in July and is now poised to make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and, although largely used as a substitute this term, says he is fully fit after playing regularly for the Under-20 side. Clarkson, who has almost 400 senior appearances and two caps (one goal) for Scotland, previously represented Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren currently sit eighth in the Championship, seven points above Alloa, and Clarkson hopes to help the team climb further up the table.

Bernard Matthews has been sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, and despite initial fears, Unite says the new owners will honor all existing pension arrangements. Bernard Matthews’ final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004; current employees have an alternative scheme which remains unaffected by the takeover. The new owners plan to return the firm to profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and by using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

Council leaders held a scrutiny meeting addressing the new chain ferry’s operational problems since its late launch on 14 May. These included breakdowns, grounding incidents, suspension for training issues, and vehicle damage. In response, the crossing is free until 2 July to gather feedback. Local businesses, citing lost trade, requested compensation. The council acknowledged “teething problems” and commissioned auditors to review the project. Ramp extensions are being made to reduce vehicle scraping, and compensation remains under discussion.

The House of Lords EU Committee warns that the UK’s fishing industry—though small in overall economic impact—must not be overlooked in Brexit negotiations. The industry relies on exporting most of its catch to the EU and importing much of what the UK consumer eats from EU waters. Allowing European boats access to UK waters may be a concession for maintaining favorable access to EU markets. Despite calls from industry advocates to take full control of UK waters and fishing policy after Brexit, the committee suggests that certain elements of the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy—especially science-based quotas—will likely continue and that coordinated management among England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland is crucial. Recent quota increases offer optimism, and the government views Brexit as a chance to forge a fairer, more sustainable fisheries framework.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting indecent images of children between April 2004 and February 2014. Earlier in the year, he was placed on a community payback order, enrolled in a sex offenders programme, and added to the sex offenders register. A General Teaching Council for Scotland (GTC Scotland) hearing concluded that his actions, which involved mostly partially dressed young boys in erotic poses, were incompatible with the teaching profession. Citing the lengthy period and volume of images, the panel found him unfit to teach, removed him from the register, and prohibited him from reapplying for two years. Geaney was not present at the hearing.

Firefighters tackled a blaze at the Duncan Street site beginning 2 March, causing reduced train services and delays. As a result, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste, ultimately revoking its environmental permit effective 7 August. The EA took enforcement action after the fire service, which had made multiple visits and deemed the site broadly compliant with fire safety law, raised concerns in February about the potential impact on residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad insists Syria is working to meet the schedule for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline and facing attacks on convoys transporting them to the port of Latakia. He dismisses allegations of government barrel bombings in Aleppo, despite observer reports of many civilian casualties, and rejects US condemnation as “unacceptable.” There is also dispute over control of Aleppo’s central prison: government forces deny that rebels have seized it, though some activist groups claim they have. Only a small fraction of Syria’s declared 1,300-tonne chemical stockpile has so far left the country, leading the US to express concern, but Russia expects completion of transfers by 1 March. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons acknowledges security issues are slowing the process, yet Syria insists it will fulfill its obligations on time.

England leveled the series with a dominant victory at Old Trafford, declaring twice (589–8 and 173–1) and bowling Pakistan out for 198 and 234. Joe Root, promoted to number three, earned man-of-the-match honors with 254 and an unbeaten 71, plus four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook also contributed centuries, while coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root’s response to earlier dismissals. Commentators Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott highlighted England’s “absolute hammering” of Pakistan, suggesting their opponents were out of confidence and hard work is needed. Pakistan’s captain Misbah-ul-Haq admitted disappointment with his side’s batting, and the teams now head to a tour match at Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of residential care in Wales by gathering direct experiences from older people, their families, and carers. The review aims to highlight both good and poor care practices, focusing on factors such as health, social relationships, and care home environments. Recommendations will be developed for providers and public bodies based on these findings to improve the quality of life for older residents. While Mario Kreft of Care Forum Wales supports the overall aims, he expresses disappointment that the advisory panel does not include a care provider expert.

Paul Sheerin, 39, a former Aberdeen midfielder, served as Arbroath’s player-manager from 2010 until taking over Neil Cooper’s role at Pittodrie. Arbroath finished bottom of League One in 2013–14, resulting in relegation to League Two. Aberdeen’s Derek McInnes chose Sheerin following a “comprehensive process,” with Arbroath chairman John Christison understanding Sheerin’s wish to rejoin Aberdeen. Before coaching, Sheerin played for multiple Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, earning a Scotland U21 cap in the mid-1990s. He guided Arbroath to their first-ever national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title (and promotion) in 2011.

Swansea City interim boss Alan Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead the team against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s dismissal. The club is seeking a swift appointment of a new manager, with Paul Clement as the preferred candidate. Curtis cites the risk of relegation and notes that returning to the Premier League would be challenging, underscoring the club’s remarkable rise from potential bankruptcy to top-flight stability. He believes Swansea have lost some of the “Swansea Way,” particularly since Michael Laudrup’s departure, and that frequent managerial changes and the loss of key players have diluted the club’s distinctive style. Nevertheless, Curtis maintains the current squad can survive, emphasizing the significance of Swansea’s history and community importance to every new signing.

Dr Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for accelerating the effort to map the human genome, which he turned into a competitive race. He left public research to found private institutes and achieved milestones like publishing the first complete bacterial genome and contributing to the publication of the human genetic code. His success and methods stirred controversy, particularly over data-sharing conventions. With substantial private means, he founded the J Craig Venter Institute, creating the synthetic organism Synthia and undertaking ambitious projects, including surveying ocean microbes. Despite criticism, he believes synthetic microbes could propel a new industrial revolution by helping move beyond oil and capturing carbon dioxide.

The passage highlights concerns that apprenticeships in England are often too short, low quality, and predominantly below level three, with many going to older workers already in employment. In contrast, Germany offers substantially higher-level apprenticeships to young people, reflecting a more coherent and respected vocational system. The Sutton Trust recommends creating up to 300,000 new apprenticeships each year—primarily longer, level three (A-level equivalent) or level four courses—to improve both economic competitiveness and social mobility. While the Department for Education notes reforms to raise standards, the Association of Colleges stresses that some level two courses (e.g., in construction) remain valued and that significantly expanding available places would be a considerable challenge.

Sarah Storey, a 37-year-old British Paralympian, won her latest cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska. Already Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze) across six Paralympics, she can secure her 17th world title in the upcoming road race. Originally a swimmer, Storey earned six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005; she went on to win four golds at the 2012 London Games and now holds 21 world titles in both sports.

Hereford United were expelled from the Conference after repeatedly failing to pay football creditors by multiple extended deadlines. Despite a dramatic final-day escape on the pitch, Chester have been reinstated to the Conference Premier in their place. The club’s debts, including unpaid wages and outstanding tax to HMRC, totaled around £225,000; efforts by the Hereford United Supporters’ Trust to buy the club for £1 were rejected in favor of a takeover by Tommy Agombar, which ultimately did not resolve the financial crisis. The downfall followed falling attendance figures since relegation from the Football League in 2012, and those players who worked hard to avoid relegation now see their efforts come to nothing.

James Milner, aged 30 and formerly of Manchester City, earned 61 England caps after debuting in 2009. He was selected for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for most appearances (46) for England’s Under-21 side. He registered his only senior international goal in a 5-0 victory against Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a leading conductor and pioneer in historically informed performance, died at his home in Cambridge after several months of illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it worldwide for some 30 years, overseeing more than 200 recordings, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He also held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin in the Fields, the Early Music Consort of London, the King’s Lynn Festival, Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues and friends remembered him as a generous, brilliant academic with a deep passion for letting the music “speak for itself.” A private funeral will be followed by a memorial service at a later date.

A family in Northern Ireland removed their son from mainstream schooling due to his difficulties coping. They have been waiting for a special school placement but were told that local special schools are at full capacity, with no available timeframe for admission. While an additional classroom assistant has been hired at one local special school, offering hope of placement soon, the mother remains concerned that the overcrowded system will continue to affect other families. The Education Authority stated that it cannot discuss individual cases but is currently reviewing the need for special school places to ensure availability closer to children’s homes from 2016 onward.

Newport Gwent Dragons are facing a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), which intends to maintain Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue. However, Newport County hold a lease until 2023, granting them fixture priority if they stay in the Football League. The WRU’s takeover will be voted on in early May; if approved, they hope to install an artificial surface, currently against Football League rules. Meanwhile, Newport County—two points clear of relegation—face a crucial end to the season, with relegation considered a major setback for both the club and the city.

Sierra Leone was recently declared free of a virus outbreak that killed nearly 4,000 people. In the passage, a former child soldier recounts how he was kidnapped at 15 by the RUF rebels, forced into brutal violence, and marked with their initials. After escaping, he found support through preacher Richard Cole, who helped him pursue an education and a purpose. During the Ebola crisis, he worked with others to educate communities, provide supplies, and establish a treatment unit, saving many lives. Now he regrets his past but focuses on investing in youth and rebuilding the nation.

A major 80,000-piece Wedgwood collection was in danger of being auctioned to cover the firm’s pension debt. A public fundraising campaign reached its goal within a month, ensuring the collection remains at the Wedgwood Museum in Staffordshire. Led by the Art Fund, it will be formally gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and loaned back to Wedgwood, preserving a significant piece of Britain’s cultural heritage.

Dan Groves confirmed that details are still being finalized on a potential deal for Mark Wright to purchase a 20% stake in Billericay Town, with reports suggesting Wright will become a director. The club, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has pledged £10,000 a week. Wright, known for his runner-up finish on “I’m A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here” in 2011, previously played non-league football for several teams, and Billericay recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute when Nathan Delfouneso’s chipped cross found Jamille Matt, who scored from close range. Colchester equalized five minutes later through Kurtis Guthrie following a scramble in the box. Both teams missed clear chances—Blackpool’s Tom Aldred headed wide, and Colchester twice came close just before halftime. In injury time, Colchester’s Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

Developers plan to transform the disused Fawley Power Station, which closed in 2013, into a £1bn waterfront “merchant city.” Its 198m chimney, once part of a 2,000 MW oil-fired station that powered one million homes, will be preserved as the tallest attraction south of the Shard. The scheme includes a petal-shaped glass structure at its center, alongside a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferries to Southampton and Portsmouth. Planning permission is due later this year, and construction could start in 2018.

Great Britain won two medals at the Hong Kong championships: Elinor Barker’s silver in the women’s scratch event and Mark Latham’s bronze in the men’s scratch, where he surged late to finish behind Adrian Teklinski (gold) and Lucass Liss (silver). The men’s team pursuit lost to Italy for bronze, and Joe Truman went out in the men’s keirin semi-final. In the women’s team pursuit, a young British squad with Elinor Barker joined finished fifth, missing a medal ride but showing promise for the future. Katy Marchant, Great Britain’s sole female sprinter, was knocked out in the first round but plans to focus on upcoming events as part of her preparation for Tokyo.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Dame Barbara Windsor’s final episodes. Barbara’s character, Peggy Mitchell, has been diagnosed with terminal cancer and will die in a spring storyline, prompting Grant’s return to reunite the Mitchell family. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006, expressed his friendship with Barbara and his desire to bring the Mitchell brothers together one last time. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the emotional impact of Grant and Phil reuniting to face their mother’s death.

Spurs lost at Liverpool after conceding two quick goals by Sadio Mane, prompting manager Mauricio Pochettino to criticize his team’s lack of desire and inability to handle pressure. He highlighted Spurs’ poor away record, particularly against top-six rivals, and warned that a widening gap to league leaders Chelsea would be difficult to overcome. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy also noted Tottenham’s disorganized defense and contrasting performances away from home, suggesting they stick to the back-three strategy used in previous big matches.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governor seats and had already won the presidency with Muhammadu Buhari defeating incumbent Goodluck Jonathan, marking the biggest setback for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost ground in several key northern states, retaining only eight governorships—mostly in the south-east—and it held onto the crucial oil-rich Rivers State. Some election results remain inconclusive, and violence occurred in parts of the country, but overall the polls were more peaceful than previous ones. The outcome leaves the PDP largely confined to a regional base, while the APC now controls most northern states and the commercial hub of Lagos, reflecting a major shift in Nigeria’s political landscape.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will introduce an augmented reality app that lets visitors trigger online content—like videos and interviews—by scanning signs and posters. Acts this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan notes that the feature allows people worldwide to experience the festival’s atmosphere, access updates, and even purchase tickets.

Several Birmingham schools—Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, Golden Hillock, and Saltley—were rated inadequate by Ofsted, prompting the Department for Education to consider terminating their funding agreements. Park View Educational Trust, which runs Park View and Nansen Primary, may be removed from managing the schools. Ofsted’s reports mention concerns about a “hardline Muslim takeover,” inadequate protection against extremism, and poor promotion of pupils’ spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development. Some head teachers describe intimidation and an “organized campaign” by certain parents. Lord Nash has demanded that the schools address issues such as segregation, discrimination, and curriculum breadth by early July or face loss of funding. Meanwhile, parents and staff at affected schools have challenged Ofsted’s findings, calling them biased and unrepresentative of their experiences.

Vincent Barker (Vinnie) died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution alleges optometrist Honey Rose failed to detect his swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation, leading to a buildup of fluid in his brain that caused his death. She denies gross negligence manslaughter. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man from an adult website, filming them, and sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim’s sister on Christmas Day. The offenses occurred between September 2013 and September 2014, and Weatherhogg also caused the woman’s sister and father to view sexual images. The case was passed to the High Court in Edinburgh because of its greater sentencing powers, and Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register. The victim stated she felt “blackmailed,” and the judge said the sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence, with Weatherhogg assessed as a moderate risk of sexual re‑offending.

Ireland posted 165‑5, led by Stuart Thompson’s 56, Gary Wilson’s unbeaten 41, and William Porterfield’s 39, but Afghanistan comfortably reached 171‑4 with notable contributions from Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). Ireland lost Paul Stirling early and fell short of their target total, a concern echoed by Porterfield, who felt an extra 15 runs might have pushed them toward 180. Spinner Amir Hamza (2‑23) was Afghanistan’s most successful bowler, and Ireland also suffered the setback of losing paceman Boyd Rankin for the T20s due to a back injury, though he is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs.

Barcelona maintain they have committed no wrongdoing regarding the signing of Neymar, for which they originally declared a €57m (£48.6m) fee. Allegations arose that the true cost, when incorporating various contracts, was far higher—eventually totaling around £106.8m, including wages, agent fees, and an additional tax payment. Sandro Rosell resigned as president amid accusations of financial misappropriation, which he denies. After a Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigating, Barcelona paid €13.55m in “complimentary” tax but still insist their initial payment was correct. Neymar, who is 22, has scored seven goals in La Liga and three in the Champions League for Barcelona this season.

Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to review the investigation into the murders of British tourists David Miller and Hannah Witheridge, whose bodies were found on Koh Tao on 15 September. They worked with Thai authorities—who have charged two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun—to assess evidence and confirm DNA findings. UK officials had voiced concern over the reliability of DNA testing and alleged mistreatment of the suspects. The British officers are returning home to compile a report on their findings and update the victims’ families. Post-mortems confirmed Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds; Thai police maintain the DNA matches the two Burmese suspects.

Scotland’s women’s team, having won all five qualifiers, face a crucial home match against an unbeaten Iceland side as they aim to secure top spot and qualify automatically for next summer’s finals. Forward Lisa Evans, now at Bayern Munich, is determined to avoid another near-miss after past play-off disappointments. She highlights Iceland’s status as top seeds and notes the Scots are also well placed to progress without needing a play-off, as the best six of the eight group runners-up qualify. Evans underscores the benefit of so many team members competing abroad—including in Germany, Sweden, England, and the United States—citing diverse playing experiences as a key factor in strengthening the national side. Fresh off winning the Bundesliga, she describes training with Bayern’s high-caliber squad as a privilege that raises her level, and believes that this kind of exposure to different football cultures ultimately enhances Scotland’s overall performance.

Apple has updated its security measures by extending its two-step verification system to iCloud backups, defending against third-party software that had been used to download user data. When activated, logging into a new device requires both the account’s password and a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone or via the Find My iPhone app. A separate 14-character recovery key can restore access if the trusted device is lost. Previously, even when two-step verification was enabled, attackers could still export complete backups through tools like ElcomSoft’s Phone Password Breaker. Now, those tools no longer work for that purpose. However, there are concerns about the potential for losing or misplacing the recovery key. Some experts believe Apple should make two-factor authentication a default setting, rather than an option, and continue efforts to encourage stronger passwords to help prevent future breaches.

UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Conservatives £2,980,815, the Lib Dems £1,580,575, Labour £1,027,339, the Greens £534,249, and the SNP £267,372 on their campaigns from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP’s cost per vote was 68p, Labour’s 26p, the Conservatives’ 79p, the Lib Dems’ £1.45, and the Greens’ 43p. Combined, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087. UKIP won the election, Labour placed second, and all but Labour spent more than in 2009.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has mutually ended his deal with Barrow to join another National League side and could face his old club on 18 February. Meanwhile, 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, recommended by Micky Adams, arrives from Irish football (pending international clearance). Torquay boss Kevin Nicholson views Anderson as the “leader-type” needed, while Keating is young, raw, and eager to prove himself. Torquay sit four points above relegation and have won just one of their past six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed shortly after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in Cheltenham’s Cotswold Chase and was pronounced dead from a rare “severe pulmonary haemorrhage.” Though he had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, which caused overheating and unsteadiness, he had never collapsed before. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) noted such incidents are rare, especially in horses with no significant underlying health issues, and pledged further research into prevention. Many Clouds had notable successes, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the “horse of a lifetime.”

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears during the final speeches of several retiring MSPs, including former first minister Alex Salmond and veteran Labour member Duncan McNeil. Salmond emphasized Scotland’s diversity and reiterated his view that greater powers are needed, while also injecting humor with references to the UK budget and the Cheltenham races. Marwick applauded his service to parliament and the country. McNeil’s emotional farewell focused on the need for stronger committee oversight at Holyrood, suggesting lessons could be learned from Westminster. Former Scottish Conservative leader Annabel Goldie also announced her departure, joking about her exchanges with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage announces casting updates for a live-action “Beauty and the Beast” film, set for US release on 17 March 2017. “The star” will portray Mrs. Potts, while Kevin Kline plays Belle’s father, Maurice. Emma Watson was earlier confirmed as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston; Josh Gad joins as Gaston’s sidekick, LeFou. Bill Condon will direct, with filming beginning at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decision on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects linked to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which 96 football fans died. Of these suspects, 15 are part of Operation Resolve’s investigation into the disaster’s causes, while eight relate to an Independent Police Complaints Commission inquiry into police conduct. Relatives of the victims have been invited to a private meeting, where they will learn the CPS’s intentions from Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division. Margaret Aspinall, whose son was among those who died, expressed hope that this move represents progress toward accountability, acknowledging the long struggle and the wide range of emotions for the families.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced multiple incidents of contraband—particularly mobile phones and synthetic cannabis—being thrown over its walls. Staff are working to stop smuggling, and residents living nearby have witnessed packages being tossed into the facility, although they say they do not feel threatened. A former inmate claims drones are used, though the Ministry of Justice reports no evidence of this at Chelmsford. In response, the Justice Secretary aims to ensure prisons have effective tools to combat the issue; current laws allow up to two years in prison for those caught smuggling.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old long-serving lollipop lady, was seriously injured outside Bedford Road Lower School when Brian Wright, 55, drove through a red light. Wright claimed he was blinded by the low sun and apologized in court for upending Blackburn’s life. Blackburn, now in residential care, had been escorting a mother and child across the road when she was struck. Wright expressed remorse, saying he has thought of little else since the incident. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, has chosen to skip next year’s Commonwealth Games in Australia because her veterinary medicine exams clash with the April event. Despite being disappointed to miss running for Scotland, she prioritizes completing her final year of studies. Muir, who finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Championships, remains optimistic about future competitions. She is considering the World Indoor Championships in March, feels in good shape, and is pleased with her recent personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m.

Trevor Deely, aged 22, disappeared in December 2000 after a work Christmas party in Dublin. A new search began in Chapelizod, focusing on a three-acre woodland area near the R112 and the River Liffey, and is expected to last weeks. Earlier in the year, six detectives conducted a full review of the case, enhancing CCTV footage. The footage shows Deely speaking with a man in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street, then being followed by the same individual on Haddington Road. Police are still appealing for this unidentified man to come forward.

Juan Martin Del Potro, returning from injury and ranked 165th, defeated Stan Wawrinka in four sets during his first Grand Slam appearance since 2014. He next faces either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young, sharing the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. Nick Kyrgios also advanced after overcoming Dustin Brown in five sets, setting up a meeting with Feliciano Lopez, who battled back to defeat Fabio Fognini. Meanwhile, Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga both cruised to straight-sets victories.

Tunisia narrowly avoided being expelled from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to Caf for its complaints following a disputed penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea. Meanwhile, Morocco reentered the 2017 competition when the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned its ban—initially imposed because Morocco had refused to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola concerns. Cas also reduced Morocco’s fine from $1m to $50,000. 

Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host the 2015 finals on short notice. Tunisia’s fury at the controversial penalty led to Caf demanding an apology or threatening Tunisia’s disqualification. Tunisian officials clarified they never accused anyone of corruption, but rather criticized the referee’s suitability. A meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou helped resolve the dispute, allowing Tunisia into the 2017 draw. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco is drawn with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

McLaren, one of F1’s most successful teams with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers’ titles, and eight constructors’ championships, has entered a slump that began in 2013 with a flawed chassis. Although historically they thrived—especially during their late-1980s Honda partnership and again with Mercedes engines in 1998–99—they have also suffered controversies, such as their 2007 disqualification and “lie-gate” in 2009. Now, despite having a promising car design, the renewed Honda power unit has been underpowered. Team boss Ron Dennis returned after 2013 to halt the decline, and Fernando Alonso joined in 2015 hoping for a third title, but so far success remains elusive. Nevertheless, McLaren believes they are on the verge of another upswing, banking on future Honda improvements to restore their former glory.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police arrived soon after and discovered patrons still on the premises, with till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar to close for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, was charged with two counts of permitting alcohol consumption outside licensing hours, while James Thomas, 44, faced one count. The court heard that licensing laws in Dungiven were not followed and the bar had been operating well into the morning. Citing O’Neill’s “appalling record,” the judge acknowledged he could not impose a custodial sentence. O’Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry led the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback win over the Portland Trail Blazers, breaking his own NBA record with eight three-pointers. Curry finished with 45 points and nine assists, assisted by Klay Thompson’s 26 points. LaMarcus Aldridge recorded 27 points and Damian Lillard 20 for Portland. In Chicago, Pau Gasol scored 16 with 15 rebounds, fueling the Bulls’ dramatic second-half turnaround over the Miami Heat, who were outscored 57-27 after halftime. Derrick Rose added 12 points as he continued his return from injury.

Bas van Velzen, a YouTube free-kick specialist, visited Liverpool’s Melwood training ground under the guise of a fan who had won a competition. Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic initially thought they were giving him a tutorial, but were surprised by his impressive free-kick skills. Van Velzen, whose football videos have made him a YouTube sensation, delighted in momentarily fooling the players before showcasing his talent. He relished the chance to meet and play alongside his idols, including Balotelli, and ended the day by revealing Balotelli’s famous slogan T-shirt.

Carriers of the BRCA1 mutation, like Angelina Jolie, significantly reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed (oophorectomy). A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with various BRCA mutations showed that for BRCA1 carriers, removing the ovaries after diagnosis reduced breast cancer death rates by 62% and lowered mortality from all causes by 65%. This protective effect appeared immediately and lasted up to 15 years, though it did not show the same benefit for BRCA2 carriers. Experts suggest that oophorectomy should be considered part of treatment discussions for BRCA1 mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. More research is needed, particularly for BRCA2 carriers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train shortly before 10 a.m. on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The train, traveling north from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for nearly three hours but continued on its route afterward. None of the 166 passengers were injured, although one person received medical treatment during the delay. A man who knew the couple suggested they might have been living in a homeless camp. Durham is located about 25 miles from the train’s next stop in Raleigh, and the journey from Charlotte to New York typically takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member, fled Colombia in the 1980s and spent 27 years as a DEA informant, aiding in high-profile operations against figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Though promised U.S. citizenship for his undercover work, he never received it. Now retired due to declining health, Toro’s final visa has expired, leaving him without legal status or access to benefits. He fears deportation to Colombia, where he believes he would be killed, and accuses the government of reneging on its promise. Former DEA colleagues have acknowledged his extensive service and criticized the bureaucracy preventing him from obtaining the promised legal status.

A Canadian company, Vox Populi, is selling “.sucks” domain names at high prices—often around $2,499 a year—targeting celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major brands to protect their reputations. Kevin Spacey reportedly paid to remove “.sucks” sites with his name, and Taylor Swift has taken similar measures with other domain extensions in the past. The U.S. internet regulator, ICANN, initially approved the “.sucks” domain but, after complaints from an advisory panel of companies like Microsoft and Verizon, has asked regulators in the U.S. and Canada to investigate whether Vox Populi’s practices are illegal. If found so, ICANN could deem Vox Populi in breach of its contract.

A baby boy was found floating in a Norfolk pond in 1988, his body wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag. Despite an initial investigation, police could not identify the mother and the infant, named “Peter” after the local St Peter’s Church, was buried by villagers. 

Years later, a periodic review led to the exhumation of the baby’s remains, and DNA testing matched a family member, ultimately identifying his mother. She confessed she had concealed the pregnancy, delivered a stillborn child alone, and placed him in the pond, fearing judgment. Police ruled out foul play, although the woman remains on bail for possible charges related to failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. 

Peter was reburied on the 26th anniversary of his discovery. Authorities emphasized modern forensic techniques and continued dedication to unsolved cases, expressing empathy for the mother’s emotional ordeal.

Taxi driver Michael Young unlawfully drove passenger Kristopher Hicks back to a taxi rank after wrongly suspecting he would not pay his fare. Hicks objected and, while the taxi was traveling at over 20mph, he jumped out, suffering severe brain injuries that now require round-the-clock care. A High Court judge found Young liable for unlawfully imprisoning Hicks and ruled that he must pay damages—though the award will be reduced by 50%. The final compensation amount is yet to be determined, but is expected to be in the hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Several tornadoes were reported in Kansas on Wednesday night, including one near Goddard that missed Wichita but threatened other areas. Additional sightings were noted in southwestern Kansas. Missouri was also affected, with a possible tornado in Potosi causing wind damage, flooding, and hail. CNN’s Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are especially dangerous. More storms are forecast Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to meet in a middleweight clash, with Rockhold promising to press forward aggressively—acting as “the bull” to Machida’s “matador.” Rockhold is on a winning streak, having last defeated Michael Bisping, and aims for a title shot. Machida, coming off a victory over CB Dollaway, believes his technique and strategy can stop Rockhold. Both acknowledge each other’s skills, but plan to impose their own styles in pursuit of a potential showdown for the title.

An aircraft in Fort Pierce, Florida, approached a residential airpark and landed without deploying its landing gear, scraping its belly and propellers along the runway. Realizing his mistake, the pilot immediately re-engaged the engines and took off again despite the propellers striking the tarmac. Remarkably, he then flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis—who has nearly five decades of flying experience—was accompanied by his dog, Buddy. The FAA is investigating the incident, which highlights that most gear-up landings result from pilot error or mechanical failure.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini admits disappointment with Yaya Toure's performances but pledges to support him until season's end. Club officials are open to offers for Toure—who still has two years on a lucrative contract—due to the team's underperformance, yet Pellegrini insists he remains an important player. Joe Hart acknowledges the squad has let the manager down, while Pellegrini himself faces questions about his future. Meanwhile, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce cautions Aaron Cresswell about moving to a bigger club like City, pointing to Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair as examples of English players who got limited opportunities after joining.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years, was originally sentenced to seven years in Italy in 1999 for “mafia association.” Although he lost his extradition battle in February, it emerged that under Italian law his sentence had effectively expired by October 2014, so Italy’s European Arrest Warrant is now withdrawn. Rancadore’s conviction still stands, but because too much time has passed, the sentence is no longer legally enforceable. Consequently, he is free to remain in the UK, and legal experts criticized the waste of time and public funds devoted to the extradition process.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites (alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre) for Saturday’s Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown. The race will be AP McCoy’s final Grade One ride; he and Mr Mole face six rivals, including Mick Channon’s Somersby. Nico de Boinville will ride Sprinter Sacre in place of the injured Barry Geraghty. McCoy’s full book of rides for his last day as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday. Notably, it was after winning with Mr Mole in February that McCoy announced his decision to retire.

Virginia Trimble Ritter’s daughter Marcia was raped and strangled by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia’s body was found 33 days after she disappeared, but her parents initially chose not to view it or the crime scene photos. Decades later, Ritter asked to see the images and was horrified by their contents. Barrett was eventually linked to the crime by DNA while he was in prison on other charges and convicted of second-degree murder in 2009, receiving a 44-year sentence. The case remained unsolved for 33 years before Barrett’s arrest.

Rory McIlroy regards winning the Masters as inevitable to complete his career Grand Slam, noting that failing to earn a green jacket would be a severe disappointment. He views his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011—when he lost a four-shot lead—as the most vital learning experience of his career. Despite only one top-10 Masters finish in six attempts, McIlroy believes Augusta suits him well and aims to join the select group who have claimed all four majors. He describes how personal challenges, including calling off his wedding and resolving a legal dispute, pushed him to regard the golf course as a sanctuary, helping him focus on his game.

It was a week packed with viral moments: a quadruple rainbow over New York, exotic dancers at wakes in rural China facing a crackdown, “rdj” growing upset over personal questions in an interview, and a new “lip plumping” trend (the #kyliejennerchallenge). A 102-year-old dancer revisited her past on film, a bomb-themed prom-posal drew controversy, Ewan McGregor joined “Beauty and the Beast,” Johnny Depp surprised viewers in the “Black Mass” trailer, and creative announcements—for pregnancy and a military dad’s photobomb—also caught widespread attention.

New data shows 272 children in England were hospitalized with fetal alcohol syndrome last year, though experts believe true numbers are higher. Research by the World Health Organization suggests at least 1 in 100 babies in the UK could be affected, leading to lifelong disabilities such as learning and behavioral problems. Fifteen-year-old Niamh Brown, for example, struggles with daily tasks and will likely never live independently due to her birth mother’s alcohol use. Pregnant women are currently advised to limit alcohol intake, but some experts, like Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organisation for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, advocate for complete abstinence.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, an ex-juvenile offender nicknamed “boomerang boy” for repeatedly returning home after crimes, attempted to rob a County Durham store by brandishing an axe. The shop owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry while Dhillon’s wife, Sam, struck him twice with a baseball bat to disarm him. McKerry was subsequently arrested, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery, and was sentenced to six years in prison. He had a long criminal history, including multiple arrests starting from the age of 12 and numerous offenses in his youth.

Four Royal Navy sailors were charged with sexually assaulting a young woman at a party in a Canadian barracks near Halifax, Nova Scotia. All four appeared in court and were released on bail under strict conditions: they must surrender their passports, remain at the nearby Stadacona naval base, stay in Nova Scotia, and avoid contact with the alleged victim or specified witnesses. They must remain employed by the Royal Navy, with their next court appearance set for May 27. The investigation is ongoing, and they could face up to 14 years in prison if convicted.

Valerie Jackson’s four-year-old son RJ suffers from Netherton’s syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that causes his skin to appear red, scalded, and scaly. Because of his appearance, Valerie has been reported for child abuse—at one point being surrounded by armed police while applying creams to RJ in a Walmart. She describes facing frequent ignorant and hurtful comments, with many people assuming she has burned her son. To manage the condition, Valerie regularly applies Vaseline or creams to RJ’s skin and bathes him sparingly to avoid drying it out further. Although there is no cure, over time symptoms can improve, and Valerie hopes greater awareness of Netherton’s syndrome will reduce the bullying and misunderstandings her family endures.

The passage describes the controversy surrounding Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” advertising campaign, which featured a bikini-clad model on posters across the London Underground. Many people found the message offensive and body-shaming, sparking a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, graffiti defacement, and complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority. Transport for London confirmed the ads were removed after their paid run ended, and Protein World—while defending the campaign—revealed they had received a bomb threat and other hostile reactions. Celebrity commentary ranged from criticism by TV presenter Susanna Reid to support from Katie Hopkins, with the brand maintaining that their aim is to encourage fitness.

Rail companies plan to raise some “unregulated” fares by as much as 87%, starting just days after the general election. Despite party leaders’ pledges to freeze prices, First Great Western (FGW) will nearly double certain fares between London and the Cotswolds, prompting Prime Minister David Cameron—whose Witney constituency is on that route—to request an urgent review. FGW says it is aligning the North Cotswolds route with the rest of its services and points to cheaper advance tickets as an alternative. Other operators, such as London Midlands and Virgin, will also introduce steep rises, though Virgin notes these mainly affect its “trains-only” fares, which it claims are still cheaper than competitors’ tickets. The higher costs come amid widespread political promises of fare caps or freezes, leaving passengers surprised by the impending increases.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was at home in Oldham with his wife Elaine, writing wedding thank-you cards just three weeks after their marriage. Vandals began throwing stones and then bricks at the property, smashing windows and the front door. When John opened the door to confront them, he was struck in the left eye by another brick. Despite emergency surgery, he lost sight in that eye. Police have launched an investigation, though no clear motive has been identified. Feeling unsafe, the couple plans to move away from the area.

Tom Poynton, Derbyshire’s wicketkeeper, missed the 2014 season after sustaining leg injuries in a road accident that claimed his father’s life. Following an ankle operation, he returned to action during the team’s pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. In recognition of his successful comeback, Poynton signed a one-year contract extension through the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire’s elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised his character and dedication, expressing confidence in his continued form.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed with an aggressive form of childhood cancer (neuroblastoma) in his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. During extensive treatment—80 days of chemotherapy, surgery to remove his kidney tumor, a stem-cell transplant, and radiotherapy—he drew global attention by decorating the protective radiotherapy mask as a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle to feel braver. Nickelodeon sent him Ninja Turtle gifts in support, and he has now been declared cancer-free. Harley has become the face of Cancer Research UK’s kids and teens campaign, embodying hope for other children facing cancer.

Tim Sherwood urges Jack Grealish to prioritize his Aston Villa performances rather than rush into choosing between the Republic of Ireland or England. Grealish, who impressed in Villa’s FA Cup semi-final victory over Liverpool, faces a national tug-of-war but is advised to keep developing at club level. Sherwood, referencing a similar situation with Nabil Bentaleb, says the decision is entirely Grealish’s. Grealish’s father, Kevin, agrees that focusing on club football is key before committing internationally. The consensus is that Grealish should continue showcasing his talent for Aston Villa, with the national choice to follow later.

Private jet travel is a booming industry worth trillions in the US and Europe, with millions of private flights each year. The passage highlights steep airport landing fees for private jets, especially at certain unexpected locations. Japan tops the list with the highest fees at Haneda, Narita, and Kansai airports. Other costly airports include Toronto Pearson, Darwin (Australia), Bristol (UK), Chūbu (Nagoya), Dublin, LaGuardia (NYC), and Salzburg—all charging thousands of pounds per landing. Major events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix also fuel private jet demand, driving up both flight costs and landing fees.

Cooper, a Labrador looked after by Katie Gallegos in Oregon, is known for his extremely fast eating habits. In a viral video, he quickly devours a McDonald’s ice cream cone in one bite, while his smaller companion, Daisy, enjoys a few daintier licks first. Despite criticism from some viewers about feeding dogs ice cream, Gallegos—who runs a dog resort—defends the occasional treat, citing previous dogs’ longevity and good health. Another clip shows Cooper and Daisy receiving a Starbucks “pup-uccino,” which is simply whipped cream in a cup, again demonstrating Cooper’s voracious appetite. Gallegos’s videos have collectively drawn millions of views online.

Gary Locke, previously Kilmarnock’s interim manager, has signed a three-year contract to take the position on a permanent basis. He took over from Allan Johnston at the start of February, having joined originally as Johnston’s assistant last summer. At 41 years old, Locke has lost only one of seven matches since stepping in and will address the media at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, says her son Logan—who is autistic and in kindergarten—was threatened with suspension because the DoTerra essential oils she applies to help him stay calm and focused were deemed a distraction by school staff. Though the school board initially stated the oils created a problem for others, Lake County School District later clarified Logan would not be suspended, calling it a health issue. Kemp insists the oils, which include scents like lavender and sandalwood, benefit her son and plans to continue using them.

A fire broke out at the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton on Wednesday, destroying 90 condos and causing the building to collapse. Smoke could be seen for miles, and the fire was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews responded but could not enter the structure. The complex, typically open from May to November, was used as a summer residence by owners, including the on-site building manager, who lost all his belongings. Officials are investigating the blaze, which may have started near a parked car.

Queen Elizabeth, who is 88 and nearing her 89th birthday, was recently seen riding her Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She famously never wears a helmet, preferring a silk scarf, and explains that she has always done so because of her hairstyle. A lifelong horse lover, the Queen began riding at age four after receiving a Shetland pony named Peggy. While a knee injury has led her to ride less in recent years, she remains devoted to breeding horses and ponies, including Fell and Highland breeds. Fell ponies, such as Carltonlima Emma, are an ancient, docile, and hardy breed originating in Cumbria. They stand 13–14 hands high, are typically black, grey, or bay, and have historically been valued both as pack and riding animals.

A dispute in a Brisbane neighborhood over late-night noise led to a fatal confrontation. Shift worker Phillip Pama, 28, allegedly delivered a single punch to his neighbor, 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, who was making noise around 9 pm.
